PETITION.TITLE: One World Declaration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, wish to record our support for the One World Declaration:
to focus Australian aid, and policies at the World Bank, IMF and Asian Development Bank, on fighting poverty and protecting the environment.
to restore Australian aid to 0.5% of GNP, cut military spending by 1% and work for a fairer international economic system.
to promote human rights through aid and a code of conduct for companies.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives call upon the Government to implement the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State public hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 133 citizens), Mr Beazley (from 525 citizens), Mr Braithwaite (from 19 citizens), Mr Robert Brown (from 25 citizens), Mr Cohen (from 25 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 88 citizens), Mr Grace (from 246 citizens), Mr Holding (from 108 citizens), Mr Kerin (from 112 citizens), Ms McHugh (from 556 citizens), Mr Millar (from 15 citizens), Mr Peter Morris (from 27 citizens), Mr Mountford (from 1,124 citizens), Mr Ruddock (from 393 citizens), Mr Shack (from 272 citizens), Mr Sinclair (from 97 citizens), Mr Smith (from 73 citizens), Mr Tickner (from 544 citizens), Mr Tuckey (from 217 citizens), Dr Woods (from 80 citizens) and Mr Wright (from 67 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
That the first duty of the parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life
That in 1987-88 alone Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $6.4 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they:

1. Deplore the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme `Authority only' drug list and the delisting of frequently prescribed drugs without ensuring that alternative products are readily available.

2. Deplore the proposed restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which will reduce both remuneration to pharmacists and the standard of professional service and counselling provided by pharmacists to ensure that patients follow appropriate medication usage regimes.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House do everything in its power to call on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and the Minister for Community Services and Health to reconsider the restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards (from 110 citizens), Mr Fife (from 133 citizens), Mr Tim Fischer (from 74 citizens), Mr Hicks (from 72 citizens), Mr Hollis (from 107 citizens), Mr Kerin (from 255 citizens), Mr Lavarch (from 117 citizens), Mr Mountford (from 147 citizens), Mr Sharp (from 64 citizens), Mr Sinclair (from 45 citizens), Mr Spender (from 97 citizens) and Dr Woods (from 12,887 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they:

Deplore the proposed changes to the method of Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration which will affect the quality of service and counselling the pharmacist will be able to provide to the public and which could force the closure of up to 30 per cent of Australia's pharmacies, particularly in country areas.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House do everything in its power to call on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and the Minister for Community Services and Health to reconsider these proposed changes to the method of Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hicks (from 352 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 19 citizens) and Mr Shipton (from 146 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: International Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
Our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating;
important natural resources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and the purity of air and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (the peoples' arm of the UN), has proclaimed an Australian ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade from 1988;
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a safer and more peaceful future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that a world-wide ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5 1990 with FIERY, the First International Earth Repair Year, and that this be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly. This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local and global co-operation to stop the current destruction and start repairing our Earth by: growing billions of trees to replace forests lost and to replenish the atmosphere; hygienically composting all presently wasted bio-degradable materials into humus to revitalise soils; establishing globally, economically viable, permanent self-sustaining organic agriculture to end world hunger. (See Draft Resolution to the United Nations)
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann (from 12 citizens), Mr N.A. Brown (from 12 citizens), Mr Cowan (from 56 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 12 citizens), Mr Goodluck (from 33 citizens), Mr Holding (from 26 citizens), Mr MacKellar (from 12 citizens), Mr Sinclair (from 37 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 174 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BLANCHARD; DAWKINS; FATIN; LLOYD; TUCKEY; WHITE
PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987-88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State public hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard (from 15 citizens), Mr Dawkins (from 16 citizens), Ms Fatin (from six citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 12 citizens), Mr Tuckey (from 14 citizens) and Mr White (from 443 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the House will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 1,137 citizens), Mr Cross (from 246 citizens), Ms Fatin (from 17 citizens), Mr Johns (from 224 citizens) and Ms McHugh (from 103 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Community Pharmacists
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they:
(1) Deplore the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme drug list and the delisting of frequently prescribed drugs without ensuring that alternative drugs are readily available.
(2) Deplore the proposed restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which will jeopardise the health care of Australians and force many pharmacies out of business.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House do everything in its power to call on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and the Minister for Community Services and Health to ensure that the viability of community pharmacists is maintained and that people continue to have ready access to the supply of pharmaceuticals and the professional services provided by pharmacists.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Downer (from 58 citizens), Mr Hicks (from 60 citizens), Mr Porter (from 194 citizens), Mr Sawford (from 118 citizens) and Dr Woods (from 7,256 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Community Pharmacists
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

That the proposed reduction in pharmacists' remuneration under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will be such as to produce severe cutbacks in the provision of services by community pharmacy in this country and will therefore cause unnecessary hardship and anguish to the sick and aged of this country.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House:

Takes all action within its power to bring about significant and decisive consultation between the Government and the pharmacists of Australia so as to produce a resolution of the matter which maintains both high quality health care for the community and equity for the community pharmacists of Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron (from 39 citizens), Mr Hollis (from 80 citizens), Mr Lindsay (from 80 citizens) and Mr Millar (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the increase in metropolitan house prices, which, together with the escalation in interest rates, is causing great hardship for many Australians attempting to provide housing for their families.

The petition also draws to the attention of the House the widely expressed need for a higher level of saving in Australia and the fact that the savings of ordinary Australians are currently penalised by taxation.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to enact legislation to provide for:

(a) the establishment of a savings fund open to all Australians but directed to young people for the deposit of a fixed percentage of their income from the time of their entry into the workforce until the age of 25 or earlier marriage;
(b) the exemption from income tax of interest earned on money invested in such a fund; and
(c) the provision by the fund of low interest housing loans to contributors to the fund.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fitzgibbon (from 1,098 citizens), Mr Webster (from 1,000 citizens) and Dr Woods (from 954 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the statement of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce expressing concern about Australia's low savings ratio and need to examine initiatives which encourage saving.
The petition also draws to the attention of the House the belief of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training that there needs to be a higher level of saving in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to enact legislation to provide for:
(a) the exemption from income-tax of interest earned on money invested in specified funds;

(b) a compulsory deferred pay scheme for all taxpayers under the age of 25, the moneys from which would be invested in specified funds, the proceeds of which would be paid to taxpayers on attaining the age of 25 years and participation in which would entitle taxpayers to a housing loan at low interest rates based on the amount saved in the scheme.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

the damaging effects to community pharmacy which will be caused by the most recent decision of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. We believe that if the decision stands, the entire Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will collapse. This will result in the loss of pharmaceutical benefits to all Australians and will hurt the aged and the chronically ill to the greatest extent.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to
set aside the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal's decision and ensure pharmacists receive an adequate and fair payment for dispensing medication and the provision of health care advice.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Gorman (from 39 citizens), Mr Price (from 5,523 citizens) and Dr Woods (from 180 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House, that pharmacists, in Australia, have had their very livelihood placed in jeopardy, by the totally unreasonable decisions, of the so called ``independent'' Pharmaceutical Benefits Tribunal, in drastically reducing the remuneration paid to pharmacists for dispensing of prescriptions under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
As a result of these decisions, the essential primary health care functions and services provided (largely free) by pharmacists to the public, have been seriously put at risk.

The replacement of such services could only be fulfilled by an already overtaxed medical profession and at a financial cost that would be virtually impossible to be funded by the Government or the Community.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to, as a matter of extreme urgency, negotiate with the appointed representatives of Australian pharmacists, to ensure that an equitable financial remuneration is granted to these pharmacists for dispensing prescriptions under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and so protect the essential services now provided by these pharmacists to the Community.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron (from 728 citizens) and Mr Tim Fischer (from 2,380 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
If open not-for-profit Health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, those costs need to be shared equitably.
Some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duncan (from 429 citizens) and Mr Porter (from 365 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Low Interest Housing Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the statement of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce expressing concern about Australia's low saving ratio and need to examine initiatives which encourage saving.
The petition also draws to the attention of the House the belief of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training that there needs to be a higher level of saving in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to enact legislation to provide for:
(a) the exemption from income-tax of interest earned on money invested in specified funds;

(b) a compulsory deferred pay scheme for all taxpayers under the age of 25, the moneys from which would be invested in specified funds, the proceeds of which would be paid to taxpayers on attaining the age of 25 years and participation in which would entitle taxpayers to a housing loan at low interest rates based on the amount saved in the scheme.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Goodluck (from 117 citizens) and Mr Miles (from 36 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity and continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his government
(1) to phase out woodchipping for export;
(2) not to renew a long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

(3) to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip export licence; and
(4) to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices including:
re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods on already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and
minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Holding (from 480 citizens) and Mr Tickner (from 116 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Dr Kim Jin-Yeop
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, wish to call upon the Australian Government to:
protest in the strongest possible way to the government of the Republic of Korea against the arrest and subsequent detention of Australian missionary and dentist Dr Kim Jin-Yeop.
demand his immediate release by the South Korean authorities and his total exoneration of the charge of ``Knowingly aiding a North Korean agent''.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives call upon the Government to implement the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms McHugh (from 322 citizens) and Mr John Scott (from 338 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Dr Kim Jin-Yeop
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.

We call for the Australian Government to protest in the strongest possible way to the government of the Republic of Korea against the arrest and sub- sequent detention of Australian Missionary and dentist Dr Jin Yeop Kim, demanding his immediate release by the South Korean authorities and his total exoneration of the charge of ``Knowingly aiding a North Korean agent''.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives call upon the Government to implement the above. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television: Northern Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

The residents of Northern Tasmania are disadvantaged by the lack of access to the Special Broadcasting Service. Northern Tasmania's migrant community, which is more physically and culturally isolated than their counterparts in more densely populated areas, are particularly deprived because of the lack of access to this service. Ethnic communities in Northern Tasmania can be small and scattered and they experience greater difficulty in establishing contact with others of their own ethnic background and have less opportunity for the sharing of information about community services.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:
Establish local transmission facilities to receive and locally transmit the SBS signal in Northern Tasmania.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Miles (from 591 citizens) and Mr Smith (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ruddock (from 48 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 29 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The Petition of certain Citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House, the inability of State and Local Government, to meet satisfactory road maintenance and construction programmes due to chronically inadequate Federal Government Funding.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House direct the Federal Government of Australia to increase the allocation of Federal Fuel Excise to roads by 10 cents per litre, from existing taxes. Further that the allocation be adjusted proportionally, to the rise and fall of fuel prices, and that the increased allocation continue from the year 1990 to 2000 inclusive.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Sharp (from 13 citizens) and Mr Sinclair (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Conservation and the Environment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

This petition of Australian citizens draws to the attention of the House that they are concerned at the threat to the environment which may result from an acceleration of the Greenhouse Effect. Your petitioners believe that urgent legislative action is necessary to protect the environment and reverse the damage already inflicted upon it. In particular, action is required to:
recycle products that save our trees and assist to eliminate waste;
stop deforestation of rain forests and provide funding to encourage tree planting;
ban the exporting and importing of chlorofluorocarbons with the same exceptions as those specified in the Ozone Protection Act;
ban all harmful chemicals, especially toxic bleaching chemicals used in paper mills throughout Australia;
monitor the disposal of waste chemicals and products by Australian firms;
punish illegal dumping of chemical waste products and accidental spillages;
introduce tax incentives for research, development, manufacturing and marketing of renewable energy alternatives and development of technology to reduce or avoid the use of chemical pollutants; and
recycle all household wastes.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take the necessary legislative action to promote all aspects of conservation and preserve our precious environment.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: We, the undersigned residents of New South Wales, draw the attention of the House to:
(a) the decision of the Government to increase the rate of the social security pension by $2 for single rate and $3.30 for married pensioners;
(b) the fact that this increase will not be received by pensioners until the pension payday in April 1990 at which a Consumer Price Index adjustment will also occur;

(c) the fact that this increase will raise the rate of the pension to a level at least equivalent to 25% of male employees' average weekly earnings, in fulfilment of a promise made by the Prime Minister in 1983.

We therefore pray that your House will urge the Government to increase the pension as indicated on the pension payday in November 1989 at which a Consumer Price Index adjustment will also occur-in view of the delay in fulfilment of the Prime Minister's 1983 promise.

PETITION.TITLE: Disposable Nappies
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled

This petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the House's attention to the presence of the cancer-causing waste product, Dioxin, in babies' disposable nappies which can be in direct skin contact for two years.
Your petitioners respectfully request the House to urge the Government to
(1) Initiate independent research into the precise levels of Dioxin in disposable nappies.
(2) Legislate to force nappy manufacturers to remove Dioxin from these products.
(3) Place pressure on nappy manufacturers to produce these products from unbleached paper therefore eliminating a significant cause of the presence of Dioxin.
(4) Place pressure on nappy manufacturers to produce bio-degradable disposable nappies which will be less harmful to the environment.

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Screening
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
about 1 in 16 Australian women develop breast cancer, that 1 in 45 risk dying from it, and that about 2,200 actually die from it each year;
while diagnostic mammograms requiring a doctor's referral are covered by Medicare, breast scanning mammograms for women who have no symptoms, or who are in a low risk category, are not.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to request the Government to implement a breast cancer screening program which is covered by Medicare, and which enables all women throughout Australia to readily access facilities for routine and expert mammographic examinations, in conjunction with a suitable education program offering specialist professional information and advice in regard to this important women's health issue.

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Screening
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament, this petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
About 1 in 16 Australian women develop breast cancer, that 1 in 45 risk dying from it, and that about 2,200 actually die from it each year;
While diagnostic mammograms requiring a doctor's referral are covered by Medicare, breast scanning mammograms for women who have no symptoms, or who are in a low risk category, are not.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the House require the Government to:
Implement a breast cancer screening programme which is fully covered by Medicare;
Make such a programme for routine and expert mammographic examination readily accessible to all women throughout Australia; and

Ensure that a suitable education programme offering specialist professional information and advice in regard to this important women's health issue is conducted in conjunction with the screening programme.

PETITION.TITLE: Credit Reporting
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to regulate credit reporting.
That it is essential for there to be commercial access to credit information on which to make sound commercial judgments.
That the new law will deny the undersigned petitioners their rights.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal to regulate credit reporting.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned draws attention to the House of the attack on community pharmacists if the Federal Government's proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme are undertaken.
The changes will penalise not only the pharmacists but the community and particularly pensioners because of the reduction in the level and quality of pharmacy services that will follow.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Fishing Vessels
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are desirous of preserving the existing fish stocks off the North West Coast of Australia for the benefit of all Australians.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. Not allow any further Foreign Fishing Vessels to operate off the North West Coast of Australia; and

2. Ensure that Foreign Fishing Vessels operating under existing Agreements off the North West Coast of Australia comply with all Commonwealth and State conservation and environmental protection laws and regulations.

PETITION.TITLE: Chlorofluorocarbons
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are concerned at the threat to the environment that may result from an acceleration of the Greenhouse effect.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government:
(1) To ban immediately both the exporting and the importing of Chlorofluorocarbons (CFC's) with the same exceptions as those specified in the Ozone Protection Bill.
(2) To introduce tax deductibility of-
(a) cost and installation of solar heating systems; and
(b) cost and installation of home insulation.
(3) To introduce tax incentives for-
(a) research and development of renewable energy alternatives;
(b) manufacturing and marketing of renewable energy alternatives; and
(c) development of new technology to reduce or avoid the use of environmental pollutants.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will legislate to provide these facilities.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens in the state of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That your electors and citizens are suffering grievously from the present compulsion to pay excessive rates of interest on the loans which we have been or will be obliged to accept in order to purchase a home, and

That we ask the Parliament to make a law before 30 June, 1989 which will prevent any bank or other financial institution from charging an annual interest rate in excess of fifteen (15) per cent in respect of loans or mortgages the purpose of which is the procurement of a dwelling for habitation by the borrower and his or her immediate family, and

That the welfare and security of your electors require an early further reduction of home-mortgage interest rates to a level not exceeding ten (10) per cent irrespective of any wage increases or tax remissions for which it may be proposed to legislate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whilst acknowledging the Government's desire to contain the growth in health costs, the introduction of 61 new drugs to the `Authority Required' listing will result in potentially serious delays in patients receiving medication prescribed by their doctors.
Your petitioners request the House to immediately reverse the Government's decision and withdraw these drugs from the `Authorities Required' list.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ozone Depleting Chemicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

This petition of certain students of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned about Ozone Depletion. Your Petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government to:
Adopt a strong stand against the manufacture, use and export of Ozone Destroying Chemicals such as CFCs and Halons.
Introduce legislation and other incentive schemes to stop the manufacture, use and export of Ozone Depleting Chemicals.
Take a leading role in the protection of Ozone at the renegotiation of the Montreal Agreement in 1990.

PETITION.TITLE: External Debt
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the following home buyers of Australia draws to the attention of the House their serious concern at the high level of mortgage interest rates.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House should introduce other methods of solving our external debts.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Piano Rolls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House that:
1. Sales tax was reimposed on the sale of piano rolls in Australia in the 1985 budget.
2. The Mastertouch Piano Roll Company (``Mastertouch'') of Crystal Street Petersham is the sole surviving commercial manufacturer of piano rolls in Australia.
3. The machinery used by Mastertouch in the piano roll manufacturing process has been classified by the National Trust.
4. Mastertouch is the sole remaining entity in Australia possessing the expertise and information required to perpetuate the art of piano roll manufacture.

5. The imposition of the sales tax and the consequent price rise in piano rolls, has placed in jeopardy the continued commercial viability of Mastertouch and if not removed will lead to the closure of Mastertouch and the cessation of piano roll manufacture in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the sales tax on the sale of piano rolls in Australia be removed and that all sales tax that may have accrued to date but remain unpaid be waived.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television: Goulburn Valley and North-Eastern Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
That people throughout the Goulburn Valley and North-Eastern Victoria request equal access for the extension of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS).

We believe that we are being discriminated against by the Government, when our area has a high percentage of residents born overseas in a non-English speaking country, and the total population exceeds one hundred thousand people.

Your Petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled to call on the Government to include our regional area along with the recently announced other nine regional areas to give us a ``Fair Go'' by extending (SBS) to our area.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that major reforms be made to Australia's Retirement Income System. These reforms are earnestly sought by retired Australians and those facing retirement.
The reforms are:
that the pension be increased to 30% of average weekly earnings (i.e. increasing the basic pension to $146 p.w.)
that the pension become tax exempt.
that the pension be adjusted so that it keeps pace with price rises rather than falling up to 12 months behind.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray that your House/Parliament will see that our requested reforms are implemented.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post Posting Box, Tasman Street, Devonport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament:

The Petition of citizens of Devonport in Tasmania are concerned at the proposed removal of the Tasman Street Australia Post posting box, which will cause considerable inconvenience to residents in the area, particularly those who are elderly and without transport.

The Petition also draws attention to the fact that this area in Devonport is growing with many units being constructed for elderly persons as well as the expansion of Bonds Weaving Mills in Tasman Street with a consequent demand for Australia Post posting box facilities.

Your Petitioners, therefore, request the House of Representatives to request the Federal Government to retain the Australia Post posting box in Tasman Street, Devonport between Greenway Avenue and William Street.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of certain children of Australia points out to the House that it is proposed to release radioactive water into Kakadu National Park from Ranger Uranium Mine, therefore causing great danger to Kakadu wildlife and possibly human life. Your petitioners therefore ask the House to prevent this from happening.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives that we strongly object to the Federal Government's high interest rate policies which are placing serious financial pressure on families.
In the past 12 months home loan interest rates have risen from 13.5% to 17% forcing many people to sell their homes or to delay the purchase of their first house.
We call on the House of Representatives to put pressure on the Government to change its policies to ease interest rates.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising by Political Parties
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the House to the threat to free speech contained within the recommendations of the majority report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

We believe that all persons have the right to express their views through paid commercial advertising on television and radio and that any limitation on that right constitutes a threat to the peoples' freedom of speech and to the Australian democratic system.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Parliament rejects the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and preserves the right of all persons and political parties to exercise their right to free speech through any media they choose.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That your electors and citizens are suffering grievously from the present compulsion to pay excessive rates of interest on the loans which we have been or will be obliged to accept in order to purchase a home, and

That we ask the Parliament to make a new law before 31st December 1989 which will prevent any bank or financial institution from charging an annual interest rate in excess of thirteen and a half percent in respect of loans or mortgages the purpose of which is the procurement of a dwelling for habitation by the borrower and his or her immediate family, and

That the welfare and security of your electors require an early further reduction of home mortgage interest rates to a level not exceeding ten percent per annum, irrespective of any wage increases or tax remissions for which it may be proposed to legislate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The 23rd of August 1989 is the 50th anniversary of the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact, which led to the outbreak of World War II. The pact included a secret agreement which divided Europe into a German and a Soviet sphere of influence.

The tragic consequences of this pact for the nations of Central and Eastern Europe have persisted to this very day. Without their removal the reconstruction of a unified Europe and the regaining of rights for self-determination by the enslaved nations of Central and Eastern Europe are impossible.
With this in mind, and appealing to an international sense of justice, your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government:

1. to demand that the Government of the USSR issue a declaration which recognizes that the Soviet-German treaties of 23 August and 28 September 1939, signed in Moscow by Ribbentrop and Molotov, were criminal by nature, devoid of any international legal base and invalid from the beginning;

2. to demand that the Government of the USSR withdraw all Soviet forces from Polish soil and from all other European territories annexed by the Soviet Union on the basis of the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact and the subsequent so-called plebiscites organized in those territories by the occupying Red Army;

3. to demand that units of the NKVD be put on trial for the genocide and war crimes on citizens of the conquered nations, including the Katyn massacre, one of the greatest crimes committed on prisoners of war, officers and men, of the Polish Armed Forces, a crime for which there has not yet been any judgement pronounced and punishment meted out.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens respectfully draws to the attention of the House:
``the ability of State and Local Government to meet satisfactory road maintenance and construction programmes due to chronically inadequate Federal Government funding''.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled, urge the Government:

``to recognise the threat to human lives from Australia's inadequate road system and increase significantly the existing 23% of present Federal fuel excise now available for roads and widen the categories of roads now entitled to assistance by measures to be included in the 1988-89 Federal Budget.''
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:
Kingsford-Smith Airport is becoming increasingly congested and existing facilities are inadequate to handle the number of aircraft or their passengers.

The diversion of aircraft from Kingsford-Smith Airport to Bankstown and/or increase landing charged for peak period will do little to relieve congestion and will place enormous financial and other burdens on commuter airlines and their passengers.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Give immediate approval for the construction of a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport, and upgrade the existing radar and traffic control facilities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Income Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the statement of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce expressing concern about Australia's low savings ratio and the need to examine initiatives which encourage saving.
The petition also draws to the attention of the House the belief of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training that there needs to be a higher level of savings in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to enact legislation to provide for:
the exemption from income tax of interest earned on money invested in specified funds;

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: This Petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the House to the Governments actions in relation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of service to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the House to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme, so as to guarantee the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE Videos, Films and Publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian community.
Because Parliament has direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child-victims, your petitioners therefore request the House:
to ban the importation, and availability of pornography in Videos, Films and Publications,
to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material,
vote against any recommendation to extend Video and Theatre Film Classifications and Guidelines into Television Standards,
ensure that Pay Television does not exceed the programme limits of Television standards,
control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation,

give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Investment in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of Australia, draws to the attention of the House that there is increasing levels of foreign investment in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will limit foreign investment in Australian homes, business enterprises, resorts, farms and basic resources to 45% of each purchase.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to your attention that thousands of Australians are suffering from the Federal Government's high interest rate policy and that:
1. High interest rates have pushed the cost of a home beyond the reach of many Australians.
2. Many Australians already paying off mortgages are struggling to meet payments.
3. Many Australians have been forced to extend the term of their loan which means they are going further and further into debt.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House take immediate steps to force the Hawke-Keating Government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion Funding Abolition Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Private Members Bill, the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill, is not to come to a vote in this current parliamentary session and we feel this is a breach of our democratic rights to ask our parliamentary representatives to make our views known on this important issue.
Your petitioners therefore request the House do everything in its power to have this issue come to debate and be put to a vote this parliamentary session.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Amendment Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to your attention that the Privacy Amendment Bill dealing with credit referencing reporting will
1. Prevent business from having access to the information it needs to make sensible commercial decisions.
2. Disadvantage or discourage persons entering into leasing, mortgage, tenancy or purchase or insurance transactions with people who they know nothing about.
3, Add to the costs of business, increase interest rates, insurance charges and defaults in rental payments and lead to over commitment by borrowers.
Your petitioners therefore, pray that the House do everything in its power to ensure that the Privacy Amendment Bill does not become legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Madam Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the continued Government interference in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded pharmaceutical benefits scheme which ensures the availability of pharmaceutical benefits through local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament,

We, the people of Australia, wish to draw the attention of members to the fact that proposed cuts in funding of pharmaceutical benefits will severely reduce service and availability of medicines to the public. Your petitioners, therefore, ask the House to reject these cuts and maintain our family chemist service.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present a summary of the report of the Committee on Drugs, Crime and Society entitled Rethinking Drug Policy.

SPEECH.PARA: In May this year the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority presented to the Parliament a report entitled Drugs, Crime and Society. That report dealt with the trade in illegal drugs in Australia and the strategies used by law enforcement agencies to combat that trade. It outlined the social costs of the present policy of prohibition and examined alternative ways to reduce the harm caused by the abuse of the illegal drugs.

The Committee found that there was ample evidence that the policy of prohibition was failing to achieve its objective. It was failing to prevent supplies of the illegal drugs from reaching those in Australia who wished to use them. The illegal drugs were available throughout Australia for anyone who wanted them. Prohibition simply made the price of the drugs higher than it would otherwise have been.

The Committee noted that for many years governments had attempted to use the criminal law as a means of reducing supply to the marketplace. The report clearly demonstrated that such an approach had limitations. To the extent that its stated aim was to prevent illicit drugs from reaching the marketplace it had demonstrably failed. The Committee argued that if the present policy was not working, then it was time to give serious consideration to alternative policies, however radical they might seem.

Although the present policy or prohibition gave the appearance of tough controls on the illegal drugs, in reality there was an absence of government control over the chemistry of the drugs being sold, the outlets where the drugs were sold and the persons to whom the drugs might be sold. This would not have mattered if the policy had been succeeding in its original aim: if, in other words, none of the illegal drugs were being sold or if there were even a realistic possibility of the trade being brought to a halt. This was not the case and the Committee argued that it was time to consider alternatives to the present policy.

The Committee recommended that the Federal and State governments and the community at large should give earnest consideration to the options by which governments might impose more controls on the sale and marketing of the presently illegal drugs. The Committee expressed the hope that its report would be a vehicle for public education. However it recognised that its call for a debate within the community on drug policy would be mere empty rhetoric if it did not take some more steps to facilitate that debate itself.

To that end it has had prepared this summary of its report under the title Rethinking Drug Policy which I present for the information of honourable members today. Besides presenting it in the Federal Parliament, the Committee intends to send copies of the summary to members of the State and Territory parliaments. It also intends to send a copy to each secondary school in Australia and to persons running relevant courses at tertiary institutions. The summary has been prepared in a format which will enable it to be copied for study purposes and the Committee hopes that this will occur. The Committee also hopes, of course, that by disseminating the summary it will stimulate further interest in its report.

The Committee recognised in its report that before any change was made to the present policy of prohibition there was a need for the Australian community to gain a better understanding of the properties of the prohibited drugs and of the costs imposed by the present policy. Hopefully, the information contained in this summary and in the Committee's report will assist in this process. The summary attempts to set out some of the facts about drug use. It examines the strategies adopted by law enforcement agencies in attacking the illegal drug trade and explains why the Committee believes that those agencies cannot stop the trade. The summary outlines the social costs of the present policy of prohibition including the cost of drug related crime and the threat that the acquired immune deficiency syndrome may spread through the intravenous drug using population. Finally, the summary attempts to provide a concise account of some of the alternatives to the present policy of prohibition.

Although most countries are signatories to international conventions which require them to prohibit the trade in cannabis, cocaine, heroin and the amphetamines, except for medical or scientific purposes, there are significant variations in their approaches. With accurate information it is therefore possible to make sensible comparisons between different policies based on the experience of those countries which have tried them. Unfortunately such information is not always readily available. The Committee's summary will assist in making some of this information more widely available and its report provides more detail and appropriate references.

Thus, for example, a number of countries impose the death penalty for trafficking offences but it is quite clear that this policy has proved ineffective in stamping out the drug trade in those countries. Thailand is a classic example. There is an enormous increase in drug use in that country, as there is in Malaysia, so it is clearly demonstrable that capital punishment does not relate to any prevention of drug use. The Netherlands permits the sale of limited quantities of cannabis in cafes and youth centres while retaining heavy penalties for trafficking. Cannabis use in that country is low and is diminishing.

Up until 1968 the United Kingdom allowed doctors to make available heroin and cocaine to addicts on prescription. The system broke down once addicts began to seek drugs for recreational use. Addicts were receiving massive doses for their own use and were reselling part of what they received, thus feeding a growing black market. The British Government therefore acted in 1968 to restrict the power of doctors to prescribe. Rather than providing addicts with maintenance doses of heroin the British clinics now generally only provide methadone, as in this country.

The provision of methadone is seen as one form of treatment to assist addicts to stop using heroin. It is no longer considered possible to undercut the black market for heroin by competitive prescribing. A policy of prohibition has applied to heroin, cocaine and cannabis in Australia since the 1920s. For over forty years it must have seemed that this policy was a resounding success.

The Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, signed in 1961 and ratified by Australia in 1967, was meant to set the seal on this success. Instead, it ushered in an era in which the consumption of the prohibited drugs has increased beyond the most alarmist predictions. The Committee's point is simple. If the policy is so obviously failing, it is time to consider alternatives. There is no easy solution, but the Committee hopes that by bringing down its report and providing this summary it will enable a more informed debate on drug policy to take place in the community.

There are difficulties in the debate. As Chairman of the Committee, I find that when I talk to the media, they want me to say that I support the legalisation of drugs. It is hoped that the media will start to take a more responsible attitude in the debate. One does not need to legalise drugs to find alternative means of tackling the problem. One can look at a variety of approaches, not just a total prohibition pathway. The pathway stretches from legalisation to total prohibition, with all sorts of areas in between. The debate, therefore, needs to be more accurately put by the media. It needs to be put without the use of words such as `instant highs from drug use' which, frankly, encourage young people to use drugs. The community must take a realistic view that it is no use putting people in gaol simply because they use a drug. I am a nicotine addict but I am not sent to gaol. Why then should I be sent to gaol if I were a cocaine addict? Those areas need to be openly addressed and discussed and we need to rethink our approach to the whole rotten trade. Organised crime is the only thing we have gained from the present policy. I thank the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the Committee's report on a visit by the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of the New Zealand House of Representatives, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report by printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian and New Zealand parliamentarians have participated in annual official delegations-exchanges of visits-during the past 10 years, under the so-called Fraser-Tallboys Agreement. The purpose of the delegations was general fact-finding, aimed at increasing the general knowledge of parliamentarians each side of the Tasman about a near neighbour. Last year the then New Zealand Prime Minister, Mr David Lange, held discussions with the Presiding Officers in Australia on the possibility of joint meetings between Australian and New Zealand parliamentary committees. As a result of those discussions it was decided to institute joint meetings in place of the regular exchanges of delegations, for a two-year experimental period. It was also decided that the first meetings under the new system were to be between the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade-the Committee that I have the honour of chairing-and its sister committee in New Zealand, the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of the New Zealand House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The visit which is the subject of the report that has just been tabled was to Canberra in August 1989. It was an exchange for one made by members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to New Zealand in April of this year. It thus completed the first round of visits under the two-year experiment.

As I have mentioned, the central activity under the experimental system was to be joint meetings between parliamentary committees of the New Zealand and Australian parliaments which share similar interests, responsibilities and subject matters. It was fortunate therefore that the first series of visits was between committees which, as the visit itself shows, have so many common preoccupations. We had some very lively discussions with our New Zealand colleagues which ranged across issues which are very relevant to this Parliament, to this Government and to the two committees, and which are very topical. There were issues such as the South Pacific, defence-this has been the subject of much recent discussion between Australia and New Zealand-immigration and the environment. For example, two of the recommendations which are included in the report that has just been tabled address two matters which are very important to those of us who live in this part of the world, namely, the protection of Antarctica. While New Zealand and Australia have slightly different views on the means to attain that protection, our objectives are certainly very much in accord. Another vital question, the protection of the Pacific from the depradation of drift net fishing, was discussed. Again, it is something on which we share very common views.

As a result of our meeting, the two committees involved in the first series of joint meetings agreed that the new system is a great improvement on the exchange of what might be called general delegations. It is possible that the subject matter which concerns the two committees had a great part to play in the success of the two visits. Of course, that will be a feature of future visits, given that they will also be dealing with common subject matters. The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recommended that joint meetings with its New Zealand counterpart be held on a regular basis. If this were to happen it would probably need to be in addition to the current two-year experiment of replacing general parliamentary delegations with committee exchanges.

I do not want to go too much into the substance of the issues that we discussed during our meetings because I know that colleagues in this Parliament, including the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) who is to speak next, will address those substantial issues. The discussions were valuable. They helped us see the perspective of our new New Zealand counterparts and they to see ours. In that spirit I commend to the House the report and the idea of joint meetings between Australian and New Zealand parliamentary committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse unreservedly the comments made by the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) and the stirling leadership he displayed during the recent visit of our parliamentary colleagues from New Zealand. Australia and New Zealand share a very special relationship. The Anzac tradition and heritage, originally forged on the beaches of Gallipoli, has developed and strengthened over many years. It has been reinforced by and through the close historical, cultural, social and economic ties that bind our two nations together. But even things as seemingly immutable as the friendship engendered by the spirit of Anzac can be threatened by changed and changing circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: The relationship between Australia and New Zealand has been severely tested on several occasions over the past few years. Paradoxically, in many instances, it is the same issue which once brought us closer together that are now causing problems, dissension and even divisions between us. Over a whole range of significant issues, the policies and attitudes of our governments differ, often quite markedly. Despite the several quite serious setbacks and challenges there is still a desire and determination on and from both sides of the Tasman to maintain and sustain the goodwill and understanding which has been the basis of the unique and harmonious relationship Australians and New Zealanders have always enjoyed. An indication of this determination and desire, and a practical way of developing and reinforcing the special bonds between our two countries, is the current program of meetings and discussions between members of the New Zealand parliamentary Select Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and our Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

The report tabled this morning details the outcome of the latest visit in this new parliamentary committee exchange program. During this visit the opportunity was taken to discuss a range of issues of mutual interest concentrating on matters generally relating to areas of foreign affairs, defence and trade. As is noted in the report, the discussions were frank and forthright. Despite a wide divergence of views, there were always many areas of broad agreement. At the time of this visit the long awaited decision regarding possible participation by New Zealand in the Anzac frigate project was uppermost in the minds of delegates of both countries.

We now know, of course, the outcome of the deliberations in regard to the frigate project. It is indeed encouraging to note that the New Zealand Government has agreed to purchase two of these vessels on very favourable terms to New Zealand, with an option for two more later. Contrary to the misgivings expressed by some New Zealand members at the August meeting and the previous April meeting, the Anzac frigate project is not something which will benefit only Australia. There are obvious and substantial benefits to be derived by both countries from this joint and very important venture.

Although the frigate issue is now satisfactorily resolved, the matter of the ANZUS alliance continues to cause me some concern. From Australia's point of view, this alliance with the United States of America is fundamental to our security and defence interests and to those of the Western alliance generally. The decision of the Lange Labour Government in New Zealand to close New Zealand's ports to nuclear capable and nuclear powered United States and allied warships and the consequent suspension of the tripartite operation of the ANZUS alliance has seriously undermined our security interests and diminished regional stability. We must continue to work towards the restoration of New Zealand's full support for and involvement in ANZUS. The same applies to the need for the New Zealand Government to recognise and fulfil its obligations and responsibilities in regard to the overall strategy for the defence of the South Pacific region.

Environmental matters were amongst other significant issues canvassed during this visit. Much of the discussion centred on Antarctica and the conservation of marine resources. The report notes that, whilst it was generally agreed that both countries sought a similar future for Antarctica, there was some disagreement regarding how these objectives and outcomes might be achieved. It is obvious that there is still much work to be done in regard to securing the future of this last great wilderness area. Both the Australian and New Zealand governments should continue to work towards implementing appropriate action which would result in the long term protection of the Antarctic continent.

Those who share the increasing concern in regard to the conservation of marine resources will be heartened to read in the report that both committees acknowledged the need for greater cooperation in tackling current problems confronting the fishing industry on which so many countries within the South Pacific region depend. Broad agreement was reached in regard to adopting a joint approach on drift netting-an unacceptable practice which poses enormous threats to very valuable marine resources.

Discussion also took place on various issues relating to the provision of overseas aid. Both committees agreed that there needed to be a rationalisation of aid to the South Pacific and acknowledged the necessity for a combined and cooperative approach to this matter. It was also agreed that there should be an increase in consultations and exchange of information between our two countries in regard to aid programs generally, resulting in a more coordinated, efficient and effective overall approach.

In the conclusion to this report, I would particularly draw attention to the suggestions for improving future visits, especially in regard to the more efficient use of available time. All too often valuable time is wasted on what could be described as pomp and ceremony that is largely unnecessary and unproductive.

Before concluding my remarks this morning, I take the opportunity of pointing out that in the introduction to this report two references are made to the current pilots dispute. Unfortunately the dispute is quite inaccurately and incorrectly referred to in the report as a `pilots strike'. As the vast majority of domestic pilots resigned on 24 August 1989-four days before the visit commenced-they could not possibly have been on strike at the time of the visit. Although this may be considered a minor point, I believe it is an important one, and that the inaccuracy should be noted.

This program of exchange visits has provided an excellent opportunity to strengthen the ties between Australia and New Zealand. Although we already share a very special relationship, we need to keep working at it, otherwise cracks may appear that are difficult to mend. There is no doubt that closer consultations and collaboration between our two countries in addressing problems of mutual interest and concern will be beneficial in both the immediate future and the longer term. I therefore commend to this House the recommendation of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that this exchange program has proven to be a worthwhile initiative, and should be continued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) on his excellent speech on the report on the visit by the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of the New Zealand House of Representatives. It was a speech which I would commend to those who are interested in the relationship between Australia and New Zealand. Historically, there has been a close relationship between the people of Australia and the people of New Zealand. There has also been a close relationship between the parliaments of Australia and New Zealand, so the presentation of this report by the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), provides an occasion on which to make some observations from an Australian perspective on the present relationship between our two countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Most Australians think of New Zealand in the context of the ANZUS alliance, cricket, rugby union and family connections. They think of a country rich in natural beauty and popular tourist attractions. There are some other things besides that which I am sure that the Chairman of the Joint Committee would have added had he had another chance to speak. New Zealand is also a unique enclave of Anglo-Saxons in the South West Pacific. It is interesting to examine the population mix of New Zealand. Of a total population of nearly 3.4 million the vast majority are of Anglo-Saxon origin. About 300,000 residents of New Zealand were born in the United Kingdom, 62,000 were born in Australia, 22,000 in the Netherlands, 8,500 in the United States of America and 6,000 in Ireland. Few immigrants have come from southern and eastern Europe. Of the population of New Zealand, 12.5 per cent, or 400,000, are Maoris. There are approximately 61,000 people from the Pacific islands. It is a vastly different population mix from that of Australia.

New Zealanders have a history of being brave and resourceful people. In World War I, 100,000 New Zealand soldiers served overseas and 16,000 of them lost their lives. In World War II, 57 per cent of men aged between 18 and 45 years served in the defence forces. Of these, 10,000 lost their lives. New Zealand was a defence ally under the ANZUS Treaty. New Zealand is a partner of Australia under the closer economic relations agreement. Under this agreement all trade between the two countries will gradually become free from restrictions. The work done by the previous Government and the current Government has gone a long way to improving trade between our two countries. This has resulted in bilateral trade between Australia and New Zealand increasing from $1.8 billion in 1982-83 to $3.2 billion in 1986-87.

It is in the area of defence policy that the respective views of our two countries differ sharply. For decades the defence and foreign affairs policy of Australia and New Zealand has been underpinned by the ANZUS alliance. New Zealand is no longer a member of the ANZUS alliance. Australia is now the only country in the Southern Hemisphere which has a defence treaty with the United States of America.

The decision of the United States to formally suspend its military obligations to New Zealand under the ANZUS Treaty was a consequence of the decision by the New Zealand Government to prohibit visits by nuclear ships from the United States. This decision by the New Zealand Government was wrong and, in my view, was a betrayal of New Zealand's responsibilities as a responsible and gallant member of the Western alliance.

It is also a nonsense for New Zealand to claim that it shares with Australia similar strategic concerns. This is not to deny that New Zealand has a legitimate right as an independent sovereign nation to pursue an independent foreign and defence policy. We respect that right but we fundamentally disagree with the New Zealand decision. Indeed, this was spelled out very clearly in this House by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 24 November 1987 when he said:

. . . Australia adheres firmly to our policy on welcoming ship visits by our United States ally. We accept the need for strategic deterrence. Australia will not resile from its firm support for the Western Alliance, with the corollary that the global nuclear balance can be maintained only through a credible United States nuclear deterrent. We believe that, although a nuclear balance of power is not an ideal state of affairs, it does exist and it has maintained world peace.
