We consider that a realistic policy is to recognise this while, at the same time, encouraging balanced reductions in nuclear forces which maintain the credibility of the deterrent at the lowest possible level.

We believe too that part of Australia's contribution to the Western Alliance system is to allow access to ports and airfields in Australia by the United States. We continue firmly to believe that such access is essential to the full effectiveness of the ANZUS alliance.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the reality.

—That is not only the reality, as the honourable member for Kingston has just said, but also a fact of life, a fact of foreign policy objectives and appreciation by members of the Western strategic community. In our meetings with representatives of the New Zealand Parliament it was regrettable that they were unwilling to share and accept that statement by the Prime Minister on our responsibilities as a member of the Western strategic community. Whatever other issues may have been discussed between our respective committees-whether it was the environment, trade, culture exchange, migration or the reintroduction of passports and other migration controls between our two countries-no other issue goes as much to the survival of our two nations as a shared defence responsibility. No matter how much we talk about the closer economic relations agreement between our two countries-and we are talking of just over $3 billion-Australia, because of the unilateral decision by New Zealand, is now the only country in the Southern Hemisphere that has a defence treaty with the United States of America.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the New Zealand Government on its wisdom in proceeding with the acquisition of two new Anzac frigates, the surface combatant ships. I hope that New Zealand will quickly restore its position as a responsible member of the Western strategic community. Like people in the United States, we in Australia look forward to New Zealand's return. I hope that as a consequence of this visit there will be a continuing dialogue between members of the respective foreign affairs and defence committees of the parliaments of Australia and New Zealand whereby at long last, after discussion, we share the common objectives of freedom and democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must commence by saying how much I agree with the comments made by the three previous speakers, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). I think they have described the situation very well indeed. I would like to also say that I believe that these joint parliamentary meetings between the committees of the two parliaments are extremely useful. I hope that they will continue, because they lead to better understanding, and I hope that they will continue beyond the defence and foreign affairs arena and into the areas of other parliamentary committees.

SPEECH.PARA: I went to New Zealand in April as part of the Australian House of Representatives Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade visit and took part in the historic first joint meeting of committees of the two parliaments as well as participating in the most recent visit by the New Zealand House of Representatives Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee. There is a perception among some New Zealanders that Australia, in its relations with New Zealand and its attitude to it, is paternalistic and patronising. I know as a fact that some New Zealanders do feel that. I am very sorry about that, because I think it would be wrong if that were the case. I sincerely trust that Australia-as a nation, as a parliament, as individuals-does not go about its relations with New Zealand in that paternalistic or patronising fashion. But if some New Zealanders perceive us as being that way, to a certain extent that makes it fact, makes it reality. Therefore, I think all of us, particularly those of us in this Parliament, have a responsibility to make it quite clear that New Zealand is important to Australia, that in many ways it is our closest neighbour-not just geographically-and that we have many things in common, many things which bind us together. One of the things which does bind us together, and should, is our relationship with the Pacific island states. I believe we have a special responsibility jointly to assist, again not in a paternalistic or patronising fashion but as partners, our friends in the Pacific islands.

New Zealand has a different migration situation from that of Australia. For instance, the people of the Cook Islands enjoy joint citizenship with New Zealand and can come and go as they please. Each year New Zealand also takes a quota of immigrants from two countries, one being Western Samoa and the other, perhaps surprisingly, being the Netherlands. Although New Zealand could be seen as being a Polynesian melting pot, it is significant that it does enjoy this particular responsibility and does what it can.

Like the other speakers, I must make reference to the Anzac frigates. When the Committee visited New Zealand in April I felt there was a complete misunderstanding about the basis for the acquisition of these frigates. People over there kept saying-and I think some of our people have said it too-that New Zealand was not going to buy Anzac frigates from Australia. That was never the case. It was a joint venture, a joint project. In fact, a little over two years ago the New Zealand Government and the Australian Government both signed a memorandum of understanding to develop jointly these particular vessels. New Zealand had an input into their design requirements. I think it has to be made quite clear that it is a joint project. They are the Anzac frigates, not the Australian frigates. Like other speakers, I am very pleased indeed that New Zealand has finally found its way clear to participate, perhaps not as fully as we would have liked, with the initial acquisition-note that I say `acquisition', not `purchase'-of two of the frigates, and hopefully it will take up the option for the other two.

The whole process will provide a great deal of benefit for New Zealand, not only in its defence capabilities but also in terms of about $NZ1 1/2 billion, I think it was, being spent in New Zealand on the project, which would initiate very useful, very important new high tech developments in New Zealand industry. I have no doubt that, in the long term, New Zealand's economy will benefit greatly because of the injection of new technology because of the Anzac frigates.

On the other hand, although some New Zealanders felt that we were paternalistic and patronising, some of us-and I must confess that I was one of them-felt that there was a fairly widespread feeling in New Zealand of isolationism. In speaking on the presentation of this report, I think it is only fair and right and proper that I should mention this. I found that many, but not all New Zealanders with whom I spoke-people in the Parliament, in the various government departments and ordinary individuals-gave the impression that there was this feeling of isolationism. Of course, that is to do with their non-nuclear policy and their withdrawal from the ANZUS Treaty. Like other speakers, I hope that in time they will see that there is an alternative and come back fully into the ANZUS alliance.

It is in the interests of New Zealand and Australia, and indeed the world, for New Zealand to participate fully with Australia and the United States. We have a joint obligation for the defence of the Pacific. Undoubtedly, because of the changed arrangements, we are unable to cooperate fully with New Zealand in defence, although there is an exchange of officers, training and information. However, there is a restriction which inhibits our working together fully.

An important issue which comes up in the report is that of aid to the Pacific region. I have no doubt that aid needs to be rationalised. Also there needs to be some degree of coordination of aid, not just by Australia and New Zealand. Perhaps the South Pacific Commission could focus on that. All too often the aid provided by other countries turns out to be, in effect, a white elephant. I refer to a cultural centre in Tonga built by the Japanese, which was very kind of them. The Japanese flag flies outside these massive buildings but they are empty because the buildings are totally unrelated to the needs of the people of Tonga. Because the Tongan people did not want to kick a gift horse in the teeth they said, `It is very kind of you to give us these things. Thank you very much'. That was a major aid project. I have been in the buildings. There is a bit of a museum there which is totally unrelated to the needs of that nation. That is why there must be rationalisation. We do not want to waste our aid.

I applaud the fact that New Zealand is working with us towards the protection of Antarctica, even though New Zealand is in favour of signing the present mining protocol. I reject totally the proposition that there be any mining in Antarctica. It is a part of the world which should be preserved. The mere fact that the maximum depth of ice is four kilometres and the average depth of ice is two kilometres, makes the logistics of mining rather difficult anyway. I conclude on a point about Antarctica because it is relevant to Australia and New Zealand. Antarctica is the only continent in the world where there has never been a war. It is the only continent where man has never killed another man. It is the only continent in the world where the wildlife is completely unafraid of human beings, and it is the only continent where there is complete sharing of scientific data and complete assistance.

I believe that the exchange of parliamentary committees program should continue. It is to the benefit of Australia and New Zealand. There should be a commitment by this Parliament to continuing the joint meetings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —During this 35-minute debate my Party has extolled the virtues of military alliances and belligerence. I strike a discordant note and promote peace and peaceful cooperation. I regret that I have some disagreement with my friend the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) who believes, quite sincerely, that the only way to avoid a nuclear holocaust is by maintaining nuclear deterrents and nuclear balance. However, I believe that the only way to avoid a nuclear war is by total global nuclear disarmament and by outlawing nuclear weapons. That will achieve the result that we both wish but in a different way. It will be achieved through peace and cooperation. I also want to join my colleagues in welcoming the exchange of visits between Australia and New Zealand. We have familiar bonds with our sister nation across the Tasman. Those bonds grew out of the Anzac tradition and have been maintained through peace. Peace, thank God, lasts longer than war. The wartime cooperation throughout history-I was thankful for it in the Second World War-is a short part of our history. It is much more important that we look towards increased trade, cultural exchange and even a possible administrative union with New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) spoke about the feeling of isolation in New Zealand. I do not have the feeling that New Zealand is isolationist. Of course, New Zealand is taking steps to get out of the nuclear arms race. It sees this as its only chance of survival. I welcome that and so do thousands of Australians. I remember more than six years ago when the then New Zealand Prime Minister, Mr Lange, decided to ban the visit of nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships to New Zealand ports. Thousands of people signed petitions. For years I presented petitions signed by Australians welcoming the New Zealand Prime Minister's move to try to break the nuclear cycle. They voiced a note of protest against the path, as they saw it, that the United States of America was taking.

The action by the New Zealand Government to prohibit access to its ports by United States nuclear ships has brought into focus the ANZUS Treaty. The ANZUS Treaty-and I have carefully read a couple of pages; 11 articles-does not mention any visit by any nuclear warship. It has nothing to do with it. The ANZUS Treaty came into being in 1951. The United States Administration proposed it to appease Australia's fears following the peace treaty with Japan. There are only two articles which can be said to allude to helping each other during some crisis. One is article 3, which states:
The parties will consult together whenever in the opinion of any of them the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the parties is threatened in the Pacific.

It does not say that America will come to our aid. We should remember history. During the first and second world wars the United States was somewhat tardy in coming to the aid of the rest of the English speaking world when it fought against Kaiser's Germany or Hitler's Germany. The United States took its time in making up its mind. It finally saw that its own interests were threatened.

In this discussion there has been an emphasis on military matters and military cooperation. This was also the case during the joint meetings with the New Zealanders. Unfortunately, we have mostly been discussing the frigates; and I support the frigates. But we took up too much time discussing military cooperation, the visit of nuclear warships and so on. We ran out of time before being able to touch on trade and peaceful cooperation. This is exactly what has happened in this Parliament this morning. We started off extolling the virtues of war and belligerence and when we heard a voice for peace we had run out of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for presentation of reports is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr N.A. Brown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Copyright Reform Bill 1989. This procedure allows me to introduce a private member's Bill and to make a five-minute statement in support of it. I have just introduced the Copyright Reform Bill 1989. It is described as a reform Bill because it will very substantially reform the copyright law in Australia. The Bill, in effect, will implement the recommendations of the Copyright Law Review Committee on imported books and other reproduced articles. The problem that this Bill seeks to resolve arises from the fact that over many years, as many honourable members in this House would realise, readers and booksellers have been quite infuriated by one of the undesirable consequences of the copyright law. It is not necessary for me to explain the details of the copyright law on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the results of the copyright law is that books published overseas are very often not available in Australia until months, sometimes years, after their publication. Sometimes they are never available despite the fact that they have been published overseas. Indeed, when books are eventually brought to Australia by overseas publishers for sale here the prices of these books are far in excess of any reasonable price and far in excess of the price at which they sell in the country of publication. There has been a lot of evidence to suggest that the increase in prices may be 10 per cent, 20 per cent or in some cases 30 per cent. This undesirable situation comes about as a result of the provisions of the Copyright Act, which provides that the publisher has copyright in the book and can determine when and where the book is sold.

The Copyright Law Review Committee has investigated this issue and has proposed a series of reforms to the law, which will be implemented by this Bill. Briefly, these reforms provide that overseas publications will be able to be imported and sold here if either of two circumstances arise. The first is where the books are not available here within a reasonable time from when they are available overseas. That is the first situation-the reasonable time test. The second is a more narrow one. It is where a distributor in Australia, for example, a bookseller, has a specific order for an item that a consumer wishes to import but not re-sell; in other words, wants to keep it to read it. The Copyright Law Review Committee recommended draft legislation to implement these proposals. This Bill will incorporate those changes to the Copyright Act. If the Bill becomes law, members of the Australian community will have better access not only to books but also to records and other reproduced articles published overseas. Not only will they have access to them but also they will be able to buy them at lower prices and with much earlier delivery times than are presently available.

I hope the Government will support this Bill. At the same time, I hope that the Government will respond to the recommendations of the Prices Surveillance Authority, which recommended virtually complete deregulation of the industry of the distribution of books and other reproduced articles. The recommendations of the Copyright Law Review Committee are milder than those of the Prices Surveillance Authority. There is now an onus on the Government to show any reason, if there is any, why the recommendations of the Prices Surveillance Authority should not also be implemented. That response-I can understand that the Government may need a few weeks to examine the Bill-should not be allowed to delay the Copyright Law Review Committee proposals, which I now propose in this Bill should be put into law.

It is a very healthy example of micro-economic reform. In many areas the Government has been dragging the chain on micro-economic reform, and here is a very good example. The Government should pick up the ball and run with it, accept this Bill, take it over as a government Bill and make sure that it is passed and put into law as soon as possible. Consumers will benefit; purchasers will benefit; industry and commerce and the economy will benefit. Nothing can really be said against this Bill. Therefore, I hope that in the interests of all buyers and readers of books, the Government will support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—In accordance with sessional order 104a, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, recognising the high level of public concern about foreign investment in Australia, this House:
(1) supports Federal Government restrictions on foreign purchases of Australian residential real estate;
(2) opposes the abolition of the Foreign Investment Review Board; and
(3) calls on the Government to investigate further initiatives to impose appropriate controls over foreign investment in the national interest.

This debate is about the national interest. It is about whether members of the Australian Parliament will listen to the voices of their constituents and respond with appropriate legislative and other controls to protect the national interest. This debate divides the House between those honourable members who believe that the Government has a legitimate role in protecting the national interest and ensuring that foreign investment is targeted to those areas where it truly benefits our country, and those honourable members on the other side of the House-led by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock)-who believe that government has no role in the important matter of protecting the national interest.

One aspect of the Federal Labor Government's policy on foreign investment is that it is a balanced approach. The present Government is not zealot-like in its approach to this issue. We say that, in many circumstances, foreign investment has a legitimate role to play, both as a driving force for the advancement of the Australian economy and investment in new industry as well as bringing new technology to Australia. We do not have a blinkered view of foreign investment that would seek to make Australia a fortress. However, there ought to be a balance and we ought to recognise that the community has legitimate concerns about foreign investment. That concern is not solely in any one section of the community. Many people right across this country share my concern and the concern of my constituents about excessive levels of foreign investment. Sections of the business community and the trade union movement have expressed that concern. Indeed, the national conference of the Returned Services League of Australia put on public record its concern about foreign investment and called for greater powers to be given to the Foreign Investment Review Board. The Government has acted on some aspects of those concerns. Later I will refer to a piece of legislation that was passed in this House to give effect to concern about excessive foreign investment in Australian residential real estate.

The concern of the Australian community has not been solely about residential real estate. Concerns have been expressed about excessive foreign investment in primary industry. To his great credit, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, has recognised that concern and he has put on the public record his view that we ought to be monitoring developments in the beef industry, for example, and that we ought to ensure that proposals that are referred to the Foreign Investment Review Board are referred also to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for an expression of viewpoint that will protect rural Australia.

Minister Kerin's concerns are, firstly, that, where possible, foreign investors should establish joint venture arrangements with Australian interests; secondly, that there should be provision for adequate capital injection for plant upgrading in abattoirs and meat-processing works; and, thirdly, that such proposals should open up direct lines to overseas distribution and marketing organisations. It seems to be an inherently reasonable proposition that, as a national government, we should ensure that the national interest is protected.

On the other hand, the Opposition supports a policy that abdicates the national interest. It is an open slather policy which, on the public record, leads clearly and unequivocally to the abolition of the only effective control on foreign investment in this country-namely, the Foreign Investment Review Board. I intend to speak at some length on that proposal's impact on Australia, because it is completely out of step with public opinion in this country.

I will not-and I do not believe that any of my colleagues will-be prepared to countenance a debate on foreign investment that is going to be based on race; that is going to try to whip up fears in the Australian community based on the source of investment from any one country. From the Government's point of view, this debate will never be allowed to touch on those issues. This is a debate about the national interest.

I have mentioned the Government's initiative in November of last year of introducing into the House of Representatives a law to effectively place controls over foreign investment in Australian residential real estate. That Bill contained the requirement that foreign purchasers of residential real estate were to notify the Treasurer of those proposed transactions. The Treasurer would also be given the power to stop a transaction and prevent the foreign acquisition of Australian residential real estate if it were considered not to be in the national interest.

I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, members of this House and the people of Australia: What could be more reasonable? What a heinous and horrendous proposition that the Treasurer of this country, representing the people of Australia, should actually have the power to stop foreign investments that are not in the national interest! That inherently reasonable proposition was bitterly opposed by the Opposition, which voted against it. The Opposition believes that the Treasurer should not have the power and that there should be an open slather, open door policy on foreign investment. I charge the Opposition with being totally out of step with Australian public opinion.

The policy that the Liberal and National parties have adopted-albeit by a tortuous and divided process-has been to take the view, according to their so-called Economic Action Plan, to abolish controls, except for certain strategic areas-and they only give the example of the media-and with them, the only effective mechanism of control. The Opposition proposes the abolition of the Foreign Investment Review Board because it views it as being out of step with the outward looking, entrepreneurial spirit that it talks about as its so-called rationalisation for its slavish adherence to the false goal of free market forces.

Time and time again the Leader of the Opposition has been on the public record on this issue. Earlier this year, in his capacity as shadow Treasurer, he appeared on the Sunday program and was asked by Mr Laurie Oakes:
Would a coalition government be more or less regulatory where foreign investment is concerned?
The then shadow Treasurer replied:
We would be less regulatory. I have no hesitation in saying that, and you either believe in a more deregulated society in a greater flow of funds around the world or you don't.

There has to be balance and protection of the national interest. That is why the Government rejects the call for the abolition of the Foreign Investment Review Board, and that is why foreign investment will be an election issue. The Government is glad that it will be. We are glad about that because we think we are in step with public opinion and that the Opposition has abdicated its responsibilities.

There are further dimensions to the Opposition policy on foreign investment that ought to be drawn to the House's attention. It has put out a document called Privatisation-The Australian Way. Whatever view one takes on privatisation, frankly I think that a lot of Australians are not going to be happy with proposals to sell the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, Qantas Airways Ltd or, would you believe, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation-something which I would have thought was part and parcel of the history of this great country. It is one thing to take a view in support of selling off these national assets, but it is an entirely different proposition to say, as the Opposition does, that we ought to allow foreign investment in those key sectors of the economy. It may well be that the Opposition would impose some limit on the degree of foreign investment in those key areas in the short term. We have yet to see finally what policy the Opposition will run up to the election with. It has certainly gone on the public record as being prepared to support foreign investment in those areas. I think Australians ought to be aware of that and ought to be aware, when they are casting their votes, of the significance of that policy.

I mentioned in the course of my remarks that there have been bitter divisions in the Opposition on this question, and those tensions and pressures inside the coalition will in my view inevitably burst out before the election. There are principled people in the Opposition such as the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), from South Australia. He is a former Minister of a conservative government who has been prepared to speak out in support of the retention of the Foreign Investment Review Board. He, like me, believes that the Board should have more powers, not less, and it certainly should not be abolished. But people ought to be made aware of what has been placed on the public record in the lead-up to this policy announcement and this free market forces, laissez faire, open slather approach of the Opposition. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt) was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald soon after his election as acknowledging the concerns in the community and saying there was a need to fine-tune the Opposition policy, and he has also been quoted extensively as suggesting the Foreign Investment Review Board ought not to be abolished. But the Leader of the National Party was rolled.

There have been others. Even as recently as 3 July the National Party federal conference-and I want to mention this because people ought to be aware of the betrayal by members of the National Party of their own Party organisation and their own constituency-endorsed a resolution calling on the party at the State and Federal level to show the strongest possible support for the operation of an effective Foreign Investment Review Board. That is the National Party policy, but it is not the policy of National Party members in this chamber. They are out of step. As recently as May this year that well known public figure and Liberal Party President, Mr John Elliott, went on public record as calling for a partial ban on Japanese investment in Australia. We will have no truck with that; we will not countenance racist calls of that nature. But at least Mr Elliott went on to be consistent with our view, in his interview on Channel 10, by saying that the fate of the Foreign Investment Review Board was being reconsidered. He suggested there might be a role for it in keeping out unwanted foreign money. On this occasion Mr Elliott happens to be right, but it is not the policy of his party because his party supports the abolition of the Foreign Investment Review Board.

There are other principled, concerned people in the Opposition who on this issue at least are speaking with one voice with the Government. The honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), from Western Australia, has gone on the public record himself as calling for the retention of the Foreign Investment Review Board. He presented a paper to the coalition party room which called for the retention of the Board. He, like the members of the National Party and their Leader, was rolled. We see now a policy which, as I have said, calls for the abolition of the Board. Others have gone on the public record on this issue. Queensland's Senator Sheil has called for limits on foreign investment. Earlier this year the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd) raised concerns about beef producers and the Western Australian rock lobster industry. Those industries are concerned about excessive foreign ownership. But he was rolled.

Let me turn again, in conclusion, to the honourable member for Sturt. I strongly agree with him. He takes the view that there are concerns about this in the community, that we should be aware of the effect of foreign investment and should ensure that we retain control. He took the view-and I share his view-that we need to retain the Foreign Investment Review Board, make it more effective and respond to those community concerns. This will continue to be an issue as we go to the election, and we on this side of the chamber are proud to stand defending the national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), has been reading too many newspaper reports about the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) and should more properly have addressed himself to what has been said by the coalition leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), in the last couple of weeks. We believe the FIRB has a proper role, and the coalition also accepts the need for controls in foreign investment in certain strategic areas. We believe there is a need for the Federal Treasury to have a proper monitoring role of foreign ownership in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, we do reject the xenophobic attitude some have that espouses a severe wind-down in foreign investment in Australia. We believe that the advantages of foreign investment far outweigh the disadvantages. We have to realise that there are economic costs that go with restricting foreign investment. More than ever there is a need in this country to have an outward-looking entrepreneurial spirit to get us out of the economic mess we are in. It is worth noting in that regard that we need foreign investment more than ever because of the parlous state that this country's economy is in. The low value of the Australian dollar and the high value, relatively, of the yen make it even more attractive for countries such as Japan to invest here.

We acknowledge freely that there are proper concerns about foreign investment, one of which, of course, is vertical integration such as we are seeing elements of in the beef industry and the tourist industry. In the beef industry, for example, if Japanese investors own the feedlot or the farm, the abattoir, and the marketing facilities, there is concern that access for Australian producers could be restricted. While that may be a concern, there has been as yet no evidence that this has gone anywhere near the extent suggested. Perhaps there is some inkling of it in the tourism industry, whereby if the Japanese buy resorts, own the buses, have the interpreters and run their own tourist shops, Australian people in this area could be locked out. Again I think it is overstated. Nevertheless, it needs watching and we have a Trade Practices Commission in this country which can properly deal with that.

Another area of concern is transfer pricing, where profits can be transferred offshore so that the proper amount of taxes will not be paid in Australia on any profits made. I believe that the Australian Taxation Office is now properly geared up to control this, and it is not creating a problem at all. There are other areas of concern in the Australian community which I think are more irrational. Some people believe that foreigners should own only leasehold land in Australia and not freehold, but if that restriction is imposed it will be less attractive for them to invest here. In any case, frankly, I have never been able to have explained to me what advantage there is in having leasehold land owned by foreigners rather than freehold land. I think it is more in the mind than in the substance. Others say foreigners are coming over here and buying up our heritage, but I have yet to see any proper evidence of this.

Others say that Japan is winning in Australia the war that it could not win with arms 40 or 50 years ago. I think that is an irrational approach. The success that the Japanese are having in their country today is due to their hard work. The problems that we are running into are due to our incompetence in running the economy and, to some extent, our laziness. The call for Australia for Australians has some danger in it for us. The British arrived here 200 years ago and populated a land that was already owned by Aborigines. They did it successfully because the Aborigines perhaps could have managed the land better, from a technical point of view. If the Japanese can come to Australia, invest and make profits-and do it better than us-it reflects more on us than on them.

If we look at what the Japanese own in Australia, we see that there is very little cause for concern. The ownership of abattoirs has been in the news a lot. The Japanese own or partly own only four out of 39 abattoirs in New South Wales and two out of 39 in Queensland, on the latest figures I have seen. They recently bought an abattoir at Forbes in my electorate in New South Wales. The abattoir had been closed down because we could not run it properly. We could not make profits on it. The Japanese bought the abattoir and opened it up. They have created 200 jobs in Forbes. The abattoir has been of enormous benefit to beef producers in the Forbes district. I can see only advantages from it. If the Japanese had not bought the Forbes abattoir, it would have remained closed. That would have been to the disadvantage of all of us. The Japanese own only 3.5 per cent of the total Australian cattle kill in abattoirs. Another 8.6 per cent is owned partly by Japanese and 3.8 per cent is owned by other countries, such as the United Kingdom, Singapore and West Germany.

People are getting uptight about the feedlot industry and the fact that the Japanese are creating a few feedlots. However, the Japanese are creating feedlots that did not exist before. By investing money in them, they are guaranteeing a market for Australian beef in Japan. If they did not invest in feedlots in Australia, they would invest in them in Brazil, the United States, or elsewhere. We have to bear that in mind. In Dubbo, in my electorate, the Japanese are talking about spending $20m on a feedlot for 30,000 cattle. That feedlot does not exist now. If we hunt the Japanese from that area and they go to America, we will lose the benefit of selling them 100,000 tonnes of grain each year. Something like $7m of freight will go into that feedlot each year. It would provide $400,000 in veterinary bills each year and it would create 40 to 50 jobs. In addition, the benefits for the beef farmers in the Dubbo district would be enormous.

There is concern in the Australian community that profits will be remitted overseas, but we have to remember that our current account deficit-leaving aside productivity increases-can be financed in only two ways: either we borrow more money overseas, the fixed servicing cost for which is now running in excess of $1 billion a month, or we attract investment from overseas. Money is remitted back to those countries which invest only if they make a profit. I would rather have a higher level of foreign investment and a lower level of overseas borrowing. That would be much healthier for Australia than increasing the debt, as we are doing today. We have had waves of foreign investment in the past. People have been concerned about the waves of investment that we have had from Great Britain. We have also had waves of investment from the United States. I can remember the xenophobia that pervaded this country when the Yanks were buying up northern Australia. All they did was develop those properties, employ people here, and create a level of expertise; most of them went broke and went back to America anyway. Thus, it was to our benefit more than to theirs. Today, we have Japanese investment in Australia. The Japanese are investing only 5 per cent of their overseas investment in Australia and New Zealand anyhow. A property of 50,000 acres in my electorate, `Wingadee', was sold recently to the Swire group, an English group, and it hardly made a paragraph in the Land. If the Japanese had bought it we would probably have seen pages written about the Japanese invasion.

With respect to the total accumulated foreign investment in Australia, the highest investor is the US with 24 per cent, followed by Britain with 22 per cent. The Japanese have only 13 per cent of the total foreign investment in Australia and others, such as New Zealand, Switzerland, Italy and the like make up the rest. There are enormous advantages in foreign investment. It creates jobs. Seventy per cent of the jobs in the manufacturing industry alone since World War II have been created by foreign investment in Australia. It brings in levels of skills, technology, new ideas, business expertise and the like, which enrich us. Without foreign investment, we would be a backwater.

If foreign investors make a profit, they pay taxes. They create an infrastructure in this country and develop new resources. They often end up becoming Australian citizens, to our benefit. It gives us a faster growth than we would otherwise have. They cannot take land home with them. If they buy a farm here, they cannot take it back to Japan. It has to stay in Australia; let us not forget that. It releases the capital that we have invested in these areas for investment in areas that we think would be more profitable. Most importantly, it locks us into their consumer markets. The classic case is Japanese beef, on which I have just expounded. It all means a higher standard of living for us in Australia today. At the end of the day, it means better, more friendly relations between nations.

There are some provisos. Foreign investors must pay the proper level of tax. They must play by our rules in Australia. They must operate here in open competition and they must do it without political favours or subsidies. We should ask for reciprocal opportunities in their countries. Where there have been difficulties in that area, for example, in Japan, I am pleased to see that opportunities are opening up. I see that Denmark, the United States, New Zealand and other countries are investing in Japan. We should too. People ask whether such investment should be made only through joint ventures. That is okay as long as it does not frighten them off and if the Australian capital exists to go into joint ventures with them, but that should not be an absolute condition. We must realise that today Japan is a saving nation and that Australia is a spending nation. We complement each other and we are foolish if we do not get together for our mutual advantage. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two tables that I have shown to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), which lists the levels of foreign investment in this country over the last decade.
Leave granted.
