TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. A survey by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in 1983-84 showed that only 5.9 per cent of agricultural land was subject to foreign ownership. We had a classic case in my electorate recently with the Auscott cotton project, which was US-owned. It brought to Australia the skills of irrigation engineers, agronomists, farm managers, ginning experts and the like. That project has now been sold to Australian Consolidated Press. There is a case of foreign investment in rural property returning to Australia, so I think it works both ways. Overall while there are concerns-some irrational, some proper-the advantages of foreign investment in Australia far outweigh the disadvantages and we should encourage it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) regarding foreign investment in Australia. I support not only what the honourable member for Hughes said, but also most of what the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) said, which is not often the case. The motion reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That, recognising the high level of public concern about foreign investment in Australia, this House:
(1) supports Federal Government restrictions on foreign purchases of Australian residential real estate;
(2) opposes the abolition of the Foreign Investment Review Board; and
(3) calls on the Government to investigate further initiatives to impose appropriate controls over foreign investment in the national interest.

I realise that it is difficult to talk about foreign investment in isolation from balance of payments considerations and the value of the Australian dollar. However, as a non-economist I do not propose to enter the debate by trying to discuss these complex interrelationships. Along with most people in the community, I can relate and react to such things as interest rates, changes in the price of goods and services and whether there is sufficient economic activity within the community to provide sustained employment for all Australians. I digress for a moment to say that whilst most people in the community find these high-level economic debates very confusing, the community nonetheless has become very sophisticated because people appreciate that there are no quick-fix solutions. This is something the Opposition has yet to learn. Its recent attempts to come up with alternative economic policies will not wash with Australian voters. Of course, people do not like high interest rates or wage restraint. However, they certainly have a better understanding than our colleagues opposite of the state of the economy and what needs to be done.

In order to enjoy sustained economic growth and to participate in the world economy, Australia needs access to foreign investment. This issue is certainly not in dispute. I also believe that foreign investment, both equity and debt, can enhance our productive base and help achieve a level of investment growth beyond that which could be achieved by domestic savings alone. In my own electorate of Hawker, the Mitsubishi motor company of Japan has made a long term productive investment in plant and equipment. This form of investment has added to the productive base. It has also provided jobs for people within my area, and I for one certainly support and encourage this type of productive investment, whether it be in my electorate or in any other part of Australia.

Unfortunately, there can be a down side to what is commonly referred to as the internationalisation of capital. When money is allowed to move freely from one country to another, speculative foreign investment has the potential to be disruptive and to detract from long term productive investment. It is in this regard that I wholeheartedly support the Government's initiative in September 1987 when it abolished the $600,000 cumulative exemption threshold and made it a general requirement that proposals for urban real estate acquisitions be submitted to the Foreign Investment Review Board. Whilst I acknowledge that it is difficult to prove conclusively that foreign investment in real estate contributed significantly to the spiralling house prices in 1986-87, there was a common perception amongst Australians that this was a major contributing factor. As economics is as much about perceptions as about other things, I make no apology for the Government's reimposing tighter restrictions on this aspect of foreign investment. It can be said that Australian investors may have contributed to this price spiral by borrowing from overseas to purchase real estate in Australia. This is another facet of foreign investment that I would like to see subjected to greater scrutiny.

I also think the events of last week on Australian stock exchanges, precipitated by the Friday the thirteenth Wall Street shake-out, bring home very clearly the vulnerability of our capital markets to external influences. This, too, is an area where more work needs to be done to see whether it is possible to separate out investment of a purely speculative nature which is unrelated to value-adding production. Whilst I assume that all speculative transactions are subject to the present capital gains tax, I believe further taxation imposts may need to be introduced to discourage the rapid turnover of short term foreign capital moving in and out of Australia.

The Hawke Labor Government has introduced many initiatives to assist and encourage Australian producers and manufacturers to become more actively involved in the world economy, such as the Button car plan, Austrade, and the exposure of more and more manufacturers to competition by reducing tariffs. I have no hesitation in supporting these initiatives and believe a lot has been achieved over the past 6 1/2 years. However, we have to recognise that Australia is a very small player in the world economy. I think the terminology used is `price taker' rather than `price maker'. That being the case, Australia can be exposed from time to time to quite severe disruptions and dislocations when transnational companies and investors pursuing their own interests can exert undue influence on the Australian economy.

We are not going to change to any great extent Australia's influence in the world economy, and it would be equally naive to return to the bad old days of trying to operate in a closed economy. The only practical solution, therefore, is to maintain a balanced approach to foreign investment, as my colleague the honourable member for Hughes has pointed out, and allow as much flexibility as possible. However, recognising that we are only a small player in a big game, it is necessary to retain checks and balances so as not to expose the Australian economy to too many sudden and disruptive movements in foreign investment. It is for this reason that I strongly support the retention of the Foreign Investment Review Board because I believe there is a role to be played by an organisation which is given that task.

There has been in recent years a great deal of concern within the community, as both the honourable member for Hughes and the honourable member for Parkes have pointed out, about foreign investment, particularly foreign acquisition of Australian property. Much of this concern has been based on ignorance, misunderstanding and prejudice. In particular, a great deal of hostility has been demonstrated towards Japanese investment. This hostility is found particularly amongst the older generation, who were involved in or who remember the events of World War II. Unfortunately, much of this feeling has been provoked by extreme Right racist groups with their own warped political motives. I find, however, that when I talk to people in my constituency, particularly about the difference between speculative and productive investment, they begin to take a much more reasonable view on this matter. I have great pleasure in supporting this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for this debate has expired. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue her speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House supports policies aimed at creating a fairer Australian society through reduction in the extent of inequities in the distribution of income and wealth by (a) increasing employment and reducing unemployment; (b) improvements in the social security system; (c) strengthening the progressive tax system; and (d) policies aimed at increasing competitiveness and reducing industrial concentration.

Since this motion was foreshadowed, the Opposition parties have announced an economic package, every aspect of which would make Australia a less fair society. Therefore, in this speech I will concentrate on discussing the Liberal and National parties' policies. Nobody with any compassion can vote for the Opposition parties at the next election. There is an ideological thread running through every aspect of the Liberal-National Party economic package and that is the reduction of the incomes of the vulnerable and the poor. Every part of the package is designed to reduce the security of those who are already most insecure. Every part of the package would reduce the incomes or the services of those who are most vulnerable. Every part of the package is socially divisive, increasing conflict between the haves and the have nots. This package must, therefore, be rejected by every person concerned about fairness, equity and justice in Australia.

The Peacock package is a shocking reflection on once responsible parties. It vividly demonstrates the extent to which the conservative parties have been captured by New Right Thatcherite ideology. It demonstrates also the appalling ignorance of those responsible for its preparation, for no-one who has met recently retrenched unemployed or the long term unemployed, who has seen a neglected Aboriginal settlement or who has visited an impoverished Third World city could possibly support this package. One astonishing feature of the package is that it does not do anything about Australia's economic problems. Despite analysing some of the serious problems we face, there are no new policies for addressing any of them. The stand on fiscal policy is the same as the Government's. Nothing is said about the exchange rate; comment on industrial relations and wages is limited to repetition of superficial ideological posturing; and comment on monetary policy is inconsistent, unpersuasively linking claims about the aim of reducing interest rates, with no indication about how that could be achieved. This package fails the test of economic responsibility.

There is one goal in the Liberal-National Party package which everyone could welcome and that is the aim of increasing family income. But why limit that goal to only middle and higher income families? Why choose methods that will at best leave incomes of the poorer families unchanged and at worst reduce them even further? Why not choose methods which would increase the incomes of all families when these are readily available? While one of the ends of this package is desirable, all of the means of achieving that end are misjudged, regressive and perverse. Nobody with even a shred of compassion can support the Liberal-National Party economic plan.

The major feature of this unfair package is the brutality of the attack on the unemployed. If a Liberal-National Party government were elected, everyone who had been unemployed for nine months or more would be prohibited from receiving unemployment benefit. That means that after nine months of looking for work and of being rejected, the unemployed would experience the humiliation and final rejection of being told that the unemployment benefit would no longer be received. As a special concession, and after further humiliating cross-examination, some of them would be given the concession of special benefits. Migrants would also be denied access to income support programs after their arrival. This is like using a chainsaw which has slipped and could cause severe injury. If these policies are introduced, there will be blood everywhere, not only on the victims but also on the hands of those who designed or support this policy.

Of course, there are some people who avoid working, but the Government, through the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), has been rigorously assessing and weeding out such people for two years now, and the number of people receiving unemployment benefit has fallen as a result. Unemployment benefit is not payable to people who are not actively looking for work, and that requirement is rigorously enforced. What are those who are denied unemployment benefit or special benefit to do? If they had been able to get work, they would not have been on unemployment benefit. Under the Liberal and National parties' scheme, they will have to sponge or beg or steal. A class of people in Australia would be created for the first time since the Second World War for which the community accepted no responsibility. This would not happen, of course, because non-government organisations-the welfare groups, the churches-would provide voluntary support for such people. But a Liberal-National party government would, for the first time for 50 years, refuse to provide any public income support to a substantial section of the Australian community. It is appalling to know that even a few Australians who claim to be responsible would seriously contemplate such a situation.

Not only would the Liberal-National Party package create an underclass of the absolutely deprived, but also it would abolish most of the programs designed to get the unemployed back into the work force. The package announces that Jobstart, Skillshare and the industry training support scheme would be abolished; so the very schemes which are designed to help the unemployed overcome their problems would be removed. Even the new enterprise incentive scheme, which aims to help the unemployed become self-employed, would be abolished. The plan of the Liberals is to increase incentives for the wealthy but to remove them for the poor. The new enterprise incentive scheme is an imaginative program which helps the unemployed help themselves, but even that skerrick of hope would be abolished. The abolition of these training programs would effectively imprison the unemployed in their inability to obtain work. Even support for the Commonwealth Employment Service, which finds jobs for the unemployed, would be reduced by a quarter. Such proposals are incomprehensible.

It is not even as though the coalition parties believe that their policies will increase employment opportunities. There is not one word in the package about the goal of increasing employment. Amongst the oft repeated economic goals there is not a word about employment, yet in Australia we still have half a million unemployed, which is 6 per cent of the work force. It is certainly true that the Labor Government has succeeded in reducing unemployment from over 10 per cent in 1983 when we won government to about 6 per cent now, but 6 per cent is still shockingly high. That means that half a million people who are actively looking for work cannot find it. The proof of this is that the Australian Bureau of Statistics can identify only 64,000 vacancies while over half a million people are unemployed. At present there are simply not enough jobs for everyone who wants one and is looking for one.

There is not one word in the policy about unemployment being the major cause of poverty, one of the major causes of family breakdown, and the cause of psychological disintegration, escapism and crime. There is not a word of sympathy or regret for this underclass in Australia. There is not a word about alternative policies for increasing employment or reducing unemployment. The only promises that are made are about reducing income support, reducing training programs, reducing support for self-help, and reducing support for the Commonwealth Employment Service, which finds places for people in new jobs. The introduction of such policies would make Australia a cruel and brutal society. Anyone with any compassion must totally reject the economic plan of the Liberal and National parties.
Other aspects of the Opposition's expenditure proposals also attack the vulnerable. Funding for invalid pensioners would be reduced by $150m a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—Sickness beneficiaries would have their illness reviewed not only by their own doctors but also by the Commonwealth Medical Officer. I thank the Minister for Employment and Education Services, who is at the table, for that comment.
—Kicking the cripples.

—That is right, kicking the cripples. To have one's illness reviewed in that way is not only inefficient but also humiliating. The Opposition's tertiary fees would make university entrance much more difficult for low and middle income earners. The Aborigines-the most systematically dispossessed section of the Australian community-would have their support reduced by $100m a year. The puzzle about Aboriginal deaths in custody-for which, I regret to say, Australia is known throughout the Western world-would not be resolved for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody would be wound up.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's support for the absolutely impoverished in Third World countries in our region would be even further reduced. Australia is already contributing in overseas development assistance only 0.33 per cent of our national income-a third less than the average of all Western countries, which is 0.5 per cent-yet we live in a region in which millions of people live in absolute poverty. Our shared humanity with these people at least requires that we make a contribution to enabling them to help themselves. Yet this package of the Liberal and National parties cavalierly slashes a further $100m from the aid vote. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission would be abolished, removing a check against discrimination against women, migrants, Aborigines and the disabled. Payments to the States would be massively cut, reducing their capacity to maintain adequate health, education and other services-further discriminating against the already impoverished. Anybody with any compassion must completely reject the coalition's economic package.

Even the taxation measures which these cuts in outlays are designed to support are inequitable. Increasing income support for families is obviously desirable, but it is equally obvious that it should be done in ways which ensure that the benefit goes to the children of low income people as well as to those of middle and high income people. The package chooses to make a tax rebate which will be received only by those whose incomes are high enough to pay tax, so excluding those who do not receive a taxable income. Yet the means for an equitable support for families is readily available through the family allowance scheme, which in fact was introduced by a Liberal government. That means has been rejected in favour of a new scheme which gives the benefit only to middle and higher income people. This is proposed by the same parties which criticised the family allowance scheme for applying to high income families. The hypocrisy would be unbelievable if it were not actually in front of our eyes. Anybody with any compassion must reject that means of providing family support.

The most regressive measure in an entirely regressive package is the proposal to abolish capital gains tax. Capital gains tax is a necessary part of a fair taxation system because it ensures that income received in the form of capital gains is taxed, as is every other form of income. The benefit of abolition of capital gains tax would be received by those who earn much of their income through capital gains-that is, the wealthy. Abolition of the capital gains tax would simply transfer to the already better off a further $450m.

It is a mystery why the Liberal and National parties have stuck with this part of their frequently changed past policies but have rejected their previous proposals to withdraw or change all sorts of other parts of the tax system. For example, in the middle of the year the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) travelled the country saying that he would increase the tax incentive to save. There is nothing in this package which increases the tax incentive to save. The only impact it will have on saving is to reduce income from the poor, who cannot save, and give it to the wealthy, who can.

The cartoonist Tandberg made the definitive comment on the package of the Liberal and National parties. He published a cartoon in which he portrays the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as promising that no child will live in poverty while the Leader of Opposition offers the promise that no rich child will live in poverty. That captures the essence of this package. The more compassionate members of the Opposition must be appalled by what their leaders have decided to do. It is quite clear that there was opposition by at least some of the Opposition front bench to at least parts of this package. Many members of the Opposition are humane people, but nobody with real humanity could possibly accept that this package is the way to help middle Australia.

If this package were introduced, Australia would become a divided, unjust society, like Thatcherite Britain. It would amount to a total rejection of any responsibility for mutual support. It would amount to rejection of those parts of our culture which are based on the Christian principle of loving our neighbour. Anybody with any compassion must totally reject the Liberal and National Party economic plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a predictable line of drivel from the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) which was no doubt set up by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) because this Government realises that the economic package put out by the Liberal and National parties is right. It is good for Australian families, the aged and taxpayers. It has support in the electorate. That is why Government members-these expired volcanoes-trot out set piece speeches using the words `compassion', `economics', `wrong' and `brutal'.
—Don't you believe in it?

—Yes, we believe in compassion. We believe that one of the best ways to be compassionate is to have an economy that works and this economy does not work under the Labor Government. I will come to that subject because the previous address, and no doubt the one to follow, is predicated on the assumption that the Government has got it right. But this Government has got just about every major economic decision wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to outline the recent history of the Government's more enduring achievements. The September current account deficit figure of $1.8 billion is truly appalling. It gives us an annual rate of deficit on the current account, the measure by which we are going broke, of $24 billion a year-about 6 per cent of our gross national product. Incidentally, it is even more than the horrendous figure of $18.5 billion which was forecast in the Budget Papers. So once again it looks as if the Treasurer's figures are wrong. The volume of imports for the September quarter-another achievement of this Government after seven years in power-grew at an annual rate of about 18 per cent. We have all heard the Treasurer speak on the subject of exports. He tells us how well the Government is doing and how it is on track. He tells us how industries are gearing up. But what has happened? The volume of exports is increasing at the rate of 10 per cent. What is the differential? I would think even the Labor Party could work it out. It is 8 per cent. That is what the Labor Government is doing to this country after seven years in power. We are going down the drain at a time when interest rates have reached near unsustainable levels.

The inflation figure that has just been released is another triumph for this Government. What is the level that inflation is running at? It is 2.3 per cent for the quarter and 8 per cent for the year. That is more than twice the average rate of inflation of our main Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development partners-our main partners in the advanced industrial world. That is another significant achievement of the Hawke-Keating Government.

There is also the pilots strike. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was going to fix the pilots strike. But remember what he did. Did he say, `Look fellows, this strike could be devastating for this country. Let's all sit down around the table and ask ourselves what is fair for the country, the airlines and the pilots'? Did he do that? Did this industrial peacemaker use the strength and authority of his office to do that and reach a conclusion within a couple of weeks? No, he did not. Instead, he went right over the top because he believed that, at a time when every economic indicator was going against the Government, this issue would provide him with a quick political win and perhaps would give him the window of opportunity to bolt for an early election. He has missed that window of opportunity and he has prolonged the dispute by weeks, possibly by months.

Let us look at some more enduring achievements of this Government-the long term achievements in which it can take pride. Australia's overseas debt has quadrupled in the time that Labor has been in office. It has increased by more than four times the previous figure. It is now a net figure of $108 billion plus. This is the junking of Australia. Our volume of exports is stagnant and is falling behind those of the rest of the world. Similarly, our quality of life is falling behind that of the rest of the world and our per capital income is sliding. Another great achievement of this Government was alluded to by Professor Helen Hughes, the chairman of the Government's own committee for the review of export market development assistance. Productivity growth has been negligible since 1985, and we know what a unique wages policy this Government has. It is entrenched in this Government's mentality as it looks steadily back towards the nineteenth century. It does not seem to have occurred to any of the geniuses that litter the front bench of the Government that after 80 years it is just possible that it is time to change the wages policy.

What does Standard and Poor's say about this? The downgrading of Australia's credit rating by Standard and Poor's, joining the downgrading by Moody's Investors Service, should be added to the recent achievements of this Government. Standard and Poor's had this to say about this Government's industrial wage fixing system:
. . . the centralised award system still contains appreciable rigidities that have restrained productivity improvements.
Is it any wonder that our productivity gains in the last three or four years have been negligible?

Another enduring achievement of this Government is the level of interest rates. Interest rates for home loans are at 17 per cent and interest rates on ordinary bank loans are at 21.5 to 22.5 per cent. There is no relief in sight. Also, on the most recent figures inflation is stuck at 8 per cent.

The Opposition takes great pride in the policy that it has put out. This policy has been attacked by the Government because it knows that it will be destroyed by that policy. The Government has run out of options and has become a government of quick political fixes. In the case of Kakadu National Park, it stops the prospect of mining there because it wants to buy the green vote. In the case of Eastman-Kodak Pty Ltd, it says, `Let's shovel $50m or $60m in their direction'. On the airline dispute or on any other issue, this Government has a bandaid mentality. It is attacking our policy because it is the right policy for the Australian people, and it has been judged to be the right policy. It is the right policy for families, for children and for all income earners.

I will finish my remarks by making two points. One concerns the attack made by the Treasurer on Standard and Poor's. We should recall what the Treasurer has been saying. He said, `Don't take any notice of Moody's, wait for Standard and Poor's'. But when Standard and Poor's came out and junked the Government and Australia's credit rating, the Treasurer said, `Well, I suppose they would have to do that to stay in line with Moody's'. The philosophy of the right wing of the Labor Party is, `If you see a head, kick it. If somebody does something, find a reason which shows that action to be dishonourable'. It never says, `We disagree with Standard and Poor's but we accept the integrity of Standard and Poor's'. The Treasurer is saying that `Standard and Poor's lacks professionalism, integrity and honesty and is simply falling in line with Moody's'.

The final point relates to something that was said by the last speaker, the honourable member for Fraser. He spoke about a cartoon by Tandberg. I recall another cartoon by Tandberg. Somebody is coming in to pay interest rates to a bank. On the desk are his hands, and the bank manager says, `Well, that will do for a start'. That is what this Government has done to this country. It is going out, and it knows it is going out, because the policies of the Liberal and National parties are right for the country, the people, the future and our development as a great country rather than the stagnant society brought about by seven years of misrule by these people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) had been on the front bench, from which he has recently been removed, I think he, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), would have formed the three riders of the apocalypse. This trio has given a mishmash of representation of the Opposition's policies which have been presented by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) over the last week or so. The honourable member for North Sydney gave a definition of `compassion'. If I got down my notes correctly it was to bash the unemployed; to have a policy which will bring about increasing numbers of unemployed. He said that it was compassionate to pull the crutches from underneath the invalid pensioners and that it was right to put another barrier in front of students who wished to enter higher education. He said that it was compassionate to deny access to child-care for the children of pensioner families, low income families and families of the handicapped, and women who opt to stay at home. Then this means contempt for migrants who are setting up a new life in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess that, as a lawyer, he has learnt over time that one does poorly when one has a bad brief. These sentiments are unAustralian. If we asked any average Australian in the community what he wanted out of Australian society-what he wanted the members of the various parliaments in this country to achieve-he would say, `Maintain a fair Australia'. In this country people have come to expect a fair go. Yet all we heard from those opposite was in direct contrast to that. They said that if one is rich one should get richer and if one is doing well one should be better off.

Let us have a look at some of the statistics-some of the facts-about how our society distributes its wealth and its income. Recently I visited a school to debate with an Opposition member of this chamber whom I will not name because he is not present here and I have not warned him. When we were discussing the Opposition's policies he made a peculiar statement that fits very well with what was said by the honourable member for North Sydney-that there was no poverty in this country. `Look around you', he said to the students, `There is no poverty whatsoever'. I said to the students, `Hasn't he heard of the Smith Family, the work of the Brotherhood of St Laurence and the studies of the Australian Institute of Family Studies? Doesn't he know the research and the work done by the Social Welfare Research Centre? Doesn't he talk to people? They will tell you that there is poverty in this country and that the way to roll back that poverty and have a more egalitarian society will be to continue the policies that have been put forward by the Hawke Government and this will take more time'. But, like the honourable member for North Sydney, that Opposition member of parliament said that there is no poverty.

We have a very unfair distribution of income and wealth in this country. The top one per cent owns 25 per cent of private wealth in this country; the top 10 per cent owns 60 per cent of the private wealth. The remaining 90 per cent has to do with 40 per cent of private wealth. We must maintain a strong public sector with strong government business enterprise. We must put a stop to any thought of privatisation if that 90 per cent is to have any share of the public wealth of this country and not have it distributed in a concentrated way to that top 10 per cent of private wealth owners.

If we look at income distribution 70 per cent is from wages and salaries, 14 per cent from the self-employed and 5 per cent from property, with 11 per cent of our population receiving income from superannuation and pensions. When we work out after tax net family income the top 20 per cent gets 41 per cent of income, the top 40 per cent gets two-thirds of income and the bottom 40 per cent gets a miserly 17 per cent of income. The bottom 20 per cent, the very poor in our society, has to do with 5 1/2 per cent of the income distribution in this country.

We have a very unequal society. When we look at the changes that have taken place, the money from the so-called squeeze on the low and middle income earners, more income is not going to the poor. The best that this Government has been able to do is maintain the line against deterioration of the situation of the poor in this country. It is very difficult to make advances unless we have a greater acceptance of a more progressive taxation system. But here we have filching of the income, a stealing of the wealth of the middle class to give to the upper class-the upper wealthy people, the richer people. Let us not be wrong about this. Let us be quite clear. The squeezing of income of the middle and low income earners in this country has not gone to the poor, the unemployed, the elderly, the handicapped or the students; it has gone to those who are already in a more powerful position in our society. The Opposition's policy will increase that direction of maldistribution-in other words, make this country even more unequal. The Opposition has attempted to go out and find a scapegoat in society to get its election bribe across to the middle income earners. It has found an emotional scapegoat. In effect, it says, `If you find someone who is down and out, kick him hard'-instead of equitably redistributing income in this country.

When the Australian Labor Party came to office 2.8 million Australians were living in poverty; unemployment was 10.3 per cent; child-care was not an accepted thing and was extremely hard to get; secondary school students left too early and so were jeopardising their futures as regards getting a good and secure job and a good income. Tax rorts were rife. When people went to a party or social gathering the talk was about how one cheated the Australian Taxation Office-how good one was at ripping off the public sector and making it hard for others, the pay as you earn taxpayers who had to support the whole system. Pensioners found that they faced a declining and less certain future. We were getting two classes of retiree-those on well padded superannuation packages from the private and public sector and those who were meant to make do with the declining real purchasing power of a public pension.

The Government has put in place its social justice strategy. It is not just a simple one-liner meant to attract votes out in the community or the dangling of a carrot of a few dollars but a solid integrated package overarching all the different programs of Government to bring them together in a cohesive and progressive policy. The Government's social justice policy is about making a fair go for all in redressing inequities in Australian society. The strategy is based on the Government's firm belief-and I think all Australians hold this-that all Australians are entitled to genuine equality of treatment and opportunity in all spheres of community life, including equal access to and an equitable share of the nation's resources. In contrast to the distorted understanding of compassion put by the honourable member for North Sydney, a socially just society to us is one in which the economic resources are distributed fairly, individual rights are protected and enhanced, fair access to essential community services is assured and all have the opportunity to participate in the life of the community.

Over a series of Budgets we have put together-clearly documented now as a Budget Paper-a program which integrates economic policy with social policy. We have put together progressively a wide range of programs that are making Australia a fairer, more compassionate society that provides better life chances for all Australians. We now see 1 1/2 million more people at work. We see fewer unemployed. We see a fairer society emerging. The choice that is starkly facing us is whether we take the definition of compassion as outlined by the honourable member for North Sydney and turn the clock back or make further progress. I predict that when the people have their chance, they will demonstrate that they want more of this Government and reject the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for this debate has expired. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House queries the benefits of multiculturalism to Australian society.

In moving that motion I want it to be quite clear that `multiculturalism' is one of the debased words of our society, because it has so many definitions. When I say this, I am talking about those aspects of multiculturalism which tend to create division within our society, which tend to cause segregation, apartheid, separation of peoples and even ghettos. This is totally wrong. The practice of multiculturalism in Australia, as set on the new directions by the coalition's policies, will be of great benefit to Australia. This country has already benefited mightily from migration. I do not think anybody in this country can dispute that Australian culture has grown and diversified and been enriched by migration. Australia owes its origins to people who have come from many nations, each making a contribution to the development and fashioning of the Australian identity which marks us out as being different from any other country. Successive waves of immigration have changed the Australian identity over the years. This process will continue.

Terms and concepts such as `multicultural' and `multiculturalism' do provoke a great deal of debate. They mean different things to different people. To many they are words of reassurance, but to others they have, over time, connoted division rather than unity. We really are bound together by common Australian values and traditions to which all have contributed and in which all should feel an equal degree of pride. These values and traditions include a generous acknowledg- ment and understanding of the desire of Australians born overseas to preserve a continuing affinity with and affection for the cultural heritage of their birthplace.

I am sure I can speak for the whole of the coalition when I say that it is our goal to ensure that all Australians, no matter what their racial or cultural background, can be truly confident that they have an equal and valued role in developing the modern Australian nation. I certainly endorse the objectives of a cohesive society within which people are free to express their own identities. I support equal opportunity for all to participate fully in Australian society and in local and national affairs, as well as the encouragement of a commitment by all to the national well-being. All newcomers want and should have open access to avenues of success and satisfying acceptance in the constantly changing Australian society. Pluralism must not lead to a perpetuation of distinction between new and old, them and us. There must be no first-class and second-class citizens. Equality of opportunity is achieved when people of different backgrounds are able to participate in Australian society on the same basis. We in the coalition believe that our citizens and residents should live in an environment which allows everyone to achieve his own maximum potential.

When we come to government at the next election, we of course will continue to encourage respect for Australia's cultural diversity, acknowledging that we are a people drawn from many parts of the world. Our pride, a pride which I share, in the history, culture and language of our diverse origins is a legitimate expression of self-esteem. The sharing of our heritages will enrich our nation and strengthen our sense of unity.

It is important that we should be aware of what the present Labor Government did when it completely reversed what it was doing in terms of multiculturalism, because it is freely acknowledged, apart from those who are fanatical about it, that in recent years the Labor Government had been pushing divisive policies, had been pushing policies of segregation and separate development. But when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) launched the national agenda for a multicultural Australia in July, he adopted a great deal of Liberal-National Party policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—My friend opposite laughs. He should compare the two documents. The coalition's policy was released many, many months before that of the Government. We are pleased that the Government has backed away from the form of multiculturalism which the honourable member has been espousing personally for some time and which is anti-Australian. I agree with the Prime Minister that the three dimensions of Australia's multicultural policy should be cultural identity-the right of all Australians, within carefully defined limits, to express and share their individual cultural heritage, including their language and religion-social justice, being the right of all Australians to equality of treatment and opportunity and the removal of barriers of race, ethnicity, culture, religion, language, gender or place of birth; and economic efficiency, involving the need to maintain, develop and utilise effectively the skills and talents of all Australians. The Prime Minister's statement was an embodiment of the coalition's policy.
—Rubbish! What a joke.
—It is in black and white. Is the honourable member saying that his own Prime Minister is talking rubbish? The honourable member ought to wake up to himself.
—You are talking rubbish, comrade.
—What?
—Order! Will the honourable member continue and ignore the interjections.

—I certainly will ignore these ridiculous interruptions. Labor's definition of multiculturalism unashamedly uses words almost exactly the same as those contained in our policy. In order to provide the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), with some time to contribute as well, I must finish. This country has to go forward and provide equal opportunity for all Australians, whatever their background, whatever their origin, so that they can enjoy life here and so that their children can grow and develop and certainly enjoy the enrichment of the Australian culture, which is enhanced by cultures from many other lands.

SPEECH.PARA: I personally have a total commitment to the teaching of English to migrants. This has to be the basis of successful settlement in Australia. As a parliament, we should do much more in the teaching of English.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion, Mr Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —From listening to the speech of the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), one would be somewhat surprised to realise what his actual motion was. The motion was:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House queries the benefits of multiculturalism to Australian society.

In his speech, the honourable member appeared to be saying that multiculturalism was all right provided that it was defined in certain ways and that it followed certain principles. Then he tried to tell us that those principles were taken from the Liberal Party's platform. Obviously the honourable member must be a bit confused, because the concept of multiculturalism and the principles to which he referred have been around for about 15 years, ever since they were first propounded by the Whitlam Government, then adopted by the Fraser Government and then adopted by the Hawke Government. In fact, the only time there was any debate on multiculturalism was during the unfortunate period last year when the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was Leader of the Opposition and he decided to try to initiate a debate in which he attacked multiculturalism on similar lines to those on which the honourable member for Cowper has attacked it. He tried to attack it on the basis of some ridiculous claim that multiculturalism is divisive in Australian society.

I make it quite clear that we welcome the return to a bipartisan approach on multiculturalism since the change in leadership of the Opposition. We welcome especially the position of the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). We want to continue this cooperation.

Motions such as this one from the honourable member for Cowper do no good at all to the sustenance and support of that bipartisan position. In fact, they give credence to those few elements in Australian society who are opposed to multiculturalism for the wrong reasons and who want to promote a divisive approach. It is not multiculturalism which is divisive in Australia; it is the opponents of multiculturalism who have been using an argument against multiculturalism and trying to divide Australia. There are extremist elements who are obviously blatantly racist in their rejection not merely of certain cultures but of virtually every culture of the world except the very narrowly defined culture which they choose to interpret as Australian. In fact, Australian culture is a much broader and richer concept than any of these individuals can imagine. Many of them live in the past and imagine that Australia is something like it was 70 years ago, when cultural development would have been much narrower than it is now. The fact is that Australia has been enormously enriched by immigration and by the contribution of waves of migration and their cultures.

Multiculturalism is not divisive; it is a unifying force. It says that every Australian should be able to contribute to the cultural development of Australia through drawing on the cultural heritage from which he or she comes. The cultural heritage might be Anglo-Saxon, it might be European, it might be Asian, it might be Latin American, it might be that of one of the Pacific Ocean countries. All of those cultures have come together in Australia and are contributing to the evolution of the Australian culture of the future. Anyone, unless he walks about with his eyes closed, can see that Australia is much enriched by this development and by the fact that internationally we are recognised for the important contribution which multicultural philosophy has made to social development. When I have been to Europe and the United States of America there has been enormous interest in our multicultural policy, in the way in which we have harmoniously brought together different cultural streams. In contrast to many other countries, we have brought the various cultural streams together in such a way that they have made a positive contribution to the development of our nation. This multicultural philosophy is certainly the philosophy of the future. It is the way in which we will move ahead as a society that gives a fair go to all to participate through their cultural contribution.

I do not know what the honourable member has to object to in the general philosophy of multiculturalism. He put this motion down saying that he queried the benefits of multiculturalism, but he put down no argument at all. What argument did he present? He presented some vague arguments, similar to those put forward by opponents of multiculturalism such as Professor Blainey, about multiculturalism creating ghettos and separation and all those problems. Anyone who contrasts Australia with any other developed country that has a number of cultures will see that we have the opposite. We do not have ghettos; we have people mixing. Originally, people might come together in one geographical place for their first five or 10 years in Australia, but what do they do after that? They all spread out. Where is the Greek community, the Italian community, the Spanish community, all the different communities? They are everywhere; they are spread around. We do not have ghettos. What are these people talking about? They are simply trying to raise conflicts which do not exist, and we are better off that they do not exist.
