DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Abortion-Brisbane City Council: Environment Policy-Wheat Industry-Economic Action Plan-Youth Suicide-Queensland Election-Gold Coast College of Advanced Education-Age Pension News

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some in the Western world today who believe that Liberal democracies have been so successful in nurturing freedom and pluralism that there no longer exists a common philosophical foundation or a common morality upon which we can debate social issues or develop law and social policy. It seems to me from my discussions with colleagues on both sides in this place over the last few years that such a pessimistic assessment about our capacity for rational conversation on moral issues is unwarranted. In rising to speak today on the issue of abortion, I intend to put a number of questions to my colleagues and to the Parliament in an endeavour to discover just what principles and values we do share in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Many honourable members will have seen comments by a Western Australian academic recently warning his fellow Australians that the growing demand for foetal tissue for cell transplants could see the development of a commercial pregnancy and abortion process whereby poor women are paid to fall pregnant or be artificially inseminated and then have an abortion to make foetal tissue available to doctors. Many honourable members will be aware of debate here and overseas about whether it is time to make use of anencephalic babies by maintaining them on life support systems to provide organ transplants or spare parts for other persons. Many honourable members will recall evidence last year that Australia, as with other civilised countries, is now seeing gender-determined abortions. That is, it is now common for women to abort a baby once the sex of that child has been determined.

I ask these questions of my colleagues: In a country where we fund and legitimate over 60,000 abortions each year, in a community where the dominant assumption is that it is not immoral or wrong to abort by poisoning and dismemberment, why would it be wrong for a woman to fall pregnant and abort for money? Why would it be wrong to set up anencephalic spare parts units? If there is nothing wrong with abortion, what does it matter that the reason for an abortion is that the woman does not want another girl? Is this Parliament capable of discussing and judging these moral questions?

I put a more basic matter to my colleagues: Tens of thousand of citizens are insisting that abortion involves the termination of an individual's life, constitutes murder and involves the question of two sets of rights-those of the mother and those of the unborn person. In this place on 17 August I put the view that scientific, philosophical and moral logic support the view that an individual's antenatal and postnatal development constitutes a single process of becoming what she or he already is-an individual person. I referred honourable members to the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation, which found against marker events in the development of an embryo and argued for the status and rights of an embryo. Members of this place, as law-makers, are being asked to form and state their own view on this matter. Do honourable members believe that an embryo or foetus is a human person some of the time or any of the time whilst in the womb? If only some of the time, for the purposes of law-making, what is their suggested marker event and how can it be justified in a non-arbitrary way?

I now ask a different question. Have those members of parliament who so freely dismiss abortion as a minor procedure ever studied or seen what happens to a foetus when it is destroyed in the abortion process? During the International Year of Peace, in order to provoke debate and consciousness, films and glossy coffee-table books went into graphic detail in describing a nuclear blast. Next week, the library will show three videos on abortion, which are both rational and graphic. How many members of parliament have the courage to inform themselves about what actually happens to a foetus when it is poisoned or cut to pieces in the unnatural and cruel process that is so calmly described in the community as a simple medical procedure? Are members of parliament willing to give abortion the consideration that it is due? Can they resist what I claim are the unavoidable and obligatory moral questions that confront those of us here who are responsible each year for funding tens of thousands of abortions?

I turn now to the political questions. Regretfully, yesterday, the Government indicated that its schedule is too full to allow a debate and a vote on the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill. The Government's position reflects the contempt with which it treats all those Australians, both pro-abortion and anti-abortion, who believe that the Parliament should make its position clear on this issue. Its position reflects also the contempt with which it treats the Parliament, which, according to it, has no right to determine legislative priority or to amend the schedule of business.

The questions that I ask my colleagues on both sides of the House are these: Will they continue to accept the way in which Parliament and back bench members of parliament are denied their rights to initiate debate and law? Do they believe that they have the right to keep from their constituents and their voters a clear picture of where they stand on abortion, and abortion funding in particular? Having allocated time on such crucial Bills as the goat fibre levy Bills that were before the House this week, do they accept that the issues of whether one person should be forced to pay for another person's abortion decision and whether abortion and its funding is out of control are not worthy of a position on the legislative schedule of this session of this Parliament?

I ask my parliamentary colleagues to reflect on all of those questions. However, I leave till last what will undoubtedly be the most important question for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Bob Hogg: In staving off debate and a vote on the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1989, will they be happier with a vote on the Bill or a de facto abortion vote on whether to discuss the Bill just before the next election in 1990? I ask all of those members of parliament whose first consideration when dealing with the abortion issue is not the substance of the issue but how they can manage it in their electorates: Will they be happy with the Government if it succeeds in preventing debate on the Bill in 1989 and it becomes a problem on the floor of this House early next year, which will ensure that it becomes an election issue?

Honourable members are failing the community and themselves in their refusal to consider, discuss and vote on the abortion issue and abortion funding. I call on the Parliament to ensure that time is allocated for a proper debate and vote. I leave to the Government the decision whether there will be some kind of vote on the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill this year or in the shadow of the 1990 election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of a number of citizens in Forde and, in particular, on behalf of those residents in the Centenary suburbs whose calls have been totally disregarded in relation to having any control over the area in which they live. We hear much about the Opposition's policy on the environment, but I intend to discuss the implementation of such a policy and the way that it impacts on many people. In Brisbane, Liberal Party policy on the environment is determined by the Brisbane City Council.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been said about the Year of the River. In fact, the Lord Mayor's environmental council has been established to ensure that environmental matters are taken into account. However, no less than five groups within an area of five kilometres who wish to have some say about their own environment and the way in which they choose to live and who wish to create an environment for their children to live in have been denied any input to that famous environmental council or to the Year of the River. Indeed, those people have been treated in a very high-handed way and extremely rudely.

The first group is the Jindalee Action Group, which is endeavouring to maintain public parks and recreational facilities within its local area. The matter came to a head with the building of a girl guides hut. Well may one say that we certainly support the girl guides, the kind of work that they do in the community and the way in which they develop independence and confidence in many young girls. However, their needs and the necessity for parking and recreational facilities in the area must be balanced. A most extraordinary situation has developed in which one of the local commercial enterprises has taken over the girl guides hut and has promised them the use of a park along the river which is currently owned by the Brisbane City Council. That area of land is not towards one end or the other of that recreational park but is right in the middle, which will deny access to a whole range of people. Over a period the Brisbane City Council has allowed that park to be impinged upon by builders. As a result, the area that was originally set aside for recreational purposes has been reduced by one-third or almost one-half.

The action group is not asking that the girl guides not be given a home but that they be listened to and that parks, recreational and public facilities within their area be maintained. The group went to a great deal of trouble. It consulted some very educated town planners, architects, engineers and others who suggested a range of suitable alternative sites. One night, in true Queensland style, a special meeting of the City Council was held and approval for the building of the girl guides hut was raced through. Consequently, that hut will stand in the centre of that recreational area despite the fact that probably four or five other areas would be suitable to both the girl guides and the residents.

That is yet another example of the Opposition's high-handed attitude and its policy on the environment. Anybody who opposed that stance and suggested alternative sites for the girl guides' hut was abused and called a child hater. Over 2,000 people who attended a public meeting were called child haters, which is quite an extraordinary and high-handed statement to make about people who are trying to maintain parks for all children in the area and for all people.

I turn now to another group of people who live a couple of kilometres from the recreational area and who have also had to deal with the high-handed attitude of the Brisbane City Council and the impact of its environmental policy. The Queensland Cement and Lime Co. Ltd which, as honourable members would know, is not famous for its environmental stance, has sold off its buffer zone land to L. J. Hooker, which is trying to make people believe that it is not going to build light industry there but that it is going to keep the land as a buffer zone.

Clearly, to the residents of that area and to those of us in the real world, it is obvious that L. J. Hooker is not in the business of buying land to maintain it for trees, birds and so on. That would be an extraordinary and ludicrous belief. Although the minutes of council meetings reveal that the land has been rezoned for light industrial purposes, we have been told that we have all got it wrong and that the fact it is in black and white in the minutes is simply a little bit of grandstanding by people who happen to oppose the local Liberal Party alderman and that it would be quite extraordinary to believe otherwise. Those 1,000 people are seeking to maintain some control over their lives, over their environment and over the way in which they and their children would like to live.

When one talks about environmental policy and conservation, one talks not only about the great wonders of the world such as the rainforests, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, Kakadu and the wilderness of Tasmania but also about the day-to-day events of all individuals in the community who are trying to determine the kind of environment that they want for themselves, for their backyards, for their recreation and for their children. All of this amazes those people who see land being rezoned at council meetings in the middle of the night, who see extraordinary events happening and who are told that they are child haters and are misguided because they happen to believe what they see printed in city council minutes.

Another kilometre down the road we have a bicentennial project, which was funded by the Australian Bicentennial Authority-the cleaning up of a creek and the establishment of a beautiful barbecue area. As it is at the back of a school many children go there. It is a very pleasant area. We now find that that, too, is to be rezoned for heavy industry, for factories. So, behind a primary school of 400 to 500 students, we are now to have large trucks and heavy industry in an area in which the council last year saw fit to apply to the Federal Government for funding to create a public recreational park. When 400 or 500 people gathered together to ask questions about this matter, no representative of the council turned up. They approached the Lord Mayor's environment council: `Oh,' she said, `We haven't time to discuss any of this'. Indeed, where does one go? It is suggested that people are making it up; that they are grandstanding? But the signs have gone up. Teachers, parents and children at the school are, of course, equally horrified by the fact that a quiet little street and a large park area, which is literally at the back of their school, should be used in such a way.

I also point out that members of another group, a boating group, who actually meet on the river, find that their riverbank is to be mined. Their little sailing club where they have met for a very long time is, in fact, quite historic since John Oxley and various other people sailed up that part of the river. They see daily evidence of the riverbanks being eroded, but they, too, can find no voice here. I simply ask that in this, the Year of the River, the environment council and the Opposition's stand on the environment, these people be heard. What is the response to these groups? Can all these people be wrong? Is it wrong for them all to want to maintain the parks next to them and over the road? One of the reasons why many of them bought their houses was so that their children could play in these parks and live in a pleasant environment. Is it wrong for the school community not to want huge trucks and factories behind the school ground? Are they wrong to be worried that their children may well be run over or affected by fumes? Instead of this they expected a nice little nature walk and a barbecue area. Is it wrong for the sailing club people to suggest that the best possible maintenance of the Brisbane River in an environmentally sound way is, in fact, better for everybody in the longer term?

Indeed, one has to ask what the Opposition is doing. Why is it treating people in this high-handed manner? These are ordinary citizens who have every right to ask that their views be listened to, that the kind of lifestyle which they want for themselves and their children be taken into account. They should not be treated in this very high-handed and offhand manner. This approach is all too often part of the way in which people are treated by members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to highlight a couple of rapidly escalating problems confronting Australian wheat growers and, by extension, the nation at large, given the importance of wheat exports in relation to the balancing of the nation's books-or, I should say, attempts to balance the nation's books. These problems are, firstly, the failure of this year's wheat crop across large areas of eastern Australia, and, secondly, the impact of interest rates and the economic environment in which we live on wheat growers and their capacity to keep producing.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me begin by making the point that we are in a time of crisis in relation to our foreign debt levels. Australia now has a foreign debt that has increased by more than 500 per cent since this Government came to office. The debt stands at close to $140 billion and has doubled since 1985. The implications for the future of all Australians are both immense and frightening. Already 63c in every export dollar is required to service that debt. In that there is an assumption that we have the commodities to export in the first place and also that they are worth reasonable amounts of money.

A major stumble in either area could well see Australia simply unable to service its debts in the future. That is a frightening prospect and one which we, perhaps rather arrogantly, never thought would happen to us in the lucky country. But it may well happen to us and, of course, yesterday we had the Standard and Poor Corporation reassessing our economic performance because it is plainly concerned that we are getting in too deeply, as well it might be concerned.

Last financial year we had our worst ever balance of payments deficit of $17.4 billion. The Budget projection of $18.5 billion for this year is already beginning to look hopelessly optimistic. The $3.88 billion current account position for the first three months of 1988-89 contrasts with a figure of $6.1 billion for the first three months of this year. The implications for a possible massive overrun on the already very high figure of $18.5 billion projected are very worrying indeed.

Some months ago the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) made the point to this Government that it was being overly optimistic in its projections for wool exports this year. We know now that he was correct in that forecast. In addition, we have to add to that several worrying developments: the live sheep dispute is one; the pilots dispute is another. What will that add? Perhaps $1 billion or $2 billion-possibly even $3 billion-to our trade deficit for this year. Now we face a further development: this year's wheat crop will be way down on our earlier expectations. That is worrying enough, but I want to suggest that even worse is the prospect that next year's crop will be very low indeed. Many of our wheat growers are so badly knocked around that, given the high interest rates and continually rising input costs faced by the farming sector, they may very well not line up to sow a big crop next year. In other words, it will not be just farmers who will suffer, it will be Australia.

It is not unusual for farmers to face tough times. Crop failures are not rare; droughts are not rare; and floods are not rare. But certain factors have combined to make the going extraordinarily tough for Australian wheat farmers. For one thing, last year's crop was not particularly good and growers needed this year to boost their position. For another, we have had a series of years of low commodity prices which have weakened the position of the strongest farmers, driven many others into deep debt, and, of course, as we know only too well, driven others off their farms altogether. Given that most farmers are philosophical about seasonal conditions and even commodity prices-they will always talk about next year and the prospects for turning the corner in the next season-worse is the fact that the economic environment in which they have to operate is so unbelievably hostile. To be fair to the Government, as I have said in this place before, it has sought to do what it can in the area of international commodity prices by seeking to reform international trade and it deserves-and has-the gratitude of farmers for its efforts in that department.

But let us look at the rest of the scene. Our inflation rate has for years been higher than that of our competitors and, as today's figures reveal, they remain so. The cost of farm inputs has continued to soar way and above the inflation rate figures that we see published for the rest of the community. I am reliably informed by one competent farmer in our area, who would have done his mathematics correctly, that his costs have risen by 14 per cent over the last 12 months. That is far worse than the sort of inflationary figures that the rest of the community has had to put up with. We are slugging the most efficient and, coincidentally, the most vulnerable sector of our economy the hardest. That is a great deal less than sensible.

Reform on the waterfront and in transport lags hopelessly. The efficiencies available for the taking identified by so many different investigations over recent years have simply not eventuated. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has provided some revised figures on farm profitability for the last five years. It indicates that it underestimated by more than $5 billion farm costs in that period. On the other hand, it overestimated farm income by $4 billion in the same period. The overall decline in the terms of trade of Australian farmers in recent years has been sustained and serious.

To turn again to the plight of farmers, it is true that crop failures do happen. It is also common for a good year to follow a poor one. For example, in 1982 the horrendous drought that had Australia in its grips saw wheat production in New South Wales fall below two million tonnes. But in 1983-84 it shot back to top eight million tonnes; a dramatic improvement in anybody's language. Farmers took advantage of strong country-that is to say, country that was well rested by not having produced much the year before amongst other things-and a good season to plant as much wheat as possible. They reaped the benefits and so did Australia. Now, obviously enough, there is a need for a repetition of that pattern next year in Australia. Farmers will need the cash flow and so will the nation. But in the context of the economic environment in which farmers find themselves, there may well be no repetition of 1983-84.

We are continually told in this place that tight monetary policy and attendant massive interest rates are necessary to balance the nation's books. But here is the ultimate irony: the very mechanism used by this Government in its vain attempts to balance the nation's books threatens the capacity of our exporters to produce and export-in other words, to make their contribution to righting our trade imbalance. No better example exists of the counterproductive nature of present interest rate policies than this one. Quite simply, many farmers will not front up next year for carry-on finance; they will not be able to front up for carry-on finance to plant next year's crop. Many will leave the industry. There is precious little prospect of a great surge of export dollars resulting from wheat sowing and stripping next year as there was in 1984 and which did so much to right our economic situation in the early days of this Government. It was indeed a lucky government.

It is not as if farmers are confronted by interest rates of a mere 17 per cent. No; for the most productive sector of an otherwise often very unproductive society, a very unproductive Australian economy, the rates range from anywhere around 19 per cent right through to a horrifying 27 per cent. That is the highest figure I have yet heard but there are farmers out there struggling with a burden of interest rate levels of 27 per cent.

Especially galling to Australia's efficient wheat producers is a justification given by the Government for the handout to Kodak. That justification in large part was that Kodak earns $250m per year in exports for Australia. Many times that figure is available for the taking if Australian farmers are given an environment in which they can expand their production. It is time that we heard the cries of our primary producers. We will continue to ignore them at the cost, not just of social injustice and human suffering on the part of farm owners and their families and the communities that they service and live and operate in, but also of continuing our national slide into international indebtedness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to refer to today is the Northern Territory Government's attitude towards the Opposition's action plan which has been released with such fanfare and has been the cause of such contention and debate within this House. That plan is, of course, as honourable members are well aware, a recipe for economic disruption and social chaos. The plan has as its base the politics of division; the pitting of Australian against Australian. It is a plan that mirrors the number crunching calculations, the pencil and eraser of the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) and the misplaced public service drop-out who masquerades as the shadow finance spokesman. It has no policy basis. It is not even understood by the Opposition front bench, and we have seen that in the last couple of days in terms of the child-care policy. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has already had to admonish two shadow Ministers for their failure to understand aspects of the policy which affect the areas for which they supposedly will be responsible if there is any change of government.

SPEECH.PARA: If this policy were ever implemented it would have a devastating effect on the Northern Territory. It surprised me somewhat when reading the Northern Territory Sunday newspaper, the Sunday Territorian, of 22 October, that the Northern Territory Chief Minister should heap praise upon this document. He said, in part:
Support for responsible families and taxpayers is a bottom line of this policy.

I would like to direct my attention to that statement, that support for responsible families and taxpayers is a bottom line of the policy. That is a cause of some concern because what this policy does is alienate a large section of the Australian population from the benefits of the Australian economy. What it does, quite clearly, is attack those people who are presently on welfare in this country, who may, through no fault of their own, be in positions where they are reliant upon the public purse.

It is clear that the statements by the Northern Territory Chief Minister, supporting the coalition's economic statement, show a complete lack of leadership and support for Territorians. The Chief Minister's uncritical acceptance of the coalition's economic package makes it crystal clear that the Northern Territory Government no longer has the capacity to stand up for its own constituents. The coalition's policy totally ignores the needs of rural and remote Australians.

Under Labor, programs have been initiated which specifically target the needs of people living in remote areas, to ensure that they have effective and equal access to government services and funding. A large measure of that is a result of the country task force of which the previous chairman was the present Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons), who is at the table. The Chief Minister, Mr Perron, in his headlong rush to tie himself to the apron strings of John Elliott and the Leader of the Opposition, has fallen hook, line and sinker for a set of policies which would devastate rural Australia. Gone are the programs set up under Labor, such as the rural education access program and the rural women's access grants scheme, which have been of real benefit to people living in remote areas, not least to those living in the Northern Territory. It is these kinds of services that the Northern Territory Chief Minister is saying he wants to see thrown on the scrap heap.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Countrylink?

—That is right, Country-link as well. Not content with supporting the abolition of programs which have been specifically designed for people in rural and remote areas, the Northern Territory Government has also thrown its support behind cuts of $100m to Aboriginal affairs, which will have an enormous social and economic impact on the Territory. The Chief Minister's public statements have totally ignored the real ramifications of these cuts. Surely, even the Chief Minister can understand that by supporting the coalition's attempt to vandalise some of the most effective and innovative programs which have been designed to provide Aboriginal people with the education and skills necessary to move away from welfare dependency, he is condemning thousands of the Territory's population to abject poverty without the potential means to even lead a life of self-sufficiency. That would be the result if this policy were ever unfortunately implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: As for Territorians on long term unemployment benefit, the Chief Minister appears to be totally ignorant of the fact that there are some 2,810 people currently registered in the Northern Territory who have been unemployed for longer than 12 months. Under Labor these people have access to specially designed programs to get them back into the work force. Going for the cheap but catchy `dole bludgers' line, the Northern Territory Chief Minister, while pretending to support families, is prepared to throw these Territorians on the scrap heap. When one takes away all the hype about caring for families and punishing bludgers, one finds that the coalition's policy reveals a callous disregard for those in real need and a total contempt for the special needs of remote Australia. In fact, it is an attempt to shore up the bludgers in the community, those people at the top end of the income scale. As I mentioned the other night in this place, the President of the Liberal Party has had his salary package increased by some 81 per cent to over $1.55m. How can that be justified? He is the sort of person who will benefit from the coalition's proposal to remove the capital gains tax. He will accrue direct benefits as a result of that, further to that enormous salary increase. It is no wonder that members of the Opposition are silent when it comes to admonishing the pilots for the outrageous 30 per cent demand which they have made because they are lining their own pockets through their administration. They see that the executives of this country are not prepared to take the sort of medicine that the rest of the Australian community is prepared to accept.

The other matter to which I would particularly like to refer in relation to this policy is the cuts to Aboriginal affairs. I have just left the launch of this Government's Aboriginal affairs policy by the Minister for Education, Employment and Training (Mr Dawkins). He has informed us that during the course of this Labor Government there has been an increase of 28 per cent in the number of Aboriginal people enrolled at school, an increase of 126 per cent in school retention rates for Aboriginal people around Australia and an increase of 205 per cent in tertiary education enrolments.

What does the Opposition propose to do to Aboriginal employment, education and training if it is elected, God forbid, to govern this country? The Opposition proposes to cut Aboriginal employment, education and training funding by $23m. What that will mean, in conjunction with the other cuts it proposes, is that Aboriginal people in my electorate, who are the recipients and the beneficiaries of this expenditure by way of programs targeted to meet their special needs and get them off the welfare train, will be relying on the welfare train for the rest of their lives. That is the net effect of this policy. Its impact upon the Northern Territory community is one that has been totally ignored by the Northern Territory Government. It is so prepared to accept the legitimacy of the arguments being put forward by those opposite, that it could tolerate $100m worth of cuts to Aboriginal affairs expenditure and also similar cuts in the area of employment, education and training, which would have a devastating impact upon its own community.

It is worth pointing out that a study this year pointed out that the Aboriginal economy was worth 30 per cent or thereabouts of the total Centralian economy. A large part of that is a result of expenditure made by this Government, either in terms of general grants through the Northern Territory Government or specific program grants by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs or the Department of Employment, Education and Training. In 1988-89 the Northern Territory Government and community benefited by $44m from expenditure by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. What we are seeing is support for a process which would undermine that expenditure, which would undermine the capital improvements which are being made in schools in Aboriginal communities throughout the Northern Territory, one of which was opened this very week by the Northern Territory Minister for Education. That school was the recipient of $1.7m worth of Commonwealth funding.

These are the people who want to lead the Australian community. These are the people whom the Northern Territory Chief Minister supports as being the alternative government of this country. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, how anyone with any rational, objective approach to the good of the Australian community, could support the policies which are being advocated by the Opposition, and supported by the Northern Territory Chief Minister and the Northern Territory Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak about a national tragedy-that of youth suicide. This issue gains some publicity in April every year when the Australian Bureau of Statistics releases its statistics on causes of death. The issue gets two or three articles in the newspapers and then is promptly forgotten for the next 12 months. Yet it is an issue of great importance because suicide is the second largest killer of 15- to 24-year-old men in this country. As such, it is a tragedy for Australia, as well as being a very personal tragedy felt by the families of those children and young people who commit suicide.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an important issue because in the past 30 years the number of young people taking their own lives has increased 300 per cent. In the past five years it has increased nearly 40 per cent. What do those figures mean? They mean that this year we can expect about 380 teenagers to kill themselves. That is more than one young Australian every day. That is really just the tip of the iceberg, because for every successful suicide there are at least 100 unsuccessful or parasuicides. That is a conservative estimate. That means that in this country, this year, we can expect 40,000 young people to attempt to take their own life.

Why is it happening? Why is there this enormous increase? Certainly it is a phenomenon that is occurring all around the world, although some people writing about it have suggested that Australia's increase has been more dramatic than that overseas. Many people have ideas about this. A Sydney psychologist, John Howard, has gone on record as saying:

It seems that an increasing number of young people feel so empty and powerless that they are seeking some form of oblivion, escape, tension-release, recognition or validation of their existence through acts which are antisocial, violent or self destructive.
Richard Eckersley, who works for CSIRO and has written extensively on the predicament of youth in this country, put it this way:
Accelerating cultural, economic and technological changes have led to more family breakdowns and conflict, poverty, youth homelessness, unemployment and educational pressure.
He went on to say:
We have created a level of tension and anxiety and a level of instability that has existed on very few occasions this century.
That theme is echoed by most people who write on the subject-high unemployment, lack of opportunity, family break-up, uncertainty about the future, drugs, alcohol, alienation from society.

What can be done? The most important thing in this area is to realise that there is a very important relationship between the people who attempt suicide and the people who are successful. Half of all those people who are actually successful at suicide have attempted it before, and have been documented as doing so. To follow that up, one per cent of people who attempt suicide will subsequently succeed. That is, one per cent of teenagers who have an unsuccessful suicide attempt will succeed in suiciding in the coming 12 months. So what can be done? There are a number of areas where we really could make a significant difference. Youth telephone counselling services are fragmented and not well organised around the country; there is no attempt whatsoever to identify depressive disorders in schoolchildren, and hospital casualty outpatients generally have exceedingly poor counselling and follow up. I worked at one of Melbourne's busiest casualty departments for 12 months. I was admitting officer and in charge of casualty at one stage. I remember the frustration of admitting young people who had attempted to kill themselves. On occasions I had to certify people, as I had no other option to ensure that they would survive the night.

There is very little understanding of this problem by medical professionals, by paediatricians, psychologists and social workers, and there has been really no attempt to raise the awareness of this issue among the people who actually deal with it. There is the phenomenon of copy-cat suicides. In a school community or a group where one person commits suicide, in the following four to six weeks it is well documented that those other kids in the group are at much greater risk themselves. Yet we have no post-intervention process to prevent that happening.

At the outset I concede that this problem is largely one that falls within an area of State responsibility. However, it is of national concern and, as such, it does warrant a national response. We have a totally fragmented, piecemeal approach. The one person in this place whom I believe can hold his head high is my colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), who has been pursuing this issue for two years, privately as well as publicly, in an attempt to get something done. He has met with no response whatsoever. On writing to the Minister for Youth Affairs in 1987, who at that stage was the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), there was the promise that something was in the pipeline. He said, `We do not want to give this any publicity'. That was reasonable, but that was two years ago. On attempting to take it up again with the present Minister responsible for this area, the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), he did not even get a response to his letter and that was over a year ago. I have been unable to find any mention of a recognition of the problem by the present Minister. All I found was a statement in December 1988 that the Government was reviewing youth policies and he would have something to say by the end of February-two months later. I can forgive him for the fact that it took eight months to get anything to happen.

What came out of this year's Budget was totally inadequate. We have a response of $28.7m which, if one takes out existing programs that are already funded, means $27.2m-including a one-off $10m payment for homelessness. In real terms that will decrease by 28 per cent over four years. Let me put that in some sort of context: if we compare that $27m with what one department, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, underspent on its youth programs last year we find that the underspending on youth training and employment was $135m. Yet in an attempt to solve this problem we are giving back a paltry $28m.

One of the things that the Government makes much of is the youth homeless allowance. I have seen this at work in my electorate. I have seen how difficult it is to get. I have seen a 16-year-old girl, who was being sexually abused by her father with the willing cooperation of her mother, knocked back for the homeless allowance because her parents would not sign a written statement as to why she could not live at home. That is the sort of ridiculous approach that we have. Other areas of assistance for youth are highlighted in the current year's Budget Paper for youth, sport and recreation, where grants to States, local government, community groups and individuals to improve and build sporting and recreational facilities for young people are projected to fall in real terms by more than 20 per cent in the next three years.

This whole approach is indicative of a system that seems more concerned with putting out glossy brochures, with having lunch with advertising executives or with trying to increase expectations to such a high point that they cannot be met. Raising expectations is so dangerous because when they are not met it just increases the alienation that is felt by young people.

I am really concerned that we have very little understanding of this problem. Not to be alarmed by the increasing suicide rate of young people and not to make it a high priority for action is to ignore one of the biggest problems facing our young people. It is time we put some store into protecting Australia's future by making a genuine attempt to protect Australia's vulnerable children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Queensland State election on 2 December is being billed as the `great three cornered contest' in which each of the political parties in that State claims that it can win government in its own right. Of course, the Australian Labor Party can win government and the National Party obviously also can win government. The Liberal Party of Australia, unfortunately-and I accept that it is unfortunate-is the major victim of the Queensland electoral system and yet it continues to come out with a facade of rhetoric that it is able to win government in its own right. The reality of the situation as it now stands in Queensland is that there can be only one of two results from the election on 2 December-that is, a Labor Party government or a National Party majority conservative government in the State of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: This is denied by the Liberal Party-indeed, it is denied with great fanfare. The leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland, Mr Innes, comes out with great statements that the Liberal Party will refuse to serve in a coalition government unless it is the senior partner and that it is going for government in its own right. Unfortunately there is nothing particularly new in these claims because before the 1986 State election the then Liberal Party leader was Sir William Knox and, oddly enough, on 26 October 1986, in the week leading up to the State election, we had Sir William declaring, `I will be the State's next Premier'. That was splashed across the Courier-Mail and he was quoted as saying:

There has been a dramatic change over the past couple of days and the situation now is that I will be leading the largest party in the Parliament . . . Former National Party supporters are coming over to the Liberals in droves.

That statement is somewhat similar to the statements made by Terry White when he was the Liberal Party leader in 1983. It was even a little bit familiar when Sir Llew Edwards was the Liberal Party leader in the election prior to that. The fact is that at each State election the Liberal Party makes these outlandish claims that somehow it will magically overcome the gerrymander and become the major conservative political force in the State of Queensland. Any view of the figures over a series of elections shows that through the 1960s and 1970s the Liberal Party consistently outpolled the National Party in Queensland, but it never came any- where near winning more seats than the National Party.

The current situation is also clearly demonstrated by every opinion poll researching the political mood in Queensland. The most recent one was the Sunday Mail-Channel 9 poll which was published in the Sunday Mail on 15 October. That poll revealed that State-wide, the Labor Party's support was 50 per cent; the Nationals, 18 per cent; and the Liberals, 26 per cent. Again, even though the Liberal Party is clearly ahead of the National Party in terms of its overall support across the State of Queensland, the reality is that it is impossible for the Liberal Party to win more seats than the National Party. The only remote possibility of that happening is if the Labor Party wins government and wins it so convincingly that it takes a lot of seats off the National Party. In that sort of scenario it is feasible, although unlikely, that the Liberal Party could possibly end up with more seats than the National Party.

That sort of result in the State election is not only referred to in that particular poll; it is also confirmed in the polling of the political parties-by Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd for the Labor Party and by the Kenning Organisation for the Liberal Party. The latter's research document was leaked to the media a few weeks ago. I will not go through that document, except to refer to its conclusion, that the present 52 to 48 two-party preferred split in Labor's favour compares favourably with 42 to 58 at the 1986 election. Labor has a very good chance of winning. That is also confirmed by the Morgan and McNair polls. The position is also neatly summarised by Queensland academics, including Professor Peter Coldrake, of the Queensland University of Technology. Professor Coldrake points out quite correctly that it is almost impossible for the Liberals to win in their own right or to be a senior partner in the coalition. Yet it is strange that at each election the Liberal Party has repeated these claims that it can make it in its own right. The reason it does that is that it suffers in the public's perception when it is understood that the Liberal Party is no real alternative; that the alternative is between a Sparkes-dominated National Party conservative government, propped by the Liberals, or a Laborgovernment. Those are the two alternatives which the people of Queensland have to decide upon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong.

—I notice that the honourable member for Groom objects to that, but in the final analysis there is not a great deal of difference between the Liberal Party and the National Party in Queensland. In fact, after the drubbing in 1986, the then leader of the Liberal Party said, `The Liberal Party and the National Party should amalgamate'. That was Sir William Knox's answer to the difficulties. He added, `I believe it is a legitimate objective which some time ought to happen'-that is, an amalgamation of the Liberal Party and the National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course that will not happen. But it does not really need to happen because in Queensland, Liberals and Nationals are like interchangeable players. It is like a team event in which one can be a Liberal one day and a National the next day. Let us just go through some of the candidates who will be contesting the forthcoming State election. No doubt there will be another flurry of nominations as we get nearer the date. But this is the situation as it stands at the moment. Let us start alphabetically. Brian Austin: we all know about Brian Austin and his running mate Don Lane, and what happened in 1983. Both were former Liberal Party Ministers who became National Party Ministers. We have Yvonne Chapman, the National Party Minister who started her career in local government as a Liberal Party councillor. In fact, she was simultaneously a member of the Liberal Party and the National Party.

In the seat of Barambah, which was Joh Bjelke-Petersen's old seat, the endorsed Liberal Party candidate against Trevor Perrett is in fact a former National Party member. In the seat of Ashgrove, Alan Sherlock went through the waiting and guessing game before the last election before finally deciding to plug for the Liberal Party's camp. In the seat of Fairfax, contesting the Federal election against John Stone, will be another former member of the National Party, Alex Somalay. In the seat of Aspley, the National Party's sitting member is Mrs Beryce Nelson. Mrs Nelson was a Liberal Party member who was defeated by the National Party in 1983. She came back and beat the National Party bloke who beat her in the 1986 preselection. In the seat of Cooroora, where the National Party member is retiring, the Liberal Party candidate is a Mr Allen Low, who is the former president of the National Party in the area. In the seat of Maryborough, the sitting member is Mr Gilbert Alison, who was recently promoted to the National Party Ministry. He was formerly a Liberal member. His opponent was his former National Party campaign director who is now standing for the Liberal Party.

In the seat of Warwick, which is held for the National Party by Des Booth, a Mr Peter Beattie is seeking selection for the Liberal Party. This Mr Beattie is not the one who is more well known in Queensland; he used to be the National Party president in that area. In the seat of Albert, the Liberal Party candidate is Kay Elsen. She was the National Party candidate in the seat of Woodridge in the last State election. Standing against Brian Austin in the seat of Nicklin is Councillor Bob King, who is now the Liberal Party candidate for the seat of Nicklin. He, of course, was the well-known National Party spokesman in that seat prior to getting preselection for the Liberal Party. Sir William Knox did not need to get amalgamation between the Liberal Party and the National Party. One does not have to get official amalgamation in Queensland; it occurs automatically. Party members just swap. They put their fingers to the wind, decide which way the wind is blowing in Queensland for the conservatives, then they pick their mark. If they think the National Party is doing a bit poorly, then they go over to the Liberal Party. If they think the Liberal Party is going down the drain-as it has in the last two elections-that is no problem, they just swap. They do a Nelson, an Austin, a Lane, an Alison. There is no trouble involved.

Yet the Liberal Party has the gall to say that it is an alternative. It says, `Vote for us, we are different from the National Party'. How different is it, when half its candidates are former Nationals, and half the Nationals are former Liberals? It is a joke. No wonder the people of Queensland will reject this spineless Liberal Party and will come to the conclusion that they either have the National Party again, and all that means, or they have a Labor Party government led by Wayne Goss. Those are the alternatives in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) would like to hear an explanation and a very interesting defence of the subject of changing parties, I suggest he read some of the speeches of a very distinguished former Australian Labor Party (ALP) Minister, Senator Wheeldon, and see what he had to say about changing from the Liberal Party to the Labor Party. This was a subject that was raised on a number of occasions in the Senate and, I dare say, there are others who might have read Senator Wheeldon's speeches and be using them right now. It is really ironic for a Queensland Labor member to talk about realignments when the Queensland public has become dizzy over the past 30 years following the course of the Australian Workers Union (AWU) in and out of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland. The fact that it is in at the moment is undoubtedly one of the reasons that the Labor Party's stocks are up a bit. The position is very shaky. The AWU gets in, then it argues with the ALP, which chucks the union out again. The ALP knows that it has no chance of winning an election without the AWU, but if the honourable member really wants to watch musical chairs, he should watch that situation. It has happened so many times that one would go cross-eyed trying to keep up with it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party is not going to win the next Queensland election because it is gutless. No matter how good Mr Goss might be looking at the moment-and I certainly have no personal axe to grind with him-I would like to ask him what he is doing about the Labor Party and its effect on Queensland. There has been some publicity in the last few days about the fact that Mr Goss has told the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to stay out of Queensland during the election; he does not want the show pony up there. He can use any justification he likes, but we all know why: the Hawke Government is totally on the nose, particularly in Queensland. It has never been very popular there but the honourable member for Fisher would have to be the first to be shaking in his boots at the thought of what will happen to the Labor Party in the next Federal election. Of course, there are two reasons why the Prime Minister must stay out of Queensland during the State election. One is that his Government is hopeless and the other is the way his Government has treated Queensland, which is one of the subjects that I am going to talk about today. Mr Goss really ought to do something about the Hawke Government. He has been Queensland Labor Leader for a while now; he has told the Prime Minister to stay out of Queensland. He is a few months overdue in telling the Prime Minister to do something about the way the Hawke Government's policies are affecting Queensland.

I rise today to speak on just one such topic-this Government's treatment of the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education and its funding. The subject of amalgamations of tertiary institutions has been debated here on a number of occasions and it is within that context that I speak today. The Gold Coast College of Advanced Education was one of the last to indicate that it would be entering into an amalgamation arrangement and therefore its funding was not included in a document that was tabled and debated in this House during the last parliamentary session. That document contained supplementary funding decisions on higher education for the 1989-91 triennium. However, by the time the document was debated the decision to amalgamate had actually been taken. I made some comments on that subject in the debate on the document.

The document tells us about amalgamation and funding decisions and the amalgamation decisions in relation to Queensland are outlined on pages 11 and 12. On pages 31 and 32 the funding decisions that flowed from this are outlined. In that document the tables were given of capital funding over the next triennium for all tertiary institutions. I want to refer quickly to a couple of those and just contrast them with the treatment of the Gold Coast CAE. As I intend to refer in some detail to these tables, which I have shown to the Minister at the table, I seek to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Campuses from the Brisbane College of Advanced Education-three of them, Carseldine, Kedron Park and Kelvin Grove-are to be retained as a separate teaching institution. The funding table will show that Carseldine had funds released for projects in 1990 and Kelvin Grove for projects in 1991. Darling Downs and Capricornia Institutes of Advanced Education are to become university colleges, formally sponsored by the University of Queensland. The document shows that funding for the Capricornia University College of Central Queensland for capital projects starting in 1989 and 1991 has been approved. The Queensland Conservatorium of Music is to become a member of the unified national system by merging with the University of Queensland. The document shows that funding for 1991 and 1992 was therefore approved. Queensland Agricultural College (QAC) will amalgamate with the University of Queensland. The table shows that Queensland Agricultural College therefore had capital funds approved for 1990. The table shows that the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education, which needed funds for 1989 and subsequent years because it was in a phase of growth, having been only recently established, was subject to review. That was because at the time of drawing up the document the amalgamation agreement had not been reached.

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth Government funding of nearly $8m for stage two of the Gold Coast CAE capital building program has been frozen since May of this year as a result of the requirement by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) that the college amalgamate with another institution of higher education in order to become a member of the unified national system. In July 1989 the college council gave a clear undertaking to Mr Dawkins that it had entered a process of discussions and negotiations whereby it would become an affiliated university college of a major university in Brisbane, similar to the QAC and the other colleges to which I have referred. It also indicated that discussions were taking place with the University of Queensland and Griffith University.

In August the Gold Coast CAE council resolved that it would enter a phase of detailed and exclusive negotiations with the College of Griffith University and at that time advised the Senate of the University of Queensland that it did not wish to proceed. Since that time detailed discussions with Griffith University have proceeded in a very positive and affirmative manner and both councils are proceeding as quickly as possible to finalise a memorandum of agreement. All of this information was conveyed to the Minister and letters were also sent to him by the Queensland Minister for Education, Youth and Sport, the Chairman of the Gold Coast CAE Council and the Vice-Chancellor of Griffith University, confirming the state of these exclusive negotiations and seeking release of Commonwealth funds to stage 2 of the college's capital building program. Honourable members should remember that I am referring to a building program that is supposed to be under way for next year.
However, a response dated 23 August 1989 from the Department of Employment, Education and Training stated:

I am encouraged to learn that the College is engaged in discussions with Brisbane universities and that a firm agreement is not far off. The Department is not, however, in a position to release further funds to the project until arrangements for the College to become part of the unified national system are formalised in Heads of Agreement documentation.

The Gold Coast College of Advanced Education is the only tertiary institution in Australia that has had that condition put on it. The Minister's action in withholding capital funds, given the clear intentions of both institutions, is unwarranted and punitive and discriminates against the college.

If the Labor Party wants to win some votes in Queensland in the State election it should do something about that. We are not talking about silvertails, we are talking about the most rapidly growing area of Australia-an area with a population of a quarter of a million, projected to reach half a million by the year 2000 or shortly thereafter. We are not talking about wealthy people, we are talking about people who have been denied tertiary education for years, because they did not have a local institution and could not afford to take themselves off to Brisbane. One of the remarkable aspects of the Gold Coast CAE is the number of part time students, particularly women, who have enrolled in it-students who qualified years ago and were accepted by other tertiary institutions, but who could not afford to attend them. They are now undertaking tertiary education because the facility is there. Those who might have looked to that facility in the future will have that prospect denied by the Minister's action.

The Minister talks much in this place about the equity in the Government's programs, but the Minister is treating the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education in a particularly punitive way. In addition this condition has made it very difficult indeed for the college to enter into detailed negotiations with Griffith University. Far from giving a level playing field, it has put the college in a very particular position, quite different from that of any other tertiary institution in Australia, much less the rest of Queensland. I have sought information on this subject from the Minister; I have put questions on notice and I look forward to the reply. I note that my questions have not in any way been acknowledged so far. But the Labor Party will ignore this issue at its peril, because this institution serves not only the Gold Coast, but also areas such as Logan City, Beenleigh-Mr Goss's own electorate-and places in between the Gold Coast and Brisbane. It has introduced courses which are not available from other institutions within quite some distance.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I think that the Government needs to pay urgent attention to this matter. It is now out of the question for the college to embark on its capital program for 1989 and the program for 1990 is now also jeopardised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes I have I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate the Government and particularly the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on the second edition of the Age Pension News which is in the process of being posted out to several hundred thousand age and service pensioners in Australia, both full and part pensioners. This is actually the second edition and, as I said, it is going out to all pensioners. It is the first time that age pensioners in Australia have been provided with full, comprehensible and easily read information on their pension rates, their entitlements, fringe benefits, the income test free area, the tax free area and how other income will affect their pensions. It is an excellent publication and for those Opposition members who have not read it, I suggest that they do so because they will probably learn something as well. From what I gather, the knowledge of the age pension system is very much lacking on Opposition benches. This publication includes information on rates; it also includes a lot of information about the measures coming out of the Government's retirement incomes package, some of which were announced in the April statement and some in the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the pleasure of being the only South Australian member of the retirement incomes task force which was set up by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the end of last year to go around Australia talking to groups of retired people and individuals about the retirement incomes system. One of the things which was made very evident to us, which was raised at every meeting that we went to, was the lack of information; the fact that these people did not have, or could not get without great difficulty, the most basic information about their pensions and entitlements and what would happen to their pensions in the case of other income. It was raised with us consistently that information was something they craved. In my experience in my own electorate, I have found that people want information and, until now, they have not been getting it. Pensioners, in particular, now get accurate and relevant information through the Age Pension News.

The Opposition has, however, attacked this publication, suggesting that it is an irresponsible use of the taxpayers' money. Opposition members are, in fact, saying that age pensioners and service pensioners should not get any information-this information that they have craved for years and have not been getting. They say that this is an irresponsible use of taxpayers' money. We are providing them with the most basic information about their incomes on which, of course, they depend entirely. Of course, this publication is produced with taxpayers' money but some of these retired people, these pensioners, pay tax and if they do not pay it now they certainly have paid it in past. Why not use some of the tax that they have paid to give back to them information about their incomes. However, I gather that the Opposition prefers to keep them in the dark; it does not want them to know what their entitlements and pension rates are and what is happening in relation to their income. I know that the Opposition members are not in the habit of giving out this kind of information because people who live in neighbouring Liberal electorates ring my office asking for my pensioner information kit; thanking me for some advertisement I have put in the paper involving pension rates; and asking me for information about pensions because they say that I am the only person in the area who provides this. They say, `Mrs Harvey, I am very sorry I do not live in your electorate because nobody else around here is giving out any information at all about age pensions; about this income that we rely on'.

I would again like to thank the Minister for Social Security on behalf of my constituents and all the age and service pensioners of Australia for this excellent publication which includes not only information about pensions but also useful information for pre-retirees, people in their fifties and early sixties who are coming up to retirement and need to know now, well in advance of their retirement, the Government provisions for superannuation and, particularly, the tax treatment of pensions and superannuation which has been greatly liberalised by this Government. I am looking forward very much to the third edition of the Age Pension News. I am not sure when it will be coming out but I am sure that it will contain--

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the election, I suspect.

—I do not know when it will come out. It will come out at the appropriate time when there is useful information, which this Government wishes to impart to age and service pensioners. I wonder whether the honourable member has been telling his constituents about everything that has come out of the Budget.
—Yes, I have.

—Then he is one of the rare Opposition members who pass on that sort of information. Pensioners are entitled to know but they have not been getting that information. Now, through the Age Pension News, they are getting it, and I congratulate the Government on this publication.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Land Care-Nuclear Disarmament-Seat Belts in Buses-Hackham West, Adelaide-Tabulam Aboriginal Area-Pensions-Medicare: Abortions-Roxby Downs Mining Project: Environmental Impact Report-Importation of Pork-Illegal Entry onto Private Property

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Early today it was my pleasure to attend a very important launch by the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, of the formation of a private company to manage a national information and education campaign in support of 1990 as the Year of Land Care. I congratulate Mr Jim Kirk, the Chairman of the Australian Bicentennial Authority, on his acceptance of chairmanship of that company. I draw the attention of the House to supporting comments made at the launch by my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) in his capacity as shadow Minister for primary industry. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Land care is above politics. It is really about the future of sustainable agriculture and of the environmental quality of the Australia we bequeath to the next generation . . . The coalition parties recognise the need to present a corporative, bipartisan front to the people of Australia.

I take this opportunity to congratulate Rick Farley of the National Farmers Federation and Phillip Toyne of the Australian Conservation Foundation for their initiatives in making today's launch a reality. I also commend Mr Hector Tod of Hodgson Vale, Councillor Dick Scanlan of Laidley, and Dr Brian Roberts of the Darling Downs Institute, all in my electorate of Groom, for their vision and industry in these matters over the years. I also take the opportunity to welcome to the public gallery 30 of my constituents from Lockyer Valley.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 and 28 June this year, the second international meeting of representatives from 39 countries and 10 international organisations supporting nuclear weapon-free zones took place in Berlin under the sponsorship of the German Democratic Republic. Today I take the opportunity to congratulate the delegates at the conference on their establishment of the international liaison office for nuclear weapon-free zones. Membership is open to the participants of all countries and regular meetings will be held to exchange views, discuss proposals and note progress.

SPEECH.PARA: As the United Nations representative noted, there have been a number of important treaties prohibiting the deployment of nuclear weapons: notably, in the Antarctic, outer space and on the sea bed, as well as in Latin America with the Treaty of Tlatelolco and in the South Pacific with the Treaty of Rarotonga. The Australian delegate was Mr George Georges, a long time senator of our Parliament, who was representing the Australian Peace Committee. I would like to conclude by quoting from his speech to the conference. Referring to nuclear disarmament, he said:

It is not sufficient to make significant statements at a high level using diplomatic terms. It is necessary to take your campaign to the understanding of ordinary people, as it is the mass mobilisation of people against the initiatives and programs of major nations which has led to now a disarmament process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly on a subject on which I felt I could no longer remain silent. I was stirred by the very tragic bus crash several days ago in which many people were killed. Unfortunately, major bus crashes are now becoming very much more a feature of our road statistics. I would like to suggest that the time is now overdue to make the fitting of seat belts compulsory in buses and the wearing of them compulsory in those buses which travel extensive distances. I do not, of course, refer to the sort of bus that goes around the town and in which people are permitted to stand up. Obviously, in that case it is not possible, but in those buses that travel longer distances along the highway and at speed, I believe that the fitting and wearing of seat belts should be compulsory. It is possible: there are buses which are available to charter which do provide that service.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great risks in an accident is, of course, of people and objects flying through the air and injuries being caused in that way. Seat belts are compulsory in motor vehicles and aircraft. If they are compulsory in aircraft and, apparently, are thought to serve some sort of purpose in the event of an accident, then they ought to be compulsory in buses. I would like to call on the Federal Government to raise the matter with meetings of appropriate State Ministers. Obviously it is something that State Ministers have to act upon, but it is something on which we need a national approach. I would like our national government to take the lead in this very important area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw the attention of the House to the way in which grave damage can be done to the reputation of respectable citizens living in particular suburbs by thoughtless remarks reported in the media. Recently the Adelaide News carried two reports quoting police officers who described the suburb of Hackham West in my electorate as `the Bronx'. Naturally, the residents of Hackham West, which is a pleasant garden suburb full of people anybody would be proud to have as neighbours, were outraged by this comparison-and rightly so. As I told a meeting of Hackham West residents a couple of weeks ago, I have visited the real South Bronx in New York: a dangerous, treeless, burnt out slum where violent crimes such as armed robberies and widespread drug dealing have driven decent citizens away. I can assure the House that there is simply no resemblance between the Bronx and the well-kept suburb of Hackham West, which is full of respectable citizens who do take a real pride in their area.

SPEECH.PARA: The police officers quoted in the story enjoy a position of trust in the community and that is well-deserved, but that trust carries with it a heavy responsibility to be careful and accurate with their public statements. The people of Hackham West know that the Bronx label is wrong. So does anybody with any judgment. This is not the first time there have been sensationalist, inaccurate reports in the newspapers about Hackham West, but I certainly hope that it will be the last. The people of Hackham West are sick and tired of being misrepresented as a trouble spot in the social fabric of Adelaide. I want to assist their efforts to clear their good name in any way I can and raising this matter in the Parliament is, I hope, a step in that direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the granting of $130,000 for the construction of a new indoor sports centre at the Tabulam Aboriginal area in northern New South Wales. The centre will be the first of its kind in that region and will include a gymnasium and basketball facility. Undoubtedly it will be a building of great significance to the local area. The corporation concerned had heard of a similar project in another part of Australia and had the wisdom to apply for funding.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, however, one serious difficulty. The general community of that area of northern New South Wales has now discovered that the centre will be for the exclusive use of Aboriginal people and it is causing a great deal of concern and dissatisfaction. Similar facilities do not exist for young people living in the near vicinity to undertake sport of the kind that will be possible in this new complex.

I urge the Government to consider the importance of making facilities of this kind available to all Australians. It seems to me very retrograde to have a restriction of this kind. Many of my constituents who seek a review of the Government's decision have approached those who advise the Government on these matters. I would strongly urge that, in the interests of better relations in the various sections of the community, no such restriction be applied.
