SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking of attacks on the elderly, the most disgusting one has come from Grey Power, a rabid right wing fascist organisation. Grey Power's candidate in Hinkler, Ken Webb, was reported in a local newspaper as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: People who work hard all their lives and pay their taxes but don't waste their money are made to fend for themselves while some drunken bum who wasted every penny he had is given the full pension and all the benefits that go with it.
People work hard, raise families and educate their children. Most have only a small amount of savings left, particularly the many people who, over the years, have been receiving the base rate of pay.

The Government recognises those in genuine need and delivers a pension accordingly. Grey Power wants to abolish the means test for pensions. The average working family would have to pay increased tax so that Grey Power could give a millionaire a pension. Grey Power supports citizen initiated referenda, an idea which is, incidentally, supported by the League of Rights. We all know that the League of Rights is the Ku Klux Klan without bedsheets.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my sadness regarding the inability and unwillingness of the Hawke Government to provide time from the business of the House for us to debate appropriately a Bill introduced by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) to prevent Medicare funding of abortions. I believe it is very appropriate not only that the Bill be discussed and debated but also that we be allowed to have a division on it. So many in this community do not want our Medicare funding, our taxpayers' funds, to be used for this abhorrent purpose. In this group we all believe that life begins at conception and that abortion is nothing but the wilful destruction of life. We need to debate and divide on the Bill. We need an opportunity to express our views on this vitally important issue and to prevent taxpayers' money from being wasted by subsidising this abhorrence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express great concern over the outrageous refusal of the management of the Roxby Downs project to make public the annual environmental impact report. What is this uranium mining project hiding? While South Australian taxpayers have ploughed a massive $46m into the Roxby Downs project, to date a mere $640,000 has been received in royalties from uranium mined at Roxby, with a further $660,000 received from the copper deposits in the form of royalties. This is a disgraceful rip-off of taxpayers' money for a very dubious and environmentally dangerous mining venture. South Australian taxpayers are paying millions of dollars for the Roxby Downs secrecy.

SPEECH.PARA: South Australians were promised thousands of jobs at Roxby Downs, promises that ranged from 200,000 jobs to 30,000 jobs during construction to 15,000 permanent jobs. But in 1989, after many years of operation, there are only 870 jobs covering the project work force, with a further 220 indirect jobs for shopkeepers and so on. The indenture is a farce. If annual environmental impact reports are not released to the taxpaying public the Government must surely question its involvement in this project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter which is very important to my electorate, and that is the Government's recent decision to allow the importation of frozen Canadian pork. The Canadian industry has certain diseases that do not exist in Australia and one is transmissible gastroenteritis, which could be transmitted to Australia via pig products. Of course, the Government says that although that is a remote possibility, the product would never get to the pigs because in Australia we have laws against the feeding of pig-swill. That would seem a reasonable argument to cut off any opportunity of infected pork getting to a pig.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I draw the Parliament's attention to the fact that on 4 October 1989 a resident of Canberra appeared before the Canberra Magistrates Court for driving offences. He applied for a special licence, having lost his licence, presumably, through drink driving, and claimed that he needed such a licence so he could continue to collect pig-swill from Chinese restaurants in the Australian Capital Territory. As Chinese restaurants probably sell more pork than any other meat, no doubt they would be very attracted to cut-price frozen pork coming from another country. Whilst the Government argues that there is no way that this disease, which would devastate the Australian pig industry, could be transferred from the plate, if you like, to the pigpen, that is not so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention to an answer to a question which I received recently on the rights or indemnity of private citizens for a damages suit issued against them for injuries incurred by a person illegally entering their property. It would appear from the answer, and from a High Court ruling, that under some circumstances private law-abiding citizens can be liable for a damages suit against them by a person who, having entered their property, sustains an injury in the course of robbing the property and who commits an assault or other criminal act against the person or persons who own the residence.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, no person who enters premises for an illegal act-whether he is a professional criminal or not-has the right to the protection of the law for the carrying out of his functions. It would seem that under some circumstances the common law and the law of some States of Australia allow a person committing a criminal act to sue for damages an innocent person who is being robbed. I ask that that be re-examined and, if possible, eliminated.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENT HOUSE: TRANSPORT WORKERS UNION INDUSTRIAL ACTION

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to advise the House of some matters that relate to Transport Workers Union bans which will affect the Parliament. On 25 October 1989 the clearing of waste from the loading dock area was banned until further notice. However, I understand that a load was taken away today. Banned indefinitely is the route 777 tourist bus to Parliament House. On an indefinite basis buses will not pick up or set down passengers at Parliament House bus stops on routes 231, 234 and 235. These are the only bus services which travel between Woden and Civic via Parliament House.

INTERJECT.PARA: At 9 p.m. on 25 October 1989 Commonwealth car drivers refused to pick up or drop passengers at Parliament House. However, Aerial Taxis advised that it would take cash bookings from Parliament House. The bans are part of a general campaign by unions in the public sector in support of their wage demands under the current wage fixation principles of the Industrial Relations Commission. The Department of Industrial Relations has been notified of these bans and is coordinating the Government's response. I am unaware of any other services to the Parliament that have been affected at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Did the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories give as Cabinet's reason for withholding permission for the development of Coronation Hill that `we've got no assessment at all' needed to determine the impact on the Kakadu National Park of additional mining projects being allowed to proceed? Was the Prime Minister advised by the Minister of the existence and contents of the report from the Minister's department which did in fact assess future mining development in the region? If so, why was this report ignored and, if not, will the Prime Minister now reopen Cabinet's considerations of this vital economic policy matter to consider not only this report but also the personal submission of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy?

—The matter will not be reopened. I understand that the report referred to by the honourable member in his question was a very preliminary report prepared by officers of Senator Richardson's department last year on the basis of a one-week visit to the conservation zone. We do not consider that that report provided an adequate basis on which to make a proper decision about the possible cumulative environmental impact of mining in the new exploration area, and quite clearly the 12-month inquiry envisaged by the Resource Assessment Commission will provide a more intensive study of these issues. It is after receipt of the results of that inquiry that the matter will be considered again by the Government.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to reports that domestic aviation capacity is running at much less than 50 per cent of normal demand. Can the Minister advise the House whether these reports are correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen reports of claims by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) and also by its soul mate, the Federal Opposition, that the capacity of the domestic aviation system is running at under 50 per cent. For instance, last weekend the Leader of the National Party of Australia was encouraging pilot propaganda about the number of flights being less than 10 per cent of the normal number, and that half of the passengers were being carried by the Royal Australian Air Force. Opposition members are just parroting pilot propaganda.
—Come and catch a plane with me.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting and listen to the answer.

—Those claims are totally wrong. The fact is that capacity is now at over 50 per cent of normal demand and will increase considerably in the near future. Normally there are something like 40,000 seats required each day. At the present time we have available 21,000 seats a day, which is a little over 50 per cent. Of those 21,000 seats, 61 per cent are being provided by Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines through their own aircraft and through wet leased aircraft-that is, foreign aircraft and foreign pilots. Fourteen per cent are being provided by Qantas Airways Ltd, 10 per cent by the Royal Australian Air Force, 9 per cent by international carriers, and 5 per cent by commuter airlines flying trunk routes. So clearly, current capacity is meeting more than 50 per cent of normal demand, and that capacity is about to increase dramatically through November. It will increase because of a number of additional wet leased aircraft and also because of the companies getting more of their own aircraft into the air.

ANSWER.PARA: At the moment there are seven wet leased aircraft. Ansett has two America West aircraft; Australian has four aircraft and the two airlines share a Royal Brunei aircraft. The Royal Brunei aircraft is going out of action this week but there will be 12 additional wet leased aircraft coming on in the next couple of weeks. There are to be two 757 aircraft from the United Kingdom for Ansett and two additional 737s from America West. Australian will have five 737s, two 757s and one 727, all of which will be available by mid-November. What we will see, therefore, is a very dramatic surge of capacity in the course of the next few weeks, through the introduction of these additional wet leased aircraft and also the capacity of the companies to get more of their own aircraft into the air. That is increasing daily through their recruitment of fully trained foreign pilots, as a result of more pilots being trained here in Australia, and also, importantly, as a result of AFAP pilots increasingly coming back to work.

The pilots are returning to work despite the fact that there is intensive intimidation of those who do return. That intimidation has taken the form of telephone abuse, some of which I have heard from a tape recording taken from an answering device. It was obscene and extremely aggressive. There has been a lot of abuse of pilots at their homes by persons going to their homes; surveillance of pilots; the sending of wreaths to pilots who go back to work; and intimidation of pilots at the airport when they are about to get onto a plane and be in charge of passengers. Despite all of this, we get the Federation talking about concerns about safety. Not- withstanding all of that intimidation, pilots are increasingly coming back to work and the companies are therefore confident that through November they will move to a capacity of about 80 per cent of normal demand. They will shortly produce schedules for mid-November through the Christmas period and thereafter which will demonstrate that confidence.

This all has a significant message for those pilots who are still refusing to come back to work. Firstly, they should understand that the system is being restored despite the fact that they remain out. Through November capacity will lift to about 80 per cent of normal demand. The second point they should understand is that the longer they wait to come back, the less chance they have of getting a job. That is because they understand, I hope, that with the increased productivity coming from the new award, or from the new contracts which became the new award, several hundred fewer pilots will be needed by the airlines. New recruits are being employed, and they are taking up the positions. As well, some of their colleagues are coming back. So the longer those who are out stay out, the less chance they have of getting the remaining jobs. The third point that they should understand and understand well is that they should not live in any expectation of a negotiated settlement, despite the propaganda from the AFAP leaders that this is still a possibility. The fact is that there is no possibility of a negotiated settlement. The new award has been established and the Government and the airlines will not deviate from that new award-unlike the Opposition which, despite the fact that it says it would have a wages policy which would reduce inflation, wants to negotiate wage increases outside the wage guidelines. We are not like that. There will be no deviation from the awards. The only way that the pilots can return to work is by deciding individually to do so. The sooner they make that decision individually, the better off they will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. He has underpredicted inflation in six Budgets out of seven. In the light of today's figure of a 2.3 per cent rise, giving an annual rate of increase of at least 8 per cent, does he still stand by his August Budget prediction that the consumer price index (CPI) will rise by 7 per cent through this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand by my statement that the CPI will rise by 7 1/2 per cent on average throughout the year. I make the point that if we compare apples with apples, the CPI, which was just on 11 per cent under the Liberals, is today 6.7 per cent.
—How do you arrive at that?

—The Australian Statistician arrives at it by excluding those components which have since been added. If we compare it to the CPI under the Liberals, we see that inflation has come down from 11 per cent to 6.7 per cent. The most interesting thing to emerge this morning came from the shadow Treasurer who, on the World Today program on the same subject when asked whether inflation would be reduced through higher interest rates, said:

ANSWER.PARA: No. I think if you work fairly quickly with a tighter fiscal policy and changing the wage determination process and those micro-reform measures I referred to, you immediately take the weight off monetary policy . . .
Let me just examine the point. The shadow Treasurer is advocating working with a tighter fiscal policy. His own figures put the surplus at $140m larger.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that's wrong.
—It is in the honourable member's statement. It would be $140m larger in an economy of $366,000m.
—You are wrong again.
—What extra weight on fiscal policy is there there? Because there is an $800m hole, that is minus $700m. That is a surplus--
—You include them in your own statistics.
—Order! The member for Dundas!

—The honourable member for Dundas must be getting frustrated. He was at this yesterday. The Opposition's surplus would be $700m less than that of the Government and the Opposition is committed to give away fiscal drag. So it has $5 billion worth of fiscal commitments, but the shadow Treasurer has the temerity to talk about a tighter fiscal policy. The second point the shadow Treasurer made was to change the wage determination process. That means he would move to an enterprise bargaining model. Does anybody believe that in an economy with any growth, particularly such as we have had, the enterprise bargaining model would do anything other than lift wage rates and inflation way beyond the levels at which they are now? But the shadow Treasurer would move quickly on a tighter fiscal policy which, by his own definition, is no tighter, and which is clearly weaker, and to a wage bargaining system. Today the Opposition has apologised for the pilots with their 30 per cent claim. According to the shadow Treasurer, all that will allow the Opposition to take the weight off monetary policy to reduce inflation. That is the essence of the Liberal policy. That is the essence of its policy document. When we comb through the rest, we see that that is it. The Opposition will have a weaker fiscal policy, but wage bargaining at enterprise level. We could imagine how enterprises would go with a bunch of unions coming at them in the free-for-all that the Opposition is encouraging.
—Why don't you table the Hansard of three years ago?
—Order! The honourable member for Tangney!
—You ought to give it away.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar!
—I call the honourable member for Canning to order also.
—An enterprise bargain with one enterprise trying to stand against the attack of a craft union--
—It never comes out as he says. We have not had the J-curve yet.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting or I will name him.
—I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.

—An individual enterprise would try to stand against the onslaught of a group of craft unions, encouraged by the coalition's policy. The coalition would then say that we would have lower wage outcomes along with a weaker fiscal policy and that would allow it to take the weight off monetary policy. I do not think anyone who has ever had the shadow Treasurer's job has ever uttered rubbish like that. Even the people who did not have quite the tightness in the linkages, understood the linkages and did not commit themselves to rubbish like this, yet that is the rubbish we hear from the shadow Treasurer every day. What do Opposition members think the financial markets will think of the shadow Treasurer's statements when they know that the Opposition has said that it will not have a tighter fiscal policy and that it has been enjoining the Government for eight weeks to cave in to the pilots and that it will stand up with some enterprise bargaining model, and we are supposed to see wages fall so that the weight can be taken off-not put on-monetary policy?
—Productivity would be up.

—Oh, productivity up! We will have a wage increase of 12 or 13 per cent and we would need a 6 or 7 per cent productivity shift to be able to reduce interest rates and inflation. Opposition members must be joking! This is the tripe, this is the rubbish, that is put up as an alternative economic policy supposedly by someone who knows something about macro-economic policy. I have been through the policy document on a number of occasions, but today the shadow Treasurer repeated that bunkum: a tighter fiscal policy for a Budget he himself says will be only $140m tighter-out of a total of $366,000m that is nothing-and a wage determination system based on enterprise bargaining against a craft structure. According to the Opposition, that will let it take the weight off monetary policy. Nobody believes it. The Opposition is trying to dupe the Australian public with a set of policy settings which no group in the world, no economist in the world, certainly no financial market economist, no Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development economist, no International Monetary Fund economist, no basically reputable economic agency in the world, would regard as anything but rubbish.

—Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training inform the House of the outcomes of programs to assist the unemployed? Is the Minister aware of proposals to change these programs? If so, what is the Government's response to them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have been pleased to record on several occasions in the House, one of the proudest achievements of the Government has been the creation of some 1 1/2 million jobs during our period in office. That has meant not only an increase in the number of people in the work force, but also a dramatic reduction in the number of people who are actually registered as unemployed, a reduction from some 700,000 when we came to office to something like 500,000-a very significant drop indeed.

ANSWER.PARA: In order to pursue the honourable member's question, it is worth looking a little at the composition of the unemployed to see where the most important reductions have occurred. We find a most dramatic reduction in the number of longer term unemployed people. It should not be necessary for me to remind the House that it was as a result of the recession induced by our opponents, the Opposition, that there was such a dramatic increase in the number of longer term unemployed people. In 1982 or thereabouts, about 47,000 people were registered as having been out of work for between 12 and 24 months. Within about a year that had more than doubled to between 108,000 and 109,000. Similarly, the same story occurred with those who had been unemployed for more than two years. As a result of the recession the numbers increased from about 44,000 to more than 100,000-more than doubling. That was a clear consequence of the policies which were pursued by our opponents.

Under this Government, the most dramatic reduction has occurred in the number of those who have been unemployed for between 12 and 24 months, a reduction from 108,000 to 47,000. The fall in those unemployed for more than 24 months has been from 100,000 or more to 67,000. That is, some 90,000 people for whom unemployment and unemployment benefit had become a way of life were rescued from that parlous, dismal and frustrating circumstance. But how did we get there? It was not just as a result of hoping. It was not a result of callously knocking people around by trying to haul them off the dole and then put them onto some other benefit. It was as a result of carefully targeting training programs more recently and, before that, job creation programs.

We have been particularly successful, through our training programs, in addressing the circumstances of the most needy-that is, those most in need of government assistance. We have helped them and, importantly, their families. These 90,000 people were not just individuals floating around somewhere in the ionosphere; they had been breadwinners, thrown on to the dole scrap heap by our opponents, and we had rescued them and their families with the programs we have pursued. Yet, what does the Opposition now say? It wants to rip $250m out of these very programs which have been so successful in helping these people. This is the most gutless policy that we can imagine any respectable political party ever embracing. The Opposition says it wants to save a few bob, so it picks on those people who are least able to look after themselves, the ones who are least able to complain. It is not only a question of political gutlessness on the Opposition's part, but it is also obviously a social disgrace that these people should be ignored and penalised by the Opposition. But it is even worse than that.

As a result of a very new program that my colleague the Minister for Social Security and I have been putting into effect, that of Newstart, we have helped 20,000 people, specifically in this longer term unemployed category. Our opponents say, `We will keep Newstart, but we will get rid of Jobstart'. Little do they know that one of the most important ways of helping those people is through Jobstart. It wants to keep Newstart, but it wants to rip out of Newstart that part of it which is most effective in helping these long term unemployed. So the 20,000 people who are being encouraged back into the labour market, encouraged back into work, encouraged off the social security system, are the very ones whom the Opposition is intent on abandoning.

To take up the theme of the most recent answer given by my colleague the Treasurer, what solution does the Opposition offer? Again, we are back to wages policy. Not only will wages policy fix inflation, not only will wages policy fix interest rates, not only will wages policy fix the current account, but also wages policy will fix training! Somehow the Opposition's miraculous wages policy-and in order to believe in its wages policy one would have to believe in fairies-will give effect to these important objectives. Nobody believes that is true. Nobody believes that is possible. What we know now, as we have known in the past, is that the only recourse a Peacock government would have to economic policy is to grind the economy back into a recession, to tip onto the unemployment heap hundreds of thousands more people. As we have observed before, it takes a very special talent to drive this economy into reverse. It is perhaps the only talent that the Liberal and National parties have. Thankfully, it is a talent they will never, ever, be able to exercise again.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES: STAFF MEMBER

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. I remind him that he said yesterday that the declarations of pecuniary interest by Mr Michael Ross who, for 4 1/2 years, was in an obvious conflict of interest while he worked for the Minister, were in order, that those declarations of interest were regularly updated, and that one of them had been located and was handed over to, or drawn to the attention of, the Australian Federal Police although, as the Minister would realise, the Hansard has been altered to read only that the form was drawn to the attention of the police and not handed over to them. Will the Minister now table these declarations of interest, including the one located and shown to the police, and any reports made on them, to enable the House to see for itself what commercial or other interests Mr Ross brought to the notice of the Minister at the time of his appointment, and subsequently?

—I do not propose to table any pecuniary interest declarations. I totally stand by what I said yesterday and that is that the pecuniary interest declarations from Mr Ross were indeed submitted to me and they did not include declarations of interest in consultancies or in any other external businesses.
—How can they be in order then?
—Order! The honourable member for Lowe.

—Furthermore, as I said yesterday, the security clearances of this individual by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and other Federal authorities prior to his starting work with me were granted to a `top secret' status. The pecuniary interest form declarations were regularly updated. They never included any declarations of the nature to which the honourable member for Menzies refers. At least one of those declarations, which was located, of course, in the safe in my office, was drawn to the attention of the Federal Police and the others, of course, were handed over to the Department which I understand has a policy of, after a certain time, destroying all the pecuniary interest forms which are held. That policy, I understand, operates as far as the Public Service is concerned, and as far as government staff members are concerned-for everyone. I conclude my answer by raising two questions of my own which I will rhetorically address to the Leader of the Opposition. Is it the practice of the Leader of the Opposition and the front bench members of the Opposition to require pecuniary interest declarations from their staff? Does he ascertain whether or not any of his front bench members are in fact receiving fees from any consultancy?

—I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. To what extent is so-called contracting out currently undertaken in the delivery of government services? What are the up-front costs associated with the total contracting out of these services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important matter because it goes to the heart of the way in which government delivers services to itself--

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Downer interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Mayo.

—To the way this Government does that and the ways in which the Opposition, in the unlikely event of its getting into government, would deliver services to government. The fact is that the Opposition has proposed to contract out services to government. I draw the House's attention to the fact that a great number of government services are already contracted out to the extent of about $1,000m per year. Something like 98 per cent of the construction of government buildings, up to $735m worth of work, is already contracted out. Forty per cent of project design, totalling $40m, is already contracted out. Also, approximately 90 per cent of removals and associated storage, to the extent of about $70m, is already contracted out. All of those areas, plus a number of other areas, are already contracted out. In the Opposition's propositions with regard to contracting out it has totally neglected to mention the substantial reforms that this Government has already implemented with regard to cost recovery.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Moore interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Hello, the Great Gatsby over there wants to have a bit of a say; the great contractor, the great privatiser. To whom is he going to sell the Overseas Telecommunications Commission? To Christopher Skase? As far as commercialisation is concerned--

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members are eating into their own Question Time.

—The Opposition, in talking about contracting out, has neglected to mention that we have already taken substantial decisions on reforms to government services involving cost recovery and commercialisation, which means untying agencies to go to the private sector-that is, contracting out-if they so wish. Already something like 2,400 personnel and $75m have been saved in that area in the last year.

ANSWER.PARA: I come now to a very important point about the Opposition policy. What it has totally neglected to mention in its costings of this exercise is that the total contracting out of the other services, in addition to those already contracted out which I mentioned at the outset of this reply, would involve the retrenchment of something like 11,500 personnel, particularly in the Department of Administrative Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—I have been informed by my Department and the Department of Finance that these retrenchments would cost something like $1.2 billion directly on Budget outlays in the first two to three years. That means that there would be a direct addition to Budget outlays of anything up to $600m in each of the first two years. So the Opposition cannot have it both ways. The Opposition either has to fund this massive retrenchment program by further savings or it must reduce the proposed tax rebates by, say, $600m per year in the first two years. So in addition to the $835m hole-that is, the savings shortfall that the Treasurer has already identified in the Opposition's misguided exercise-the Opposition now has to explain, if it wants to go ahead with contracting out, how it is going to find $1.2 billion, that is, $600m over each of the first couple of years, with which to fund its exercise. Otherwise, of course, the Opposition would not be able to proceed with contracting out, because it would lose a lot more money than it would propose to save.

—I refer the Prime Minister to the Treasurer's public statement yesterday that no interest rate relief is likely before June next year. Will the Prime Minister now admit that his unsubstantiated claim in the Western Australian State election that home mortgage interest rates would fall below 15 per cent by the end of the year will simply not eventuate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position in regard to interest rates is, like so many things that come out of the Opposition, continually misrepresented. The position which the Treasurer has put, not only yesterday but in recent times, is exactly the same as I have put. It is that the economic condition confronting this country is basically one of too strong a level of demand. In that situation, it is necessary that the instruments of policy be appropriately set to reduce that level of demand. That level of demand has developed during this year at a higher rate than was anticipated by any economist in this country, government or private, going back to the beginning of this year or at the end of the previous year.

ANSWER.PARA: As distinct from those opposite in their period of government, when they showed a complete inability to conduct macro-economic policy in a way which would sustain a level of activity consistent with employment growth, what this Government has done, as has been said in answer by some of my Ministers previously today, is to have a rate of employment growth which is five times faster than the Opposition was able to generate in its seven years in office and more than twice as fast as that of the rest of the world.

We are not going to throw away an economic policy which has allowed a massive reduction in unemployment in this country. At the same time, we are not going to allow a level of demand which will continue to impose unsustainable strains upon our external accounts. That is why the Treasurer and I have said in these circumstances that all arms of policy-monetary, wages and fiscal-will be set in a way which retains that proper balance. That has meant that monetary policy will remain tight for as long as is necessary to bring down the level of demand to that equilibrium sort of level which maintains growth; not to a level which is too high on the external account, but to one which is sufficiently high to enable employment to continue to grow.

That means, as we see it, monetary policy staying tight into the future. We have both said, and I repeat, that monetary policy will not be kept tight one day longer than is necessary to achieve those objectives; nor will it be taken off one day earlier. We will do what we have shown ourselves capable of doing in our 6 1/2 years in government, which the Opposition was never able to do, and that is to keep growth going and to sustain employment. The Opposition was never able to do that. The one reason the Opposition was never able to do that, apart from its ideological obsession, was that, in technical terms, the Opposition never had available to it a wages policy. What happened was that when the pressure came on the then Prime Minister and his Treasurer, and those advising him-who have now been elevated to or deposed from, whichever way one wants to look at it, the front bench of the Liberal Party-did not have a wages policy. What happened in the event was that when the pressure came on the Opposition gave away the centralised wage fixing system and the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission said, `Okay, that is the government policy; we will give it away'.

So we do not have to have a theoretical exercise to examine the inadequacy of the Opposition's policy. We can simply say, `Cast your mind back to 1981; that is when you had exactly the position, the policy, that you are advocating again now'. The Opposition has not got the wit, the wisdom or the guts to learn from its own mistakes. It seeks to inflict upon the Australian people again what it inflicted upon them in 1981. What happened in 1981? Wages exploded by 18 per cent because the Opposition did not have a wage policy. The Opposition inflicted upon the Australian economy the worst recession in 50 years, with simultaneous double digit unemployment and double digit inflation, because it did not have a wages policy.

One would have thought that people with a modicum of intelligence would have said, `My God, if we did that with the previous policy, perhaps we ought to think of something better and different'. But no, the Opposition sat down in its cocoon for six years trying to think up a policy-we are all waiting for it-but at the end of it, the Opposition came out with exactly the same mishmash as before.

The Opposition is saying, `We are saying to you, the members of the business community who have had now under the Labor Government a massive lift in the profit share from 11.2 per cent to 16.5 per cent and who, associated with that, have had the highest level of investment since statistics have been recorded, the highest proportion of gross domestic product going to investment ever, that we will take that away from the business community, we will take away the protection of a centralised wage system which has given record employment growth, record investment and record profit share, and expose you to an unregulated, uncontrolled wage bargaining system. We will give you pilots multiplied a thousand times. What we have said to the pilots is, ``You go for your 30 per cent. The Opposition has supported you from day one in that'', and any other group in the community which tries to exercise its industrial muscle would be fully entitled to do it under the Opposition'. Yet the Opposition has the temerity to get up here and talk about interest rates. One knows what would happen in that situation. If the Opposition allowed its unregulated wages policy to apply, the economy would collapse and interest rates would go through the roof.

Fortunately, as we go into the period between now and the election, which we are all looking forward to, we will be able not simply to look at the theoretical inadequacy of the Opposition's policy but also to remind the people in Australia, who have got good memories in this matter, of what the Opposition inflicted upon them before. In its last 12 months in office another quarter of a million Australians were thrown onto the unemployment scrap heap. Who is to blame for that other than the Opposition? The Opposition could not blame anyone else. It could not blame the unions or the Industrial Relations Commission, because they were doing what the Opposition told them to do. The people of Australia will remember that. They will remember the record interest rates, record unemployment and record inflation which the previous Government's policies inflicted upon them and which those opposite inevitably would inflict upon them again if ever they get the opportunity. Fortunately, they will not get it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to a report regarding a proposal retrospectively to abolish the existing capital gains tax? If so, what are the intentions of the Government in this matter? What are the implications of this proposal for Commonwealth revenue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that the capital gains tax has played a major part in restoring fairness to the tax system. The proposition is this: why should somebody who gets his income from buying or selling property or shares pay no tax while millions of ordinary wage and salary earners automatically pay their tax each week? The capital gains area has shifted into the tax system to support productive investment whereas before its presence passive speculative investment was rewarded with capital gains free income. Now that income from capital gains is taxed in the same manner as any other form of income, investment is being channelled into those areas of economy which produce dynamic income-areas which produce employment, growth and activity. It is only through growth and activity that Australia's current account deficit will change. This measure has completely torn away the underpinnings of the tax avoidance industry which tried to turn all forms of income into capital gains type income so as to escape taxation. In other words, the whole tax avoidance industry was about changing the nature of income from income to capital to escape paying tax.

ANSWER.PARA: The amount of revenue generated by the tax proves the point. This year $500m will be generated. Through the payment of capital gains tax, $500m will accrue to the Commonwealth. If it were to be abolished, as is proposed by the coalition, property prices would skyrocket, as investors would flood back into the market. In essence, any proposal to abolish the capital gains tax does not provide a plan for increasing investment or national savings. There is an argument, particularly from the coalition, that one should abolish the capital gains tax to increase investment in national savings. The converse would clearly be the case. Less than one per cent of individual taxpayers actually pay capital gains tax. I have had these figures checked. It would penalise the 99 per cent of individual taxpayers not liable to pay capital gains tax.

As recent media articles have pointed out, the significance of the proposal put by the coalition is this: the Opposition is making a commitment not only to abolish the Government's capital gains tax but also to backdate the effect of its abolition to 19 September 1985. The words `retrospective legislation' used to apply to a tax penalty applied retrospectively. This is a benefit applied retrospectively. It is reverse retrospectivity. It is a benefit, not a penalty, applied retrospectively. As a result, an enormous dislocation in the property and share markets would ensue as people with accrued capital gains sought to cash in on the windfall gains, gratis of the Leader of the Opposition. The billions of dollars of capital gains liability now sitting in the system unrealised would be realised if all of this property was cashed in on the market.

Who would be the grandaddy of those who would cash in? Of course, it is that champion of the working class, the President of the Liberal Party, Mr Elliott, the person who says that people receiving the unemployment benefit are bludgers. Next month Mr Elliott will be sitting on over 11 1/2 million bonus shares in Elders-IXL Ltd in respect of 15 1/2 million one cent paid ordinary shares directly held by him in the company, for which he has paid $155,000. What contingent capital gains attach to these bonus shares? What are they worth upon realisation? The answer is that Mr Elliott is sitting on a potential capital gain of about $35m. He has paid $155,000 for the shares and he is sitting on a potential gain of $35m. If a coalition government decided to remove the capital gains tax as from the date of the election, that gain would continue to be taxable, but it would not continue to be taxable if the retrospectivity applied because, as I understand it, these shares were taken out somewhere between June and September 1987. Come September 1992, if they were realised, there would be a contingent tax liability to the Commonwealth of about $17m. So a $17m benefit would accrue in this case to Mr Elliott by virtue of the fact that the measure is retrospective to 1985-not by virtue of the fact that the measure would be cancelled from the date of introduction by a coalition government, but by virtue of its retrospectivity.

Is it any wonder that the so-called speculative gains tax would be backdated? Is it any wonder that the Opposition proposes a few dollars for families with kids and $17m for the Liberal Party's boss? That is the kind of equity we would see from a coalition government. One per cent of taxpayers are affected by capital gains tax, yet billions of dollars worth of unrealised capital gains liability would be handed back. No country in the world would have witnessed such a trans-fer of wealth because of one shabby decision by those opposite which would confer a retrospective benefit from 1985. The billions of dollars worth of unrealised capital gains contingent liability accruing in the name of the Commonwealth is to be given back, while at the same time the coalition would throw a couple of dollars by way of rebate for families. It would hand $17m to the Liberal Party's President and at the same time take the unemployed, beat them up and send them to Saint Vincent de Paul, the Smith Family and the Salvation Army. It would throw 100,000 people off the unemployment benefit queues.

That is the sort of morality of those opposite. The Opposition's policy is not only immoral but also, as the Australian Financial Review said yesterday, it has no philosophical basis because it would lopside the tax system. The Opposition, instead of having a tax system which would support dynamic, income producing employing activity, would support capital gains free benefits for passive investments. How does the Opposition think that we can dig our way out of the current account hole that we are in if the nation is investing in blocks of flats and open space property instead of in companies or in any capital formation? The Opposition would not only lopside the tax system but also it wants to give its mates billions of dollars. It wants to give its principal mate, the bloke who runs the Liberal Party, a $17m benefit. Is it any wonder that the Opposition's shabby proposal is backdated to September 1985? Is it any wonder that it is doing what it has usually done-looking after the people who really bludge on Australian society, the people who do not pay their tax?

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Prime Minister forthwith making a statement outlining the Government's plans to deal with the mounting economic crisis which is a direct result of this Government's economic mismanagement.

The reason the Opposition moves this is quite clear. There is a sham approach to government in this country today. We are seeing a demonstrable failure of leadership by the current incumbent of the prime ministership. It is reflected in the failure of economic management, record taxes, record interest rates, high inflation, abysmal productivity and mounting foreign debt. It is also reflected in broken promises to the Australian people, in cave-ins to special interest groups and pandering to the trade union leadership. In short, a policy-bankrupt government, under this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), has lowered the living standards of most Australians.

In the last two days Australia's credit rating has been downgraded again. We have had yet another disastrous result in the balance of payments and another bad consumer price index number. To sum it up mildly and in brief, the Government's situation is bad and the economy is even worse. All the bravado and all the phoney confidence of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) cannot hide the fact that Australia is stuck in an abysmal malaise under this Labor Government. The Government has, simply put, given up governing. It has left us in Opposition to produce the only alternative for this nation. It can certainly be said that under Hawke and under Keating there is an absence of any plan, any set of policies, to get Australia out of the very mess their policies have produced.

Let me just run through a few of the elements that sum up this Government today. First, it is a government of the big lie. There is a desperate, deliberate effort to hide the real truth from the Australian people. Second, there is an unremitting willingness to sacrifice the good of the country to the narrow partisan interests of the Australian Labor Party and its mates. Third, it is a government of cliques and mates. There is no Labor principle that this Prime Minister will not sacrifice in his desire to placate the rich and the powerful. Any principle that Labor held dear can be put to one side. Fourth, we have seen an unprecedented use of government power for purely partisan purposes. Fifth, we have seen the wholesale abuse of taxpayers' funds to try to advantage Labor's election prospects. Sixth, there has been an absolute failure to take action when it is needed in the national interest because of the fear of an election. All the bravado has led to putting it off and putting it off and putting it off. Seventh, we see both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer hurl what can only be described as vicious abuse at whoever incurs their wrath. Finally, this Prime Minister will find that the tactics of the quick fix, of stitching up the deal of the moment, the backroom operation, just will not wash with this country.

Time and again we have come in here and asked for policies. The change in the political landscape over the last couple of weeks has been very interesting. It is the Opposition that proposes; it has the blueprint and the policies. The Government has nothing. Ask this Government what its future policy is in any field of government administration. It does not have one. In not one arena will it be going to the election with a policy for the future. Honourable members actually heard it today out of the mouth of the Prime Minister: in the campaign he will be stressing what transpired in the past. We are looking forward; the Government can look back.

I am now going to pose a number of questions. We can answer every one but the Government cannot. Where is the Government's policy of tax relief for families? Will the Government commit itself to the discipline of forgoing the proceeds of bracket creep? Does the Government intend to reduce the size of the public sector? Where is the Government's oft talked of program of privatisation? Will the Government adopt our spending cuts? Will the Government liberalise the labour market and achieve long overdue productivity improvements? Where is the Government's policy on injecting foreign competition into coastal shipping? When will we see real action to clean up the waterfront? For example, after what we heard today, the Government should state its policy, not a few examples, on contracting out.

The Government cannot answer those questions other than in the negative. It has no blueprint for this nation, no policy to take it ahead. It is nothing but a fix it and stitch it up deal of the day government. What the Government actually does-bereft of any policy-is the dirtiest, crudest arrangement of the lot. It comes in here with its bombast, claims victory and then leaves the field. I can give a very tragic example of this. No Australian will be unmoved as we replay the words which the Prime Minister used as his centrepiece in the last election. The Government can do many things in this country but when in 1987 the Prime Minister claimed as the centrepiece of the election campaign that `no child will live in poverty in 1990', the day came when he must answer for that. Later in this House he walked away from that and replaced it, skidding over the words and saying, `What I meant was that no child need live in poverty'. The words were: `No child will live in poverty'.
Mr Beazley interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —No amount of interjection from you will change that. You can lie if you like; they are the words.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will withdraw that remark.
—I did not accuse him. It was hypothetical.
—You cannot make the imputation that the Minister at the table is lying.

—In the Prime Minister's address to the Australian Council of Social Service conference on this theme only last month he claimed that he had eliminated child poverty. He added, in the hyperbole of this Government, this outrageous bombast, that the Government had eliminated it `six months ahead of schedule'. On Tuesday of this week the Executive Director of the Victorian Council of Social Service, Robert Hudson, put the truth. He said that approximately 500,000 children were still living in poverty. The Government walks in here, claims victory, walks away and leaves the field. After that disgraceful degree of rhetoric in that campaign, 500,000 people have been ignored.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has the policies. It has the alternative. Instead of non-policies, it has detailed the most comprehensive economic program ever produced by an opposition in this country. We are offering real relief for families with children-the absolutely forgotten people. The Government has been dishing out the money here and there, but it has forgotten the millions and millions of hard-working men and women with kids. It has just overlooked them, other than milking them for more tax. That is why we have included child tax rebates, increased eligibility for the dependent spouse rebate and child-care tax rebates. Eric Risstrom, the Secretary of the Australian Taxpayers Association, has pointed out that a family on average weekly earnings with three children and a spouse earning $4,000 a year will pay approximately 20 per cent less tax under our policy. In anyone's terms, this is a substantial break for families.

The Opposition has given the historic commitment to return the proceeds of bracket creep. I would just like to pause on that topic. If the Government rejects the undertaking to return the proceeds of bracket creep-as it appears it would-there can be only one conclusion. The bottom line is that if it does not return the proceeds of bracket creep it is in favour of higher taxation. That leads people to say that the Liberal and National parties are the parties of low taxation. In addition, the Treasurer sought to besmirch-forgetting the countless thousands and thousands of small businessmen who will gather so much from us-the Opposition's proposal to abolish Labor's capital gains tax, which will reinvigorate small business and restore the needed incentive to save and invest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. We all realise that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) likes to strut the world stage like a barnyard rooster and send messages home on videotape, but the reality is that he belongs in this chamber this afternoon so that he can explain to the Australian people and to this Parliament what his Government is going to do with our emerging economic crisis. The reason why he is not here and the reason why the Government front benches and back benches are empty is that the Government does not have a clue what it is going to do. It has total paralysis, a fear of the impending doom at the ballot box. As soon as Government members can scuttle out of this place at the end of Question Time, off they go like cockroaches back to their offices, ringing up in their marginal seats trying to curry the favour of the electorate to get support on that inevitable day when the Australian people toss them out.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, it will not work; it will not work at all. The Australian people know that this Prime Minister and his Government cannot be trusted. Australian business knows that it cannot do business with this Government unless, of course, it happens to be in bed with it and there are lots of examples of that. This Government's Budget strategy is totally blown out of the water. It is hooked on ad hoc decision-making. It has no policies. Its members break promises and they have turned into the greatest lot of political opportunists that have ever been seen. Let us have a look at the Budget strategy and the current account deficit. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us that it would be $18.5 billion. It is more likely to be $25 billion. I will bet that I am a bit closer to the real figure than the Treasurer is at present.

Because of the Prime Minister's pilots dispute, the value of the tourist industry is down $3 billion. He has not revised the deficit figure to accept the fact that the wool clip is down $2 billion. The Wheat Board says that the value of the wheat crop is down $500m. Not one finger has been lifted by this Prime Minister or his Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to do anything about the ongoing live sheep dispute in the Middle East. That is another $200m. Beef exports will be down. The reality is that our exports will be down about $6 billion, and that will make the Treasurer's $18.5 billion estimate look very sick. The Government knows it but will not admit it. It will not admit it because it knows what it means for interest rates. While our exports go down, our interest rates go up, and so does our foreign debt.

We can look at the Treasurer's inflation forecasts. He stood up in here today and took the soft option and stood by his forecast, knowing in his heart that he was a mile out, a country mile away from reality. The Australian people know exactly how far wrong he is. They know it every time they go to the supermarket; they know it every time their household budget gets squeezed because of this Government's policies. Look at the adhockery of it. Look at the way in which the Government made the decision in relation to Coronation Hill. I am told that that decision was 14 to 2 in favour of mining. What happened? The undertakings given to Broken Hill Propriety Co. Ltd and the $12m that it was encouraged to spend on the environmental impact study went out the window. That came hard on the heels of $60m to prop up the Prime Minister's fortunes in his own electorate, the so-called safe seat of Wills.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not exactly safe.
—It is now. It is right now. The honourable member knows the spin-off effect.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Beazley interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The boundaries do not apply until the election. The honourable member should read the Electoral Act. A deal worth $200m was done with the banks to keep home interest rates down. But what about the poor Australians who borrow from building societies? What about them? Does the Government think that they do not vote Labor? That was treated with contempt in the electorate and it will cost the Government votes, not win votes for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we saw that absolutely disgraceful deal with the airlines. That is the standard of this Government. The list goes on and on. The reality is that it has no economic policies. Government members do not come in here and speak, they do not address the Parliament, because they have nothing to say. They say not a word in defence of the mess that they have made of this country; not an alternative policy prescription. They have nowhere else to go except back to the rhetoric and hope like hell that a big advertising campaign will save their bacon. Nothing will save this Government. It is destined to be tossed out. Whenever it names the day-and it is inevitable-it will be consigned to the political scrap heap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ladies and gentlemen, you have just heard the alternative Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Minister of the country. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt) have put forward their best effort at a parliamentary debate on the issue of the economy. These are the men who would be king and prince. These are the men who seriously invite you to place your economic future and your social future in their hands. This lacklustre high school debating team, which would make a better fist of it at any high school around this country, comes into this place, stung by the fact that they have been chided in the press and elsewhere for having the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) carry their economic debate in the course of this week, and try to present themselves as serious alternatives for governing this country in its hour of need. A high school debating team led recovery by the Liberal Party and the National Party is what we are being offered.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think we have ever heard from a Leader of the Opposition a more pathetic speech on the economy, certainly in my time in this Parliament. This place was dignified by the sorts of contributions that were made by people such as Bill Hayden when he was Leader of the Opposition. It was also dignified by the types of contributions made by the previous Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), when he debated economic matters in this place. He portrayed some understanding, and more than a little understanding, of exactly what it was he was dealing with and what he was asking the country to believe. What we got from the Leader of the Opposition was a melange of hyperbole. That is what we got from him-10 minutes of hyperbole on the economy. He says to people, `Trust us. Trust us to deliver on our promises. Trust us to deal with the problem of poverty when we are going to throw everyone who is on unemployment benefits onto the Smith Family. Trust us that we care about families. Trust us that we are the party of low taxation'.

What was the position when the Government came into office? The top taxation rate was 60c in the dollar. That is an example of the Liberals' low-taxing policy. Our top rate is now 13c under that. That was the Liberal Party's view of its credentials on low taxation. The Liberal Party comes in here and says, `We are the party of the family'. Tell that to the marines or, more particularly, tell that to the people who were thrown onto the dole queues by the Liberals in their last year of office when this country experienced record post-war unemployment. Who did the Liberal Party think they were-Mickey Mouse and Minnie Mouse? They were ordinary Australian families which were placed on the dole queue. This is the party that has produced a statement on families here and which, when invited to state whether or not it would support indexation of the family allowance benefit, as we have in our Budget, said, `No. we would not'. The Liberals know full well that that family allowance benefit, which goes very substantially not just to children in poverty but to ordinary wage earners, so high is its cut-out point, would be eroded in value by approximately 7 per cent per year unless indexation were to be supported.

This bunch of unbelievably generous people with their unfunded family tax cuts! In the last Budget, this Government's tax cuts to a family of two amounted to some $24.30 per week. What is the Liberal Party offering? That is our last Budget, our policy. What is the Liberal Party offering? It is offering $5.05. Well, bully for it-the great family party that can produce a tax cut which is approximately one-quarter or less than one-quarter of the size of the tax cut which, in this last Budget we brought down, went to families.

The Leader of the Opposition asks us, `Where is your policy?' Our policies are in place. The question is, `What is your policy?' That is the only relevant question that needs to be directed to the Opposition in this regard. We have tight fiscal policies. On the one hand, the Opposition says that it wishes to produce a situation in which there is going to be some renewed fiscal discipline. On the other hand, it says, and repeats it in here, that it wants to automatically hand back, unfunded by any cuts in outlays, bracket creep in taxation. This is fiscal discipline that will get us over our problems! It is fiscal discipline that consists of an unfunded hand-back of $2 1/2 billion! We are invited to believe that this is the Opposition that will take fiscal discipline seriously, if and when it gets into office-as if that is its point of discipline.

Those opposite then talk about poverty and children in poverty. What is the position of the Leader of the Opposition on the dependants of a person 10 months unemployed because of structural adjustments in a Wollongong steel mill or in one of the mines in central Queensland? What is the policy to support the family of that person if he is unable to get access to a training program and is unable to find employment? The Opposition's policy is to rely on the Smith Family. That is the position just adopted by the Opposition: The Smith Family will take care of them. Those opposite have the hide to come into this place and tell us that we are inadequate in our view on what we need to do to address the problem of children in poverty.

The fact of the matter-and the Liberals can run away from it, they can mouth off about it, lie and offer calumny about it as much as they like, but it nevertheless remains the case-is that our policies on family allowance supplement have been analysed by most of the social security organisations, including the Australian Council of Social Service, and including people such as Bishop Hollingworth, who say that these polices have massively increased the benefit for families in poverty and substantially increased the benefit to low and middle income families, who themselves are the beneficiaries of our $24 tax cut, as opposed to the Opposition's $5 tax cut-and that benefit is indexed-and those people have had the honesty to say that in so far as poverty is in itself a factor of income-of course, it is not the only factor but it is the factor that governments can most readily address-then this Government has addressed it. Even though they are lobby organisations wishing to assert that governments should do more, they have had the honesty to come into the public forum and say that the Government, through its family allowance supplement, through its taxation policies which benefit lower income earners, is addressing the area of real need. The Opposition is suggesting that the most unfortunate sections of the community should approach the Smith Family.

We can trust the Liberals to deliver on one thing in this so-called comprehensive statement, which conceded the commonsense of the Government's fiscal policy and which contained nothing about what the Opposition would do about wages and interest rates. What would this particular party do in this area? It would not continue our proposals on indexation. What could the community really trust it on? No indexation, and one other thing-delivering to its rich mates. The people of Australia can absolutely rely on the Liberals to make the benefit of their promise on the capital gains tax retrospective to 1985. Why? Because the President of the Liberal Party will be a $15m beneficiary of it. People can depend upon it that those people who will be putting money into the Liberal Party's campaign will be insisting and directing that whatever else is done, and nothing-because one cannot trust them-will be done on anything else, but whatever portion of that is implemented, whatever the state of interest rates, the economy or wages policy, it will be absolutely certain that the promise on the capital gains tax will be delivered with a vengeance. The long term future of the Liberal Party with its rich mates will depend upon its credibility in that regard.

That is a disgrace. Given the nature of the President of the Liberal Party, his situation in our society and his influence both in the election of the current Liberal leader and in his direction over current policy, it is a disgrace that such a personal benefit should be incorporated within Liberal Party policy in that retrospective way. Those opposite are a shameless pack of flannellers, and they will not be elected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I was wondering whether I could address a question to you, although I do not expect you to answer it at the moment. Could you examine the question of an alteration to yesterday's Hansard relating to Question Time? You will recall that I asked a question of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) about a former staff member of his and, in particular, his declarations of pecuniary interests. When speaking of his former staff member, the Minister for Administrative Services said in his answer:

SPEECH.PARA: He did not declare any pecuniary interest of this nature with regard to interests in this consultancy or any other consultancy. Those pecuniary interest forms were regularly updated. A copy of such a form, which was submitted by Mr Ross at a time not long before he resigned late in 1987 from my employment, was located and handed over or drawn to the attention of the Federal Police.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the expression `was located and handed over or drawn to the attention of the Federal Police'. That is my recollection of what was said, and I notice that those words are reported in the Canberra Times, for instance. However, when one looks at the transcript-the green, as it were-one finds that the words `handed over or' have been struck out and, indeed, the printed version of yesterday's Hansard records-without going over all the words again-that the Minister's proposition is that the return was located and drawn to the attention of the Federal Police. That means that the effect of that answer has been entirely altered. Whereas formerly it was said, amongst other things, that the return had actually been handed over to-namely, given to-the police, that phrase has been removed from the final edition of the Hansard.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I would be grateful, therefore, if you would investigate the matter and make some inquiries as to how the Hansard record of what was clearly said came to be altered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted the question of the honourable member for Menzies. I will seek a report from Hansard, and the Speaker will provide the honourable member with a reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, with regard to the matter the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) has raised, I am aware that when I was on my feet yesterday I said that a pecuniary interest declaration had been located and handed over-stop-drawn to the attention of the Federal Police. I did that because I knew that we had drawn their attention to it. As I was thinking while I was speaking, I did not totally recall handing it over to them. I have just been up to my office and questioned my senior staff. For the benefit of the Opposition they have confirmed that a copy has indeed been handed over to the Federal Police.
