Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purposes of this Bill are to amend the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 to implement decisions in the recent Budget on Commonwealth programs for schools in 1990 and to supplement for cost increases grants already appropriated for schools programs for 1989.

As foreshadowed in the Government's rural statement in April 1989, there are also changes to improve the educational access of rural students. This Bill provides for government and non-government organisations operating hostels providing accommodation for rural students to apply for funding under the general element of the capital grants program. It also provides for the establishment of a rural hostels program to provide assistance to such hostels with an initial allocation in 1990 of $1m. Eligibility under the new arrivals element of the English as a second language program is also being broadened. This Bill provides that students enrolling in the first formal year of primary school will be eligible for new arrivals funding where they arrived in Australia up to eighteen months previously. The Bill also amends the definition of full fee paying overseas students so that it applies to primary as well as secondary students.

The Bill appropriates an estimated $2,212m for schools programs in 1990, and provides for additional funds for 1989 programs in line with cost supplementation arrangements to bring total funding for 1989 programs to an estimated $2,055m. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act which provides funding for the 1989-91 triennium. The Bill provides funding for higher education institutions for 1992 amounting to $2,865m in accordance with the rolling triennial funding arrangements. It takes account of the Government decision to provide funding of $34m for an additional 4,000 intakes in 1992 and additional funding for capital projects in 1992 to bring the total annual funding for major works in 1992 to $198m. These measures honour the Government's commitment announced in the White Paper for the continued expansion of higher education to provide for a more highly skilled and educated Australian community.

These funds will allow the Government to make early decisions on new capital projects to commence in 1992 in order to facilitate the proper planning of these developments. Many of these capital projects will take into account mergers which have occurred, or are occurring, in many parts of the country. In relation to one of those mergers, that between the University of Western Australia and Murdoch University, I take the opportunity to announce a major new development which will become possible should the merger be given legislative effect. Agriculture is a vital area of study for Western Australia but the facilities at the Crawley campus have for some time been inadequate. The merger provides the opportunity for agriculture to be relocated to the Murdoch campus which already offers veterinary science as well as having developed a very strong capacity in the physical and biological sciences. This is one of the earliest examples of the advantages which can arise from mergers. To assist with the planning for this development the Government will fund the relocation of agriculture, currently estimated to cost $17m, commencing in 1992, and will also fund other capital projects consistent with the new university's priorities.

Increased funding is being provided for 1990 and 1991 amounting to some $13m in accordance with the Government's cost supplementation arrangements. The Bill also provides for the incorporation of Australian Research Council programs into the Act in line with the Government's decision to fund these programs on a rolling triennial basis. It includes additional amounts for new research initiatives of $150m over the 1990-92 triennium announced by the Government in its Science and Technology for Australia statement in May 1989. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Student Assistance Amendment Bill (No. 2) seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973, which provides the legislative basis for Austudy and the postgraduate awards scheme, to enhance the debt recovery regime for outstanding student assistance debts. It contains two main measures. First, it will extend the application of existing provisions of the Student Assistance Act relating to the prevention of fraud and the recovery of overpayments; the provisions concern matters such as garnishee action to recover debts incurred under the Act and the penalties for false statements in connection with applications made under the Act. The provisions will be extended to apply to the non-legislated student assistance schemes, namely the assistance for isolated children, Abstudy and Aboriginal overseas study award schemes. To further streamline processing debts under these schemes, action to waive or write off such debts will be taken under the Student Assistance Act, rather than by the exercise of a delegation under the Audit Act as is currently the case.

Secondly, the Bill provides that interest is to become payable on outstanding debts, whether incurred under Austudy or postgraduate awards or under one of the non-legislated schemes. Interest will commence three months after a debtor has been advised of the debt. However, provision is made for the Department to approve an interest-free period in cases of financial hardship, particularly where the debtor has come to an arrangement to repay the debt by instalments. The Bill would apply simple interest accruing on a daily basis. The regulations will specify a formula giving a commercially comparable rate of interest. The intention is that the recovery of student assistance debts should proceed in a manner comparable to normal commercial practice. This must include the application of a commercially comparable rate of interest so that debtors do not effectively have an interest-free loan from the public purse. Having said this, I should perhaps add that the introduction of an interest provision will affect only recalcitrant debtors who do not settle their debts or come to some arrangement with the Department within three months of having been advised of the debt.

The Bill will also enable ministerial guidelines to be set giving guidance in the exercise of various administrative powers under the Student Assistance Act. Action will be taken as soon as possible to set guidelines relating to the waiver, writing off and recovery by instalments of overpayments, and to the approval of interest-free periods. In view of the proposed guidelines, the Bill seeks to extend the range of officers to whom ministerial powers under the Act may be delegated.

A significant number of amendments have been made to the Student Assistance Act since its enactment over 16 years ago, and the Bill therefore proposes to renumber the Act so that all provisions will now be numbered sequentially. I have referred to the postgraduate awards scheme as coming under the Student Assistance Act. The Government is significantly improving the research component of this scheme by injecting more money and devolving the administration of research awards to individual institutions. As a result of the devolution, postgraduate research awards are ceasing to be administered under the Student Assistance Act.

I come now to the financial impact of the proposed measures. It is estimated that the Bill will result in increased debt recovery of approximately $5m over the two years 1990-91 and 1991-92. The effect may then lessen, reflecting the resolution of existing debts and the introduction of more effective fraud control. I would add that the significance of the interest provision is essentially as a deterrent. The actual amount to be collected by way of interest on outstanding debts is estimated to be of the order of $100,000 a year.

In conclusion, I would emphasise that the changes contained in this Bill are an integral part of an overall package of measures addressing the question of student assistance fraud. This package also includes front-end controls and other administrative measures. An important effect of the package will be an increased awareness of the Commonwealth's determination to address the problems of fraud and debt recovery in the area of student assistance. I present the explana-tory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Bill 1989 gives effect to the Government's Budget decision to endorse a national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy. The policy is a long term commitment towards the attainment of equity for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in access to, participation in and outcome from education.

The National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy is a concerted effort to address the educational needs of Aboriginal people, by cooperatively directing the strategies of the Commonwealth, the States and Territories, non-government education authorities and educational institutions, to achieving, firstly, involvement of Aboriginal people in educational decision-making; secondly, equality of access to educational services; and, thirdly, equitable and appropriate educational outcomes.

The purpose of the Bill is to enable the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to enter into bilateral agreements with State and Territory governments, higher education institutions, non-government school systems and other institutions over objectives, strategies, resources and joint monitoring arrangements consistent with the national policy. The Bill will provide a legislative basis for a consolidated program and funding approach that is supplementary to mainstream Commonwealth education funding through an Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program.

The Government has allocated a total of $266m as its commitment to the national policy over the next three years. Through standing appropriations, the Bill provides $236.3m of the above amount for Aboriginal education over the three-year period 1990-92. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and table the national policy. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the University of Canberra Bill is to establish a University of Canberra under the sponsorship of Monash University to replace the Canberra College of Advanced Education. Following the release in July 1988 of the White Paper which provided the blue-print for wide-ranging reforms in higher education, a steering committee chaired by the former Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, Mr Hudson, was established to advise on the amalgamation of the three Canberra higher education institutions. Acting on the recommendations of the steering committee, the Government introduced the Australian National University Bill 1988 into Parliament in November 1988. Subsequently, the Government agreed to a request from the incoming Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Government to defer consideration of the Bill to enable the new Assembly to provide advice on the structure of higher education in the Territory. A select committee of the ACT Assembly reported in July 1989 recommending that the amalgamation of the three institutions not proceed at this stage but that a University of Canberra be established to replace the Canberra College of Advanced Education.

The University will be established under the sponsorship of Monash University in accordance with an agreement between the two institutions. The report of the Task Force on Amalgamations in Higher Education chaired by the Chairman of the Higher Education Council, Dr Ramsey, released in April 1989, proposed that the sponsorship of former institutions in the advanced education sector by existing universities is an appropriate model for the development of these institutions as full members of the unified national system. Institutions in other States have adopted this model. The Government recognises that there is no single model that is applicable for achieving its objectives of a stronger and more viable higher education system. The establishment of the University of Canberra represents a positive step in the development of higher education in the ACT.

The agreement provides for the participation of Monash University in a wide range of activities undertaken by the new University. The sponsoring institution will be represented on the council and the academic board as well as on various committees of the University. Development of graduate programs and appointment of professional and equivalent staff will be subject to approval by Monash University during the sponsorship period. The two institutions will promote academic articulation across a range of activities, including student and staff exchanges, integrated professional awards, joint doctoral supervision and joint research projects. particular consideration will be given to the needs of the ACT community. The agreement will operate for an initial period of three years. It is envisaged that the sponsorship arrangements will be subject to external review at the end of this period. The funding for the University of Canberra will be assessed on the same basis as all higher education institutions. The Government will provide funding of $300,000 to Monash University over the next three years to contribute towards the costs incurred in the sponsorship arrangement. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The primary purpose of this Bill is to amend various Commonwealth Acts as a consequence of provisions of the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989-the Act which amends the Migration Act 1958 which is the principal Act. These consequential amendments are in addition to those matters included in schedule 6 of the Amendment Act. The Bill also makes a number of other minor amendments to the amendment Act. These amendments are made to the amendment Act rather than to the principal Act so as to avoid any difficulty which might otherwise arise with the operation of the renumbering provisions of the amendment Act. The amendments will commence immediately before the commencement of the amendment Act itself.

The majority of the amendments update terminology, make slight changes in wording or correct internal references within the amendment Act. It is inevitable in the case of legislation as complex as the amendment Act that some minor corrections will be necessary. Several amendments merit brief comment.

The Bill provides that regulations may be made that will prescribe matters to be considered in the making of decisions concerning discretionary deportation orders, the revocation of those orders and the requirement that an illegal entrant depart Australia. In addition, regulations may be made which specify procedures to be followed in determining the liability of an illegal entrant to mandatory deportation.

During the passage of the amendment Act concerns were expressed by the Opposition that it was possible under its provisions that a person recognised by Australia as a refugee could unintentionally be expelled by being deported or by being required to depart. I gave assurances that this would not be allowed to occur. To ensure that those legitimate concerns by the Opposition are put to rest and my assurances are kept, a provision is made for the procedures and the criteria for the exercise of the powers of expulsion to be prescribed in the regulations. The regulations will also reaffirm the essential feature of the amendment Act, namely the separation of processes of selection-that is, the grant of visas and entry permits-from the processes of expulsion; that is, the exercise of the powers of deportation and the requirement to depart.

The Bill also reinserts provisions allowing for regulations imposing fees for English language tests as previously provided for in the Migration Act. These provisions were previously inadvertently omitted. To further streamline passenger processing at airports, it is necessary to establish a regime whereby visas can be endorsed to recognise a person as being a person who without the endorsement would become an illegal entrant upon entry. Such persons are typically those who have been deported from Australia or another country, who are suffering from a prescribed disease or physical or mental condition, or who have been imprisoned for more than one year as a result of criminal convictions. Without this regime valuable resources are wasted in confirming the endorsement of the overseas post, and in the issuing of a specially endorsed entry permit which merely duplicates the information contained on the visa.

Another amendment is necessary as a result of the regulation drafting necessary to complement the amendment Act. To ensure the proper operation of the regulations relating to the points system, it is necessary to ensure the regulation making power is sufficiently broad. An amendment is also necessary to ensure that non-migrant visas can be issued over the counter upon application, and not be delayed by the general requirement to be imposed on pooled applications for migrant entry to notify of any material changes of circumstances since the time of application. Lastly, the Bill establishes that certain proof provisions apply in criminal deportation proceedings in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as well as in proceedings in a court or the Immigration Review Tribunal. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is pleased that the amendment we proposed to the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill has been accepted by the Government. We were concerned that the provisions in the Bill which provide the Reserve Bank of Australia with powers of investigation into the books, accounts and transactions of banks, and particularly its proposed ability to obtain information from a bank concerning individual customers where that is required for prudential supervisory purposes, did not safeguard the privacy of that information and the use of that information by Reserve Bank officials and others.

Firstly, it sought to address those privacy concerns at least to the extent that the Governor of the Reserve Bank will have to satisfy himself that information on an individual bank or an individual client of a bank is essential to the Reserve Bank fulfilling its obligations of prudential supervision. Secondly, we inserted a provision which would direct the Reserve Bank to include in its annual report details of the use of those investigative powers while protecting the identity of those who had been subject to investigation. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 October, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make particular reference to the tragic bus accident which occurred in my electorate last Friday. The whole of Australia has been shocked by this tragedy. Expressions of sympathy to the bereaved and expressions of hope to those who are still recovering from the accident and many other aspects that arise from that accident deserve some mention in this chamber. Tomorrow in Christ Church Cathedral, Grafton, there will be a memorial service to the deceased. That service has been arranged by the Ministers Fraternal representing the churches of the immediate vicinity. It will be a very solemn occasion, reflecting the feelings of the community in that area but, at the same time, will take into account the great concern of the wider community of Australia. I am sure that all members of the House would want to be aware of this service and would want to spare a thought for this rather solemn and sad occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate to refer to this tragedy during the debate on the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill because of the Bill's relationship to two issues that are uppermost in people's minds throughout Australia as a consequence of the worst bus accident yet to occur on Australian roads. I refer, of course, to the issue of road safety and to the issue of funding for the improvement and upgrading of Australia's road system. It is not perhaps the occasion to traverse the details of the reasons for the accident; suffice it to say that speed was involved and perhaps aspects touching very closely upon the issues of road safety.

I was present at the scene for a good deal of last Friday, and I observed much of the research that was done by a special investigation team from the New South Wales Police Department. I briefly mention the tremendous effort of the police, the State emergency services, the ambulance service, the hospitals, the rescue helicopter crews, the volunteers from many sections of the community and, of course, the concerned citizens who tried to assist at the scene of the horrific accident.

In this debate mention has already been made of road safety, road funding and road standards. The statistics show that the Pacific Highway is, unfortunately, the scene of far too many road accidents. The statistics show a growing incidence of road accidents involving semi-trailers and other heavy vehicles, such as passenger buses, as well as passenger vehicles. The level of road funding, the capacity of the State to contribute to road funding and the level of funding provided by the Federal Government undoubtedly must be of concern. The fall in the amount of funds provided by the Federal Government from fuel tax is a matter of very great concern to all of us.

In the last five years we have seen a fall in real dollar terms in the amount of funds provided by the Federal Government from fuel tax revenue. There has been about a 30 per cent fall. This figure is quite inadequate in view of the increasing usage of roads and the demands that are made upon the road system throughout Australia. I refer in particular to the demands placed on the Pacific Highway, which provides the link between Sydney and Brisbane and which, of course, attracts the heaviest volume of traffic. I appeal today to the Government to review the funds allocated for that specific purpose.

The New South Wales Government has taken some initiatives in this area since taking office. It has introduced a special fuel tax and has announced some allocations of funds for the Pacific Highway. But in the last allocation of funds announced by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) only a very small amount in real funds was provided for the upgrading of the Pacific Highway. My colleagues the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) and the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), through whose electorates the highway is located, have expressed concern at every opportunity about the paucity of Federal funding for roads being provided.

This afternoon I refer particularly to the section of the highway between Grafton and the Queensland border. The location of last week's road accident was at Cowper, just north of Grafton. In the vicinity of that section of the highway the general alignment of the highway is totally inadequate for the traffic volume. The last allocations of road funding were spread over a period of three years and were spent on major work near the Queensland border-a bypass, a bridge and some realignment. The allocation of a very small sum of money in the vicinity of the location of the recent road accident, north of Swan Creek near Grafton, enables the construction process to go ahead only at snail's pace.

I am sorry that the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, who was in the chamber earlier, is not here now, because I want to raise an issue to which I hope he will respond at the appropriate time. My question concerns the intention of the Government regarding further allocations of funding for roads in the current financial year for that section of the Pacific Highway. It is well known, and it has been thoroughly established, that there are inadequate passing lanes on the highway and that there is a very unsatisfactory road alignment. The highway is unable to carry safely the present traffic volume, in particular the heavy transports which are using that highway in increasing numbers, and buses which are using the highway in vastly increased numbers.

A positive plan is required. The Opposition has taken this matter seriously not only in recent weeks. Preceding the recent road accident the shadow Minister for land transport and shipping, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), visited that area and gave what I would regard as appropriate encouragement to the local government authorities, the councils and the State Government in the matter of road funding in the future. However, the present Government in its last Budget allocated an increase in road funding of only $120m over the previous year's figure for the whole of Australia. If one takes into account the prospects of that additional funding being in any way a figure that relates to need, one finds that we in this country are in very unfortunate circumstances in the matter of road funding.

At the same time, petrol taxation has increased from 6.155c per litre in 1983 to the astronomical figure of 23.15c. However, the share of that tax which is allocated to road funding has not increased in any commensurate proportion. The Government is taking a huge amount of revenue in the form of fuel tax and it is not returning an adequate amount to the road system. That is a tragedy for industry, for tourism and for the ordinary motorist who wishes to use the roads. It is a tragedy for every family which finds it necessary to use the road system and who venture onto the roads with trepidation, concerned about the risk of accidents.

At the beginning of my speech I alluded to the issue of road safety. It was at the advocacy of this Government that an increase in the speed limit for heavy vehicles from 90 to 100 kilometres an hour was introduced. I believe that that was a retrograde step. There was no identification of the roads upon which it was considered safe to travel at that speed. It is certainly not a safe speed at which to travel on the Pacific Highway. It is not a safe speed at which to travel on many of the arterial roads on which that speed is now permitted. I urge that there be a follow-up to the Minister's announcement of yesterday or earlier today that further consideration is being given by the Federal Government to the issue of speed limits, the introduction of the use of appropriate equipment, such as tachographs and speed control mechanisms on heavy vehicles, in order to try to minimise the carnage on our roads.

In conclusion, I say that this issue is of major concern to most Australians today. It is time that this Government reviewed the situation with appropriate concern. There is no doubt that the problem can be solved over time with an effective program of road upgrading and an effective approach to the needs of major roads such as the Pacific Highway. I urge that, under this particular provision of funding, account be taken of the limitations on the New South Wales State Government in attending to the very important issue to which I have referred.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: THERAPEUTIC GOODS BILL 1989[COGNATE BILL:THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 October, on motion by Mr Staples:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 concurrently with the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 is to create a national system of control over the manufacture, evaluation and marketing of therapeutic goods and devices for both export and domestic consumption. The accompanying piece of legislation, the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1989, relates to the application of a range of fees and charges for the registration and evaluation of therapeutic goods and devices, and for the licensing of manufacturers and inspections under codes of good manufacturing practice. For the purposes of this package of legislation, the definition of `therapeutic goods' is a very wide one and includes prescription and non-prescription medications, vitamin, mineral and dietary supplements, herbal and homoeopathic preparations, as well as medical devices.

SPEECH.PARA: The major parts of the Therapeutic Goods Bill relate to the determination of standards for therapeutic goods, the establishment of an Australian register of therapeutic goods approved for import, export or supply, and the licensing of Australian manufacturers of therapeutic goods. The proposed date of commencement of the legislation is 1 March 1990 with fees and charges to be collected from 1 July 1990.

In principle, both the Opposition and the therapeutic goods industry support the broad objectives of the Therapeutic Goods Bill. There are a number of obvious advantages to the community and the therapeutic goods industry in having a unified system of controls over therapeutic products and their advertising. There is no argument about the value of ensuring the quality, safety and efficacy of therapeutic goods and the need to protect the public interest in this regard.

All of us in this House, even the youngest of us, are old enough to know about the havoc wrought by thalidomide, for example. On the other hand, the Opposition shares a range of concerns expressed by the industry in relation to the Bills and the regulations which will underpin them. These matters include: doubts as to whether a national system of controls is achievable in this way; whether the Government's proposals contain adequate checks, balances and avenues of appeal; whether the codes of good manufacturing practice are excessive and unreasonable on a benefit to risk basis; the damage which may be done to the manufacturing and export industry by the proposed fees and charges; and finally the fact that the whole structure is to be underpinned by regulations which have not yet been finalised let alone made available to the Parliament.

It is for reasons such as these that the Opposition has resolved that it will oppose the legislation despite the fact that the Bills themselves are fairly innocuous. The Therapeutic Goods Bill amounts to a motherhood statement. The accompanying regulations, which have not been made available to the Parliament, will be the vehicle for carrying the real thrust of the Government's intent. From our point of view the Government has got things around the wrong way. Normally regulations are attendant upon legislation and serve to tidy up administrative loose ends and plug the odd gap here or there. In this case, however, the legislation is being used as little more than an enabling tool which paves the way for the Government to bring in the big guns by way of regulation. We simply cannot be expected to accept bland enabling legislation, thereby signing what amounts effectively to a blank cheque.

It seems that the Government, at least in the health area, has learnt nothing from its experience with the vocational register for general practitioners which the Parliament refused to accept without first having an opportunity to consider the relevant regulations. The same situation exists here, which is why we intend to move in the Senate for the legislation and regulations to be referred at the same time to the legislative and general purpose Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. In the event that this move is unsuccessful we will look to amendments and to the possible disallowance of the regulations if we find them unsatisfactory when finally we get them.

The impact of the Government's proposals on the future of the therapeutic goods industry is something which must not be underestimated or ignored. This industry is an increasingly important part of Australia's overall manufacturing and export effort. The significance of just one part of it is underscored in comments by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in a foreword to the 1988 Austrade document on the Australian scientific and medical device industry. Senator Button said:

As an industry sector you typify the new direction manufacturing must take, in that you are technology and skill based; there is a high level of investment in research and development; you exhibit a real entrepreneurial flair; exports represent a high proportion of output. In addition, you are establishing for Australia a particularly high reputation for quality and reliability for these technically sophisticated products. This is at a time when it is essential that the country lifts its whole image abroad if we are to make real headway in achieving a quantum leap in exports of high value added manufactures and related services.

That is how Senator Button sees the industry. The danger is, however, that these proposals, presented to the House by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) could serve to undermine the very achievements so warmly applauded by Senator Button.

Let me deal with the first broad area of concern-whether a national system of registration and control is attainable in the way the Government now proposes. The Government intends to draw upon broad heads of power under the Constitution, including the corporations power, to create a national system. Clearly, unless all the States and Territories cooperate, the proposed system for the national registration of therapeutic goods will be unworkable. The Victorian Government has apparently indicated that it is willing to look at repealing its own system of registration but will not do so until the spring 1990 parliamentary session. This means that if the national system embodied in this legislation comes into effect in March 1990, as the Commonwealth intends, there will be dual registration in Victoria for quite some time. This has grave consequences for the industry, which wants a guarantee that the system will be implemented on a truly national basis.
The Minister for Housing and Aged Care, in his second reading speech, said:
It is expected that the States and Territories will implement complementary legislation . . . Model legislation will be presented to the States and Territories which would effect this.

I hope that at the conclusion of this debate the Minister will be able to inform the House what progress is being made with regard to complementary State legislation. This is important as there are good grounds for arguing that Victoria should repeal its legislation and all States and Territories should have complementary legislation in place when this Bill comes into effect.

I turn now to the subject of whether or not the legislation contains adequate checks, balances and avenues of appeal. As I have said, the legislation provides for the application of corporations powers by the Commonwealth to replace existing State and Territory jurisdictions, and in principle neither the Opposition nor the industry objects to this.

There are concerns, though, that the Commonwealth powers are so far-reaching that without suitable controls and public accountability the industry may be left with virtually no say in the running of its own businesses. For example, it is the Commonwealth's intention that the recommendations of the Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) should be adopted as the poisons standard. In effect, this will give the NHMRC recommendations the force of law.

While the NHMRC is an extremely important body carrying out an extensive range of highly respected activities, it must be recognised that it exists pursuant to an Order in Council. In this context, the industry has expressed serious concerns about its lack of public accountability. In addition, the industry does not consider the NHMRC to be representative of its particular interests, industry itself having no representative on that body.

At the present time, industry has input into and representation on State poisons advisory committees, but bodies such as this will be disbanded with the implementation of the proposed national therapeutic goods system. There are, therefore, good grounds for concern that the adoption of the NHMRC recommendations will deny the industry formal representation on poisons scheduling decisions and deprive it of any effective avenue of appeal.

Also on the subject of appeals, clause 60 of the Therapeutic Goods Bill provides for decisions made under the Bill to be reviewed by the Minister and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. There are two things to say about this. First, clause 60, subsection 5 requires the Minister to give applicants written notice of the outcome of his reconsideration of a decision, but does not require him to provide a statement of reasons for that decision unless requested to do so by the applicant.

This hardly seems fair or reasonable. One would think that it would be sound commonsense and administratively more efficient to provide the reasons for the decision along with that decision rather than simply advise people that they should make a further application if they want to find out why their first one was unsuccessful.

But leaving that aside, the second appeals issue relates to the role of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The industry believes that, in view of the technical nature of matters arising from a request for a review of a decision on a product, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is an inappropriate body to hear such appeals. An appeals body which includes industry representatives is the industry's preferred alternative.

I turn now to the matter of regulation and control. What is at issue here is whether the existing control mechanisms are efficient and whether their proposed intensification is warranted. This matter was addressed by the Business Regulation Review Unit (BRRU) in its Information Paper No. 13 of March 1989 entitled Therapeutic Goods Regulation. On page iii of this document the BRRU said:

Efficiency requires a balancing of risks of harm from a treatment against other risks resulting from delays or denials of access to more effective treatment and factoring in regulatory costs involved. Any controls exercised by the authorities must be capable of achieving the objective sought. It is observed that a number of long standing difficulties in the management of the therapeutic goods program remain. The increased regulation proposed, particularly surveillance of a wider range of goods, may exacerbate rather than resolve these problems by reversing recent moves towards more risk related approaches.

These views expressed by the BRRU are mirrored in the numerous submissions that I have received as the shadow Minister for health from individual companies and groups around the country within the therapeutic goods industry. Based on the current and past performance of the therapeutic goods program of the Department of Community Services and Health there are clear grounds for questioning the Department's ability to deliver the promised improvements in the evaluation and regulatory process.

In fact the BRRU concluded that the intensification of controls proposed by the Government are not, in the main, warranted and that its charging proposals are excessive, particularly with regard to products having well known features and risks. In fact, the excessive nature of the Government's proposed controls is amply demonstrated in relation to the Code of Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP). The Minister for Housing and Aged Care, in his second reading speech, said:

The Bill provides a standard of regulation that is recognised internationally as being necessary to control therapeutic goods and which will bring Australia into line with levels of product assurances exercised and required by its major trading partners.

The point which is relevant here is that while the industry and Opposition support the principle of high manufacturing standards, the Government's proposed revision of the Code of Good Manufacturing Practice is not merely, as the Minister would have it, `in line with that of our major trading partners'. The industry says that it is, in fact, in excess of the GMP specified in the United Kingdom and the European Economic Community (EEC) and represents excessive, unreasonable and unattainable criteria for manufacturing practice which cannot be justified on a benefit to risk basis. If the Government is committed to bringing manufacturing practices in this country into line with international standards, why does it not adopt the EEC code?

Finally now, and perhaps most importantly, I turn to the issue of the proposed fees and charges for registration, listing, evaluation, licensing and inspection. The Government has scaled down its intention to squeeze the industry for the full cost of the therapeutic goods program. Initially, at least, it will be endeavouring to recover just half that sum, which at present amounts to some $15m per annum. Of course, there are no guarantees-none that I have heard of-that it will not hike this figure up at the first available opportunity. But even at the 50 per cent recovery level these fees and charges have the capacity to devastate an industry which the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology acknowledges as being essential to Australia's efforts to `make real headway in achieving a quantum leap in exports of high value added manufactures'.

We in the Opposition do not have the detail of the charges which, like so much else of this proposal, remains unresolved, but we do know that on 10 October last Senate Estimates Committee F was given an indicative range of charges. These included: $50 a year for listing a product on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods; annual registration fees of about $350 for a prescription drug and $150 for an over-the-counter medication; evaluation charges of between $700 and $52,500; manufacturing licences costing between $800 and $8,300; and inspection fees ranging from $600 to $4,000.

What is clear from all of this is that the fees will have a marked impact on the industry with costs inevitably flowing on to consumers. As my colleague Senator Peter Baume so aptly put it in the Senate, `it ends up as a tax on the users of therapeutic goods'. Not only will there be an impact on consumers, but also it is important to understand, especially in the light of Senator Button's very considered comments and appreciation of the importance of this industry, that the industry's international competitiveness will be under attack.

Let me use the example of just one part of the industry, that sector involved in manufacturing medical devices. At this stage it is only a fledgling industry in this country consisting of about 600 firms, most of them relatively small-extremely small, one might say-with an annual turnover of less than $3 billion. But, despite its lack of size, this industry and the companies within it collectively have an annual turnover of $3m. Their local production exceeds $1 billion, and their exports are valued at over $300m.

It is an industry which is strongly export oriented and already a success on the world scene. About one-third of its local production is exported, compared with 15 per cent for manufacturing industry as a whole, and there are some of these companies exporting more than 90 per cent of their production. I visited a number of them. In fact, medical devices currently represent more than 5 per cent of Australia's total manufacturing exports.

In just five years from 1981-82 to 1986-87 exports from this burgeoning industry grew from $170m to $317m. It is a success story that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, certainly understands, as does the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. These achievements, plus the potential for future development, are in jeopardy because of the Government's moves to impose charges on the industry to fund the operation of one part of the Department of Community Services and Health. This industry is looking at being severely, if not irreparably, damaged and having its international competitiveness destroyed. When I visited one factory recently, the principals clearly stated that it would now be cheaper for them to go offshore and manufacture in Malaysia, for example, but they and their employees preferred living in Australia, with all of its attendant benefits. With the imposition of a range of charges, the likes of which we have heard in the Senate Estimates Committee, the competitive position of companies in the medical devices industry will be severely affected.

In short, the Government's therapeutic goods fees and charges run completely counter to other initiatives it has taken through Austrade and the National Industry Extension Service, for example, to encourage innovation, research and development and export enhancement. All of this investment of taxpayers' funds could be wiped out by the imposition of fees and charges, which have the capacity to restrict research and development; cripple a growing export earning industry; inhibit the establishment of new companies; deny the community the benefits of new, innovative products; and, importantly, destroy potential job creation.

Interestingly, we do not come into this debate without any international experience. All of these dangers have been recognised by the United States Government, which from time to time has flirted with the idea of imposing charges on the therapeutic goods industry through its Food and Drug Administration. Arguments which have been accepted by the United States administration include the following: that product evaluation is for public benefit, not for the private benefit of the manufacturing company, and should therefore be financed from general taxation revenue, not through specific fees and charges levied on industry; that a user fee on a regulated industry is in effect a tax on research and development since it is the cost of bringing a new product into the marketplace; and, finally, that user fees would be particularly burdensome to small high technology firms, many of which do not earn sufficient revenues to support such impending costs.

All of these arguments are equally valid in the Australian context. If they are ignored, then, as I have already said, much of the work which various arms of government have undertaken to try to boost research and development, to foster new and innovative industries and to develop export markets will, in the final analysis, amount to a completely wasted effort. I give just one small example, a small company in my home State of Western Australia, Go Medical Industries, named aptly because of the innovative spirit of its founders and the people who work within it. It has been in operation since 1982 and employs a staff of 10, developing innovative products that have found a place on the world market. More than 90 per cent of its output, 90 per cent of all it produces, is exported to the United States of America, New Zealand, Italy, Canada, Singapore and other scattered countries. It is the sort of success story that Australia desperately needs when we consider the monthly balance of payments current account figures and the month by month growing international debt. This is one of the hundreds of small Australian companies which could be driven to the wall by these therapeutic goods proposals.

In conclusion, the Opposition is not prepared to stand idly by and see the therapeutic goods industry destroyed by an ill considered Government proposal. We want the whole package-I repeat, the whole package, not less than half of the package, because we are dealing with pretty innocuous legislation this afternoon-thoroughly examined. The real thrust is contained in the regulations, which we have not yet seen and I understand perhaps are not even finalised in the drafting. We want the whole package-the legislation and the regulations-thoroughly examined so that due regard can be paid to the concerns which I have raised here and the numerous other ones brought forward by all sectors of the industry.

We hope all members of the Government, not just the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, will recognise the significance of the therapeutic goods industry. We hope that all members of the Government will appreciate the tremendous contribution this industry is making to the national economy and the Australian community. More importantly for our country's future, we hope that they appreciate the enormous contributions it can go on to double, treble and quadruple, if properly supported and properly fostered in the way that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce recognises is absolutely crucial.

I hope that successive Government speakers-and there are several, to be followed intermittently by Opposition speakers-will appreciate that we come to this debate devoid of what we continually experience in this chamber: party politics. We have raised a number of serious concerns, all of which are amply evidenced and given voice to by the industry. We could have moved an in principle amendment in this chamber, but we did not. We could have moved an amendment that the Government withdraw the Bill and itself refer it to the appropriate Senate Committee that I mentioned in my remarks; but we did not. I recognise that at such short notice the Government is unlikely to agree with our position. So we will not be moving any amendments to this legislation this afternoon. Despite the opposition that I have expressed, neither will we be dividing on this legislation. The cruel reality, as we all understand, is that every time we put up a proposition that the Government does not support we lose. I do not even want to take that course on a pro forma basis because I underscore the bona fides with which we come into this debate.

I clearly foreshadow that in the Senate we will refer this legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. We believe it is the most appropriate committee to examine these proposals from an industry point of view. We do not believe that sufficient consultation has taken place with industry, let alone the States. By referring it to the Senate Committee we will be providing that opportunity. It does not disturb the Government's timetable because the Bill will not come into effect, even if passed, until March 1990. The charges will not come into effect, even if the Bill is passed, until July 1990. If we are successful in referring the legislation to the Committee-that, of course, depends on the support or otherwise of the Australian Democrats-we will be demanding, and that is not too strong a word, the tabling of the regulations. It is unreasonable to expect the Opposition, indeed any opposition, to pass legislation of this kind without the all important regulations. As I close my contribution, I hope the Government will support the referral of this proposal to the Senate Committee on Industry, Science and Technology so that all relevant matters I have raised this afternoon and others that can be put by industry can be fully considered and adequately addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am nonplussed and deeply distressed by the contribution on this issue of the shadow Minister for employment, training and youth affairs, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). I was prepared for an apolitical debate, a debate that would unite both sides of this chamber in combating a major threat to public health. I do not believe that the shadow Minister, representing the Opposition, would come into this chamber today and oppose legislation which he himself described as innocuous and which clearly is warranted in the national interest. It is a brave and foolish government that ignores reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. It is also a brave and foolish opposition that ignores reports of the Public Accounts Committee.

—I should like to ask the honourable member for Hughes whether I could be bold enough to interrupt him to request that he seek leave to continue his remarks later, so that I may make a short statement.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES: STAFF MEMBER

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this afternoon the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) asked for an investigation of why some words which he said were used by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) in answering a question yesterday do not appear in the Daily Hansard. The Principal Parliamentary Reporter has listened to the tape and advised me that the words actually used by the Minister were `was located and handed over or or drawn to the attention of the Federal Police'. The Hansard reporter transcribed the words `handed over or', but they were deleted by the Hansard supervisor on the basis that, in using the words `or or', the Minister was correcting himself. So the alteration was made by the Hansard staff, not by or at the request of the Minister or his office.

DEBATE.TITLE: THERAPEUTIC GOODS BILL 1989[COGNATE BILL:THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to initiate my remarks on this very important legislation by drawing the attention of the Opposition to one very simple fact-namely, that two prominent members of its front bench are on the public record as being flatly and diametrically opposed to the views that have just been expressed by the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). In common with me, those two members, namely Senator Bishop and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), were members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry into therapeutic goods, which amassed six volumes of evidence and which formed a damning indictment on the control by successive Australian governments of the introduction of new drugs and medical devices to the Australian market. It is clear that the shadow Minister for health has not read one bit of that evidence, let alone the unanimous recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which called for national legislation as a matter of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not as if national legislation on the subject of drugs and medical devices is such an earth-shattering proposition. Every comparable civilised democracy already has that form of legislation. Australia is so far behind the times that, rather than-as the shadow Minister suggested-this legislation being a risk to exports, the brutal reality is that our international reputation is tarnished for every minute that this legislation fails to be passed in this Parliament.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry into therapeutic goods was conducted in an honourable manner with the bipartisan support of all members of the Committee, to whom I pay tribute for their work. Let me relate some of the findings of the Committee. First, because there was an absence of national legislation, there was an inability to ensure an enforceable national standard of good manufacturing practice, the overriding purpose of which is quality control. I say to the people of Australia: what the shadow Minister for health has done by speaking in this chamber today is to say that he does not agree with Senator Bishop; he does not agree with the honourable member for Dundas; he does not agree with the Public Accounts Committee; he does not agree with what the industry said over about a year of public hearings; and he does not agree with what the consumers' representatives say. The shadow Minister for health says that there is no need for national legislation in the form in which it is proposed.

Secondly, the Committee found that the licensing of manufacturers, which is currently a state responsibility, with varying standards, in some cases precluded the power to close down substandard and unsafe premises. Let me tell honourable members what happened during the course of evidence before the Committee. A representative of a South Australian department appeared before the Committee and was asked what would happen if an attempt was made to close down manufacturers. It was found, in effect, that once a manufacturer in South Australia obtains a licence, he holds that licence for life and it literally cannot be revoked. Believe it or not, that meant that the Government of South Australia had no power to close down premises where unsafe practices were operating.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was scandalous.

—It is just scandalous. Thirdly, the Committee found, unanimously-and it included two front bench members of the Opposition-that no requirement existed to evaluate any Australian made medical device prior to sale and use in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Fourthly, the Committee found that no control existed over the importation into Australia of the vast majority of medical devices, with the result that some devices that are banned overseas can be imported legally into Australia without any inquiry. I repeat that: under the current law, it is legally possible to import into Australia medical devices that have been banned overseas. That is intolerable. It is totally unacceptable that consumers in this country are placed at risk by the utterances in this House today of the shadow Minister for health. People forget the campaign against and the misery and the injuries that were caused to people in this country by the Dalkon shield. People forget the campaign that had to be waged to get government action on that device. People forget so easily what happened in the case of the thalidomide tragedy. This national legislation is all about making sure that those tragedies never recur.

Fifthly, the Committee found further that there was no evaluation of the majority of diagnostic products. The Committee was concerned to hear in evidence that one-third of the manufacturers of therapeutic goods in Australia had not complied with the International Code of Good Manufacturing Practice and that a significant number of deficiencies of a major or critical nature had been identified over a number of years. I should explain in more detail just what that means. I repeat that one-third of the manufacturers of therapeutic goods in Australia did not comply with the Code of Good Manufacturing Practice. That information was provided in evidence on oath by Commonwealth officials. In evidence, officials of the Department of Community Services and Health defined an unacceptable standard of manufacture as:

a grossly deficient standard of general compliance which includes a large number of minor and major deficiencies, and possibly some critical deficiencies, observed to persist over successive . . . inspections . . .
It is a repeated practice that involves serious matters. They went on to say:
the critical deficiency would be one that would or could cause harm to patients and a major deficiency would be one with the potential to cause harm indirectly to patients.

For the benefit of those people who are interested to learn what sorts of things we are talking about when we talk about breaches of the Code of Good Manufacturing Practice. I point out that in evidence before the Committee, Commonwealth officials provided the Committee with a dossier of the breaches of the Code of Good Manufacturing Practice. (Quorum formed)

This debate is about whether or not the shadow Minister for health is going to come into the chamber and protect public health, and whether or not the Opposition is going to undermine the attempts of this Government to support the unanimous recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee and the call by consumers and the industry in this country to have national legislation. We have heard from the shadow Minister in the course of this debate, with respect, a pathetic effort to defend the Opposition's position. I have made the point in the course of my contribution that there is an internationally accepted Code of Good Manufacturing Practice for drugs and medical devices. That code involves vital issues of public health, and before the Opposition called the quorum in order to deprive me of speaking time I was going to highlight to the House just what breaches of that code have been revealed.

Before I do that, I repeat that one-third of the manufacturers of therapeutic goods in this country have been found not to comply with the international code. Let me take a couple of examples. In sworn evidence given to the Public Accounts Committee, and accepted by the two Opposition front bench members on the Committee, we heard of three cases of breaches involving companies in South Australia. The first was a manufacturer of tablets, capsules, liquids and creams which had demonstrated poor compliance with the international code and persistent deficiencies-including, I might add, critical deficiencies-since 1981. So for seven years it had breached the code but under the law of South Australia the premises could not be closed down. We heard the example of a manufacturer of tablets, capsules, liquids and creams which had been involved in persistent deficiencies, including several critical deficiencies, since at least 1980. So for eight years it had failed to comply with the code, the public had been put at risk, and under the State law the premises could not be closed down.

This is not an attack by me on the industry; it is a defence by me of reputable manufacturers. It is an attack on the minority of manufacturers, though a significant number, who breach the code, who put the public at risk and who, if this Government has its way, will be put out of business.

I turn to the other example, involving a manufacturer in Western Australia, where the shadow Minister comes from. We heard his example of what is happened in Western Australia, but let me tell him of sworn evidence of the Department of Community Services and Health before the Public Accounts Committee. The evidence was not rebutted by the State Government. We heard of a manufacturer of liquid creams which had shown very poor compliance with the code and persistent and major critical deficiencies since 1980. So for eight years no effective action had been taken. Then we heard about a company described as company 40, which was described as having a total absence of compliance with the Code of Good Manufacturing Practice, with many major and critical deficiencies. Remember that major and critical deficiencies are the grave ones involving issues of public health. This is a case in the State of the shadow Minister for health, who would purport to be protecting one day the public of Australia. In the course of our Public Accounts Committee inquiry we tried to find out more about this company that was in such violation of the standards that the community should expect ought to be followed. I asked a witness before the Committee whether in fact it was a sole person operating and running his own business, and the witness said that that was correct. I asked:
In suburban Perth?
The witness answered:
Yes.
I asked:
In a backyard?
The witness answered:
Yes.

So we had a company totally failing to comply with the internationally accepted code, placing the public at risk and operating out of a suburban backyard. That is the situation that the shadow Minister for health came into this chamber today to defend. If honourable members believe that there is something innovative about national legislation, let me tell them that it was first thought of and first proposed during the time of the Menzies Government, right back in the mid-1960s-and still we do not have national legislation. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) is to be commended for bringing this legislation before the House promptly, in accordance with the unanimous views of the Public Accounts Committee, including the views of Senator Bishop and the honourable member for Dundas.

There are some other matters that are unlikely to be touched on in detail in the course of this debate, but honourable members might like to hear from me-I happen to have read the six volumes of evidence and happen to know what he is talking about, unlike the shadow Minister-what the practice has been in a number of State governments. Under the international code for the issue of certificates, only the national government has the authority to issue certificates. The certificates have come into existence so they can be used as documents of credibility on the international marketplace, so that reputable Australian manufacturers can take their certificates into the international marketplace and be recognised, sell their goods, assist people in overseas countries and make a dollar for Australia.

Let me tell the House what the Public Accounts Committee uncovered in the course of its investigations. We found that a number of State governments-including both Government and Opposition controlled State governments-were issuing bodgie, shonky certificates which gave every appearance of certifying that companies were complying with the internationally accepted code. We heard evidence from people on oath that made it very clear that those certificates, issued by State governments, had been issued to companies in total violation of that internationally accepted code.

I did not come into this chamber to play party politics. Until I spoke to the shadow Minister I believed that the Opposition was supporting the legislation. I find it inconceivable that any Opposition spokesman, particularly in such a crucial area as health, could possibly fail to support the bipartisan report of the Public Accounts Committee especially when two of his shadow Ministers voted, as part of a unanimous decision, to support that document.

I think the Opposition ought to rethink its position because by taking the stand that it is taking in relation to the current legislation, which the shadow Minister in his own words described as unobjectionable, it is placing the people of Australia at risk because of that minority of shonky manufacturers. The Opposition's stand is not in the interests of consumers, it is not in the interests of the industry and it is one, with respect, that will bring great discredit and embarrassment to the Opposition. If the legislation is unobjectionable, as the shadow Minister said, it ought not to be referred to any committee of the Senate. It ought to be passed. If there is some problem with respect to fees-I believe that there is none, and I assume the shadow Minister will deal with that-let us deal with that and the question of regulations when they have to be implemented. Let us not try to stop social progress; let us not fly in the face of the unanimous recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee.

It is with great pride that I commend the legislation to the House. I commend the Minister because he has acted on those unanimous recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee and he is doing his best to protect the people of Australia from those backyard operators that operate out of the shadow Minister's own state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only guess that the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) either misheard or misunderstood the words of my colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). I am loath to come to the conclusion that he misrepresented the honourable member for Tangney in his reaction because, having known him for some time, I know that he certainly does not have a history which would lead me to want to come to that conclusion. The honourable member for Tangney has said that he would like-and we so propose-the therapeutic goods legislation to be referred to a Senate committee; that is not opposing the legislation. The honourable member for Tangney gave the Opposition's reasons for this. Whilst it might be open to honourable members opposite to contest those remarks, that was not a course that the honourable member for Hughes chose to pursue. It seems to me-I say this with all the respect that I can-that much of what the honourable member for Hughes had to say concerned the findings in an earlier report of a very formidable committee of this Parliament, one which the honourable member chairs. He then took it one step further and interpreted as a personal slight on him the fact that somehow the Opposition might want to do something different or to be a little more cautious in its approach to this legislation than is the honourable member for Hughes and his Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not that this Bill is so urgent in the sense that its provisions are not intended to apply until March 1990. There is not great panic. When the honourable member for Hughes resorted to arguing the urgency of the measure, he obviously was not aware of that fact or he chose to ignore it. It seems that as this Government gets older and more tired, its new, perhaps enthusiastic, members of the Ministry, dream up harebrained schemes without the prudence and restraint which more experienced Ministers in the Government once provided.

This legislation, along with the Privacy Amendment Bill which is before the Senate, is typical of that failing. It is yet another example of the Government and its approach to regulations gone mad. The desire of the Federal Labor Government to regulate or control industry whenever the opportunity presents itself continues unabated. However, it is not the overall scheme of national regulation which has led to the grave concerns of businesses in the therapeutic goods industries, but a system of charges to fund the new legislation which appears to be both inequitable and irrational.

In establishing the national system of regulation, the Bills go too far in imposing new burdens on businesses which are, in some respects, more onerous than the regulatory burdens faced by their competitors for overseas markets. Such difficulties as the broad definition of therapeutic goods which will require licensing do not appear to have been adequately addressed by the Government in developing the legislation. The regulatory burden which the legislation will facilitate is not wholly apparent from the legislation. We are to be presented with a whole host of regulations after the legislation has been passed by the Parliament; that is, whilst a procedure, a method, a device which is being employed increasingly by this Government is arguably unwise.

A greater part of the burden will be imposed by the regulatory powers conferred on the agencies of the Department of Community Services and Health and the standards which they choose to establish. The nature of the regulatory regime, which will be faced by the industry if the Bill passes through the Parliament, is further confused by the inability of the Federal Government to properly establish agreement with the the States about the operation of the legislation and the timing of its introduction. The Victorian Government has already made it clear that it will continue to administer State legislation in this area until well into the time when the Federal legislation is scheduled to have effect. The uncertainty that ensues represents an intolerable burden on those manufacturers and importers who will have no idea what regulations and standards might apply to their products, and how long those standards will apply. It will lead to delays in the introduction of new products and even the improvement of older products which might be well established in the marketplace. In the end, it is the consumers seeking some form of therapy or treatment who will suffer from the uncertainty which these Bills will create when enacted.

The system of regulation to be introduced is, perhaps, as comprehensive as for any other industry. In that respect, the legislation is an unusual application of the Federal corporations power which backs up its provisions. The detailed operation of most industries is regulated at the State Government level. These Bills propose the licensing of manufacturers, the regulation or listing of their products and inspection of premises to ensure conformity to Federal regulations. Licences can be granted on a conditional basis and can be revoked or suspended on a number of different grounds. None of these powers is usually exercised by the Federal Government. To that extent, this legislation is a significant indicator of the direction which the Labor Government is taking with the regulation of Australian businesses.

The Government seeks to establish the power to regulate the minute details of the production of the enormous range of products to be defined as therapeutic goods. Surely this must be considered an ominous prospect by those in business who will soon have to cope with the introduction of the Commonwealth package of companies legislation. That legislation is currently being challenged in the High Court. However, it also has the potential to alter significantly the nature of the regulation of business in this country and the role of the States in the Commonwealth. Not only would the States be removed from another area which in the past had been their responsibility, but also the area of licensing, which traditionally and constitutionally has been a major source of income to the States, will have been gradually impinged upon by the Labor Government. While I do not believe that regulation by the States is necessarily a good thing-indeed, the States are responsible for part of the massive Government burden on business-the imposition of further regulation and expense by the Commonwealth threatens a new and less responsive power to which companies must be accountable.

There is no evidence to suggest that Commonwealth legislation will be less onerous than that of the States. In time, it is likely to be more so if recent experience under this Government is any criterion. Uniformity-the most common justification for Federal regulation and the reasons which appeal to most Australian businesses-must be discounted as a value when it is remembered that the checks on the growth of that regulation are much less and the potential for avoiding over-regulation is much less than under an effective Federal system. There is some indication that this legislation owes more to an exercise in empire building by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and his Department than a genuine desire to improve the regulatory environment of the therapeutic goods industry.

One of the more significant criticisms of this legislation by industry is that products which have been extensively investigated by well-resourced and thorough agencies in other countries, such as the United States Food and Drug Administration, must go through the same procedures again in Australia. This is despite the fact that the details of the earlier investigations by other agencies are readily available and open to independent validation by Australian authorities, but in a procedure which might be significantly shorter than the full investigation from scratch.

Australian regulatory procedures are renowned for their slow approval of new drugs and other medical products. The problems which this presents for medical practitioners trying to treat patients with the most modern means available are obvious. It is essential that these existing regulatory delays are alleviated. However, this legislation imposes new regulations, new procedures, new charges and an increased burden. This burden will hold back both the development of the Australian therapeutic goods industry and the supply of the most recent forms of medication and treatment to Australians. These regulatory effects will be compounded by the system of fees which will be imposed under the new Commonwealth regulatory scheme. The Government claims that the fees imposed in this package of legislation will only recover half of the costs of the new scheme.

In a strange twist of logic, this Government has repeatedly imposed what it characterises as a user pays system of payments for government imposed regulations. That is how powerful and regulatory governments go about creating their own markets. By what means the Government could construe the regulated industry as the user of regulation, I do not know. Regulation is more often imposed on a reluctant industry and reluctant consumers to promote the interests of the regulators. This seems to be the case here-at least to some extent-given the information, or lack of it, from the Minister and his Government. Those arguments aside, the way in which the fees are structured by this legislation shows a lack of understanding of the industry which the Government is seeking to regulate. Fees will apply across the board with little flexibility to allow for the variety and different levels of production and the often very limited markets for therapeutic goods. The level of these charges bears little resemblance to the likely costs to the Department in administering the various so-called services on which the fees will be levied.

The licensing fees will be imposed on an annual basis, despite the fact that the cost to the Department of monitoring a licence might well be negligible. In those cases, it will be more than `user pays' or some form of rational contribution. The rationale for a significant annual charge on the licensing or listing of goods is not as clear as the similar charge for the licensing of the manufacturers themselves. The exact level of the charges to be imposed remains a matter for regulation under the legislation. This is another point that we object to and one which should be considered by the Senate committee to which we hope to have these Bills referred.
