The Government has made it clear that these charges are to be seen as a source of revenue which will be passed on to customers by the producers of therapeutic goods. So the consumer will pay once again. These increased cost burdens on the consumer are just one more kick in the teeth to those who are already struggling under the Government's Medicare mess.

As Medicare and the pharmaceutical benefits scheme are becoming an increasing financial drain on the Government, the Minister for Community Services and Health and his colleagues have sought to reduce that drain by imposing on individual consumers and the providers of medical services these additional costs-unforeseen costs as far as the consumers are concerned. The costs of medical assistance which cannot be legally covered by insurance have increased rapidly in recent years. Even so, the cost of private insurance has escalated enormously because of the effects of Medicare on the insurance market. The poor level of service provided under the Medicare system has been well documented with long waiting lists for surgery, shortages of hospital beds, declining morale amongst medical staff, poor delivery to country areas, and an enormous drain on the taxpayer. This legislation is in the same tradition, establishing a new unified national system of regulation, with a series of charges which could prove far more onerous than the Minister suggested in his second reading speech.

In drawing to a conclusion, I would like to make a few points about regulation in general. In spite of the very best motives of many regulators and the governments which introduce regulatory laws, their noble ideals are often not fulfilled. The Minister in his second reading speech referred to the thalidomide tragedy and suggested that this Bill would reduce the chances of similar mistakes occurring in the future. However, the thalidomide failure was not one of regulation or lack of it but was a failure due to a lack of knowledge. The Government cannot regulate against ignorance. The Government should provide effective remedies for such failures through the legal system. It should provide incentives to companies to conduct the most rigorous research and testing of new products before they come on to the market, otherwise the regulatory process becomes not a protection for consumers but a protector of companies which have met the requirements of legislation.

A firm which has gone through extensive procedures for regulatory approval has no incentive to engage in further research, or to follow up new information which emerges after the product is registered, licensed or approved for sale to the public. Regulatory minimum standards have a tendency to emerge as maximum standards with no benefit to any company which seeks to improve on those minimums. Regulation which is too extensive, constrains improvements in efficiency, quality and standards by forcing producers to conform to one standard laid down by the regulatory agency, which is not always at the forefront of research and knowledge. Regulation is always in conflict with innovation and advance.

When human lives are at stake, caution is an essential requirement for anyone building a service, such as therapeutic goods for the public. However, regulation runs the risk of causing stagnation and vastly higher costs to the consumer with little real benefit in terms of quality or safety. There is a tendency amongst honourable members on the other side of the chamber to blame chemical companies and the search for a profit for every form of medicine which does not work or, more unfortunately, which causes deleterious and unexpected side effects. Yet they neglect to inform people that most of those products have received regulatory approval before being released on the market. They neglect to mention that the vast majority of great advances in medicines and therapeutic treatment were developed by the same companies which they so readily condemn. No such advances in knowledge have emerged elsewhere from expensive regulatory agencies which more often than not slow the release of helpful products to those who need them. I support the stand taken by the honourable member for Tangney, the shadow Minister for Health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In following the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) I find myself in a dilemma. His contributions are always well thought out. They often have some substance but, unfortunately, not today. The honourable member for Curtin spoke about the overburden of regulation. There is going to be no burden on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) when he replies to this debate in analysing the contribution of the honourable member for Curtin and the points that need to be answered. Unfortunately, the honourable member for Curtin has failed to recognise that the Therapeutic Goods Bill and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill were developed from the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in which members of the party of the honourable member for Curtin participated and they agreed with the recommendations. The industry was consulted and it also agrees with the recommendations that form the basis of this legislation. So away we go again with what I describe as opposition for the sake of opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I do not think that members of the Opposition make much of a contribution to the process when they engage in opposition simply for the sake of it. I reiterate two or three points made in the Minister's second reading speech. Recognising the magnitude of the problem faced here in having legislation, in some way, to provide these guarantees, it is an immense task to put over 14,000 medicinal drug products and over 25,000 therapeutic devices into the marketplace and expect people to both understand them and ensure that those products are safe in the marketplace. As the Minister said in his second reading speech, there are still great areas where there is a lack of knowledge. There is a requirement for immensely complex checks and balances to ensure that risks to humans who take these substances or use these devices are minimised. We have to find parameters which define the acceptability of anything which is to appear in the marketplace for prescription to or consumption by the public.

First of all, we have to tackle the question of quality. We have to ensure via national legislative standards that quality is guaranteed. We have to ensure that safety is guaranteed. The honourable member for Curtin, in his contribution, made a comment about thalidomide and said that the problem of thalidomide arose because at the time there was a lack of knowledge. I put it to him that that was not the case. The problem arose because at the time there was undue haste in introducing the drug to the marketplace. It had not been sufficiently tested and the side effects when they were apparent in the early stage were not properly recognised, and were in fact ignored for what might be put as commercial reasons. It is not true to say that there was a lack of knowledge in that instance. When we are dealing with safety, particularly the safety of drugs and medicines, we have to ensure that there are satisfactory national standards.

The honourable member for Curtin makes the point that any attempt to legislate puts in place a lowest common denominator of standards. That may well be the case, but it is not sufficient to say that there should not be legislation because the best that can be achieved at the moment is the results of the intensive investigation by the Public Accounts Committee, chaired by the honourable member for Hughes, (Mr Tickner) and the recommendations from the industry that this is the way to go and which take account of the role and interest of the States.

The third aspect we have to take account of is that, having satisfied ourselves that the model will account for quality and safety standards, we have to be assured of the efficacy or the effectiveness of the product. The world have been through the development of the snake oil medicines, as they are called. Of course, there have been many wonder prescriptions of one kind or another and many millions of dollars spent by people in the chase for a product that in the end proved to be nothing more than a sugar pill. So the extent to which we give an imprimatur to effectiveness is important and is embraced in this legislation. Again, that is consistent with the recommendations.

The legislation will now require three major elements to be satisfied before the product appears in the marketplace. We have adopted the three major elements recommended by the World Health Organisation as being necessary for effective regulation. First, there must be a pre-market assessment of the product for human use. I assume that that is self-evident to every member in this place and does not need further elaboration. Second, we require through the legislation that good manufacturing practices are followed in the manufacture of therapeutic products for human use-in other words, standards of quality in the process that guarantee all the things that we require of a product that is going to be consumed by the public. Third, we have to ensure that a set of standards is developed for human and veterinary use of drugs and that there is compliance with that set of standards.

We have to take into account that at the moment there is a potpourri of State, Territory and Commonwealth legislation in this field which has evolved over many years. This legislation is an attempt to draw all that together and give industry, consumers and governments of all levels that are involved a common base with which to work. In an economy which is trying to rationalise in a whole lot of areas and with many of the inconsistencies that have developed with our Federal-State system in so many fields, this is the logical way for this nation to go, and this legislation ought to be supported by the Opposition.

A logical extension of this legislation is that, having put this legislation in place and guaranteed the quality, safety and standards of the goods that actually appear on the shelves, it behoves us as a parliament to turn our minds also to the question of prescription and supply or consumption of the various drugs and devices that are available to people. Recently in this Parliament my colleague, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), in his capacity as Chairman of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, handed down a report called Drugs and Crime in Society, and in my opinion there is a startling finding in that report. It set out to deal with the question of illegal drugs, illicit drugs, and the Committee found that there was a factor of 9:1 of toxic poisoning cases to overdoses in our hospitals and doctors' clinics. The major drug problem in this country relates to legally available drugs and compounds. They do not have the criminal elements associated with them which lead to all the other problems of illicit drugs. But in terms of people stuffing things down their throats, doing immense damage to their systems and placing great demands on the national health system, the major problem in this country is the legally available drugs and compounds.

The Minister has asked the Standing Committee on Community Affairs to conduct an inquiry into the prescription, supply and consumption of drugs. The Committee will look at the whole question of community attitudes. Why is it that we say, `Something is wrong, we must have something, let's get our hands on it quickly'? Why are we such prolific consumers of these drugs? Why is it that so many people overdose and show signs of toxic poisoning? Is it because of television advertisements such as the one that advises women that they are not good mothers unless they rub Vicks Vaporub onto their children's chests when they start to cough? Is it because we have been conditioned to traipse to the doctor and say, `I must have something'? Is it because we pay our doctors and chemists by volume? Under the prescription system, the more patients one sees and the more turnover one has, the more one earns. Is that a smart way for a nation to go about these matters?

The bottom line is that, having introduced this legislation, which at least provides a base and guarantees that what is available on the shelves will meet certain standards, even though we may end up catering for the lowest common denominator, as the honourable member for Curtin said, we must now turn our attention to trying to wind back community dependence on drugs, particularly those that are dangerous if taken excessively. As Chairman of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I point out to the House that we in the Parliament have a responsibility to follow up that matter, now that this legislation has been introduced.

I take a very broad view. I think that a much broader role can be played by our pharmacists, for instance, in advising people. I think it is absolute lunacy that, in order to obtain a drug under the prescription system, we must consult one professional, for which visit the Government pays, and we then traipse down the road into a shop and see another professional. We then pay another fee for the prescribed item, whatever it may be. Surely, there must be scope for much more harmony, coordination and efficiency not only in financial terms, but in health terms. The views of community centres, alternative medicine advocates and consumer associations need to be heard as we look at the next stage, having put in place a base by way of this legislation.

I do not think I have wandered too far from the ambit of the Bill. This legislation represents very much an action in good faith by the Minister. It shows once again-and I have made this point on many occasions-that the Hawke Labor Government is not a government which pigeon holes reports. We all know what happened to parliamentary committee reports over many years. I know that every report with which I have been associated during my time in this place has been taken very seriously and has been responded to by the Government, certainly to my satisfaction. The Public Accounts Committee, under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Hughes, has done a very deep and thorough analysis of the issue. It has presented a report of substance which has been picked up and accepted by the Government and industry. This legislation puts it into action. The Hawke Labor Government's record-whether it is in the area of meeting the pledge to remove children from poverty, getting people back to work, fixing up the Budget, or even taking note of reports of parliamentary committees-is one of action. I have no hesitation in commending the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear the comments of the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe). He may wish to stay in the chamber and listen to what I have to say about the Therapeutic Goods Bill because I was a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts that looked at the proposals for such a Bill. I am familiar with the Committee's report and its arguments, but I do not consider this Bill to be an adequate response to the issues raised during Committee hearings. I am sorry that the honourable member believes that it is necessary for him to leave the chamber at this point in the debate when I am about to enlighten him.
—I am sorry; I have another appointment.

—We all recognise the difficulty that honourable members have from time to time. I am not reflecting on the honourable member's motives. I hope that he reads the Hansard record of my speech. This matter is a difficult one because the Bill that is before the House has been a long time in its gestation. The report of the Public Accounts Committee has been referred to by Government members as a report which should be seen as approving of this legislation in its present form, leading to its passage. That is a gross distortion of the report, and the arguments put forward by Committee members. It ignores the damning views of the Committee concerning the way in which the Government responded in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to refer honourable members to the discussion which appears in the report on the question of legislation. When the Public Accounts Committee undertook its inquiry and reviewed the therapeutic goods evaluation and testing program, it was aware that there had been an absence of uniform national legislation in the therapeutic goods area. The Committee stated that the need for such legislation was recognised as far back as 1966 when Commonwealth and State Ministers formed a working party to examine the proposal. Page 13 of the Committee's report details the way in which Commonwealth powers were restricted and the legislation under which the Commonwealth presently operates. The Committee dealt with State legislation. It recorded the nature of the evidence given by witnesses to the Committee and spoke about the pharmaceutical benefits scheme review, which strongly supported the proposal for uniform national legislation, and its recommendations. The report quotes favourably some evidence that I received as a member of that Committee in relation to the way in which the States, as well as the Commonwealth, were dealing with this matter. I refer in particular to paragraph 2.42 of the Committee's report. It states:

The Committee, however, was disturbed to hear evidence from the States, industry groups and consumer groups that consultation has not been as extensive as the Department had indicated in its submission and evidence. Most groups were aware of the proposal in principle, but had had no detailed discussions or consultation with the Department. In particular, industry and consumer groups were aware of proposals but were concerned at the lengthening timetable for further consultation and eventual introduction into the Parliament.
Thereafter some quotes are included in the Committee's discussion. As I said, I was involved in that matter. In paragraph 2.46 of the report the Committee stated:

The ever lengthening timetable for introduction of the legislation is of great concern to the Committee. As stated in Chapter 1 the lack of appropriate legislation was of concern to the Committee . . . However, this concern should in no way impede proper consultation with interested parties. The Committee believes that the draft Bill should be made public as soon as possible and should be made available to those parties for comment. Adequate time should be allowed for proper debate.

The Committee indicated in its report that it had been advised that the Department might prepare this legislation for presentation in the 1989 Budget sittings. After all of those comments about the need for consultation, after the Committee had offered some views, particularly in relation to substantial issues, including cost recovery aspects, in which the Committee universally endorsed the need for cost recovery, I am surprised that the specific suggestions of the Committee were not taken up by the Government. This has been a matter of concern to industry and is a matter of concern to me. Honourable members who are not members of the Committee come in and laud the Government for introducing legislation at this time. They suggest that one ought to be pleased that the Committee's report has been responded to, yet there are significant variations between the Government's Bill and the proposals that were submitted and supported by the Committee. They were supported across the board politically-by me as a member of the Committee and by my colleagues.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the only one who has suggested that.

—That might be so, but I can inform the honourable member for Perth there are few who are perhaps across these matters. I understand that the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), spoke before me in this debate. I would have thought that he would have brought out very clearly in his speech-and I would be disappointed if he did not because we try to work in a non-partisan way in the Committee-the substantial differences between the Government's determined approach on this issue and the view that the Committee formed.
—I would think the shadow Minister would be.

—The shadow Minister was certainly across these matters because I have spoken at length with him. I have supported strongly the view that the Opposition has come to-that the legislation ought to be rejected at this time-because of the extent to which these sensible views put by the Public Accounts Committee have been ignored by the Government and its advisers.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to emphasise the time that has been taken in this matter. I would have thought that, with all the comments that have been offered in relation to consultation and the need for consultation, we would not have arrived at a situation where we have proposals that are so abhorrent to the industries concerned. I have had some discussions with industry representatives and I have not found them at all unreasonable. Over a long period speaking with pharmaceutical manufacturers in my electorate I have become aware of concerns that many of them have had for national legislation, particularly national legislation that would put in place a framework of law which would enable a good manufacturing practice in particular to be administered uniformly throughout Australia. There is a concern that if a high standard of good manufacturing practice is enforced in New South Wales, for instance, as has been the case over time, but a lesser standard is adopted in other States, industry could be forced to move from one State to another simply to have products manufactured at a lower standard. I do not believe that that is what the Australian public would want. I think Australians would want a proper and appropriate standard, reasonably arrived at, enforced uniformly throughout Australia.

When I seek advice from industry I am told-as the Opposition has put in its own comments-that in principle this package of legislation has been supported by the relevant industry groups, which see some advantages to the general public and manufacturing industry in relation to uniformity of scheduling and regulatory controls of manufacturing. But, unless there has been cooperation and proper consultation and discussions between all the States and Territories and the Commonwealth, national registration arrangements will be unworkable.

At this stage we have no clear indication that any State or Territory of Australia has drawn up complementary legislation. At this stage the Victorian Government has indicated that it is willing to look at repealing its own system of registration but will not be doing so until the spring session in 1990. This means that, even with the program that the Government has set down at this time, it will not be competent to deal with these important questions. It will not have legislation in place because the way in which the Victorians are addressing this question means that the Government will be forced to delay the introduction of the registration arrangements if it is going to avoid the situation of having two systems in place.

It seems to me that this proposal gives the Government time to arrange for these outstanding matters, of which the Government is aware and to which industry is drawing attention. They involve substantial questions of disagreement with the Public Accounts Committee and its stated view on the report. I do not know whether the Public Accounts Committee has changed its view since then. If it did, it did so when I was no longer a member. At the time when I was a member of the Public Accounts Committee we looked at the question of fees. A whole chapter, paragraphs 7.14 through to 7.30, dealt with the basis upon which we thought a fair system of fees should be introduced. We made a number of very simple points. I think the emphasis ought to be understood clearly by all honourable members. We were not in favour of cross-subsidisation or of fees that were designed to raise revenue for government; we were in favour of fees that were designed to be a proper cost recovery mechanism for services actually rendered to industry by government.

We have a Bill which does not seek to do that. We have the imposition of annual fees, regardless of whether or not they represent a payment for service, and the imposition of a secondary and indirect form of taxation-that is, revenue being gained by Government-through this exercise. As a result of what the Government is proposing we have a situation whereby exporters might well be penalised in cost terms as against other countries producing the same goods who would not be similarly charged. We have the situation in which there might well be cross-subsidisation, and that is a matter which the Committee was unwilling to embrace. In paragraph 7.22 the Committee had this to say:
However, in framing such a fee structure the Committee stresses-
I mention again that word `stresses'-
that, for evaluation or other costs, there should under no circumstances be cross-subsidisation by one category of goods in respect of any other.
The report went on to say:
Goods already on the market that only require registration should not be re-evaluated. Fees for inclusion on the Register should not be substantial.

These matters are of very considerable concern to industry. The Government seems to be moving to try to impose unreasonable charges, a form of indirect taxation which is quite unjust and quite improper. We have come to the view that this matter ought to be looked at again. The Government could have referred the matter to the Public Accounts Committee for further report and report to the Parliament if that was its desire. No doubt when this matter is before the Senate the Opposition's view that there should be a further examination of these questions will be pressed.

Finally, I think there is a need for arrangements-as industry believes-whereby for the general public and manufacturing industry there is a uniformity of arrangement throughout Australia. I think it can be achieved by proper consultation, but proper consultation did not take place before, when the Committee undertook its report and I doubt, from what I have been told, that we have seen proper consultation take place since the Public Accounts Committee undertook its review.

I can believe that officials may very well have been embarrassed at the nature of the criticism that they were subjected to by the Public Accounts Committee and I can believe that they would want to try to meet the timetable that was set. But the Committee emphasised the need for consultation. Since the Public Accounts Committee deliberations, there has been further examination of some of these questions by the Government's Business Regulation Review Unit. Some of that material was brought to my attention after our Committee reported. I thought it was of interest that that review commented on the need for the approach to be taken in this area not to be unduly bureaucratic. The government's own advisory unit said:

The paper considers that there are many areas where regulation generates unnecessarily high costs. It also considers that the intensifications of controls proposed by DCSH are not, in the main, warranted and that the charging proposals both for these intensifications and for the ongoing program are excessive. These conclusions apply with particular force with regard to products having well known features and risks.

I want to make one other point in relation to the comments made by the Government's Business Regulation Review Unit and by the Public Accounts Committee. We were not of the view that this Government, through its legislation or through the Department of Community Services and Health, ought to be reinventing the wheel. There is a wealth of information about the evaluation of products and drugs throughout the world. That information ought to be taken into account in an examination of these questions. Where inquiries have been undertaken by competent overseas authorities, there is a need for their judgment to be accepted at face value by Australia. I do not know that we are so much at the forefront of knowledge within government here in Australia that, when it comes to the European Community or the United States of America, we can say our view on evaluations, because we are not at the forefront of actually inventing these drugs, ought to be accepted, and we ought to be able to make and undertake all of these examinations to the exclusion of views reached by regulatory authorities abroad. I just do not think that is the case. The Government's Business Regulation Review Unit came to the same view: assessments undertaken by competent overseas authorities ought to be accepted; it would achieve substantial savings and would reduce delays in bringing products onto the market here in Australia.

The Committee spent a good deal of time looking at these questions. We offered these views. I would have hoped that, in developing the report, the Government, knowing of the amount of time spent, would have taken the views of the Public Accounts Committee into account and produced a Bill that would have been satisfactory to industry and one which the Opposition would have been able to enthusiastically support instead of having to ask for further inquiry, instead of having to delay implementation of legislation or its rejection if the matter cannot be resolved by a further inquiry and report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I have great respect for the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). He is a very sincere and thoughtful contributor in this place. I see the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs-the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith)-nodding his approval. But, clearly, the honourable member for Dundas should have listened to the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tucker), who, as the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts spoke on this legislation earlier. Perhaps he should have also listened to his shadow spokesman, who spoke on this issue. I sat and listened to the speech in its entirety, and I cannot remember him mentioning the Public Accounts Committee. I may be wrong on that.
—Me?

—The Opposition's spokesman. I may be wrong-perhaps Hansard will prove that-but I cannot remember his mentioning it. It would seem to me that was a considerable oversight on his part, because it was a substantial body of evidence that was collected by the Public Accounts Committee with regard to this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about therapeutic goods and the whole industry which revolves around the use of devices and substances for therapy in this country. I would have thought that it is clear that the principle that there should be national legislation is something that all of us on both sides of the House support. It is clear that the Public Accounts Committee, in its report, made considerable recommendations. But in the end, the Government has to decide on the form and nature of that legislation, and there will invariably be areas in which concern is shown by industry and by the Opposition. I accept that in this place. But to come in here and suggest that we in the Government oppose this, and to be negative and carping and saying that it is all bad, is nonsense.

I will take up some of the points that the honourable member for Dundas raised. He said that he supports proper cost recovery of those evaluations that take place, but he does not support-and it is terribly difficult for any manufacturer to sustain-a $50-a-year fee for annual membership or listing. That is absurd. He said that a $50-a-year listing fee will put people out of business. I do not believe it. Then, if a manufacturer wants to have his drug on the list, it costs him between $150 and $350 a year. I am sorry, but that will not put any reputable manufacturer out of business. It is not an unreasonable thing. It could easily be considered to be within cost recovery. To suggest that it is unreasonable is nonsense. The honourable member knows that as well as I do. To suggest that the Government is reinventing the wheel in all of this legislation is nonsense. The suggestion within the legislation that the Government will use the British Pharmacopoeia is clearly an indication that it will take on board all of that body of evidence that exists in that listing of pharmaceuticals which has been built over a long period.

It is a pity that the honourable member comes in here and is negative just for the sake of being negative. When that happens, it is unfortunate that a bipartisan discussion does not take place in here. When good manufacturing practices are spoken of and we are told how reasonable it is that good manufacturing processes should be part of the criteria for manufacturing devices, pharmaceuticals and whatever else it is that makes up therapeutic goods in this country, that is a reasonable thing. But when it is found out that in some places the evidence received by the Public Accounts Committee was that a third of the manufacturers were not fulfilling those principles-that code of manufacturing practice-then there should be concern. We should be rushing in here to do something about it, and there should be legislation.

The honourable member for Dundas mentioned, very correctly, that it is 1966 since this matter was first considered. Indeed, that is a long time ago. In 1986 the Cabinet decision was made to revise the Therapeutic Goods Act of 1966. Following that we had the Public Accounts Committee report. Now we get to this place. There has been considerable consultation. Every time I come in here to speak on a Bill-and there is all sorts of legislation that comes before the House-we have the problem that there has not been consultation. Really, there has been an enormous amount of consultation with the industry. I have no doubt that there are areas of industry in which there would still be concerns. When the regulations have to be tabled in this place, no doubt we can hear from the honourable member then. But to suggest that the Government delays, destroys, gets in the way and stops the principle from going ahead is wrong. That is where I have difficulty. What we are talking about is ensuring that the quality, the safety and the efficacy of therapeutic goods are substantial. That is in the public good for all of us in this House, and we all understand that. It is necessary that all of those devices, all of those treatments and all of those substances are sound and that people can expect that they are sound and understand that there is some sort of uniformity in the way in which they are assessed. At the moment we have a patchwork quilt.

Last time I came to Canberra, I came on the train. It was a frightening experience, because the train was derailed, things broke down and went wrong. But I can just imagine what it must have been like before the standard gauge railway was introduced. There was a patchwork of different States doing different things and it could not be all tied together. The same thing applies in this area. In the last century we had that sort of mentality-that we all do it a different way. I accept what the Opposition is saying. The Victorian Government may, for some time, have a piece of legislation overlapping with what we introduce. That may also happen in other States. But the problem now is not that there is an overlapping; the problem is that there are huge gaps. One could drive a truck through the gaps. One can bring into this country all sort of therapeutic devices that are not allowed overseas. People ring me asking why they cannot bring into Australia the latest new drug that will cure their cancer. One feels very disappointed and very sorry for a person in that circumstance. Unfortunately, there are all sorts of people who will prey on the circumstances that people find themselves in by selling them snake oil, selling them substances that really do not work. In popular mythology, crushed almond kernels used to be a treatment for cancer, but it does not work; it just costs money. We need some sort of rational, sensible mechanism that brings about control and regulation of this whole area of policy.

Five criticisms were brought up by the Opposition spokesman. The first was that we will have this overlap; therefore it is not achievable; therefore we should not do it. It is not logical to say that, because we have had huge gaps and an inefficient system for 88 years, we should not do anything about it because it will not work. If we are about anything in this place, we are about developing sensible ways of solving Australia's problems. From time to time there are bitter arguments and disputes in here, but we really need to think about sensible ways of solving some of our problems. We have here a united way of tying up this area of industry.

The second criticism we heard was that there has not been enough consultation, and that industry does not want this and does not agree with it. I have not had large numbers of people rushing to my door telling me that. The Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee has not found that to be so; the Minister has not found that to be so. So where are all these people going? Obviously they are going to honourable members on the other side of the House or they do not exist. We heard that in some way the appeal process would be unfair because when the decision on the appeal was given, no reasons would be provided for the appellant. It was said that in some way industry was not getting a fair go in the appeal process. But that practice is standard for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. If one wants the reasons the Tribunal will provide them, but the reasons are not provided unless they are asked for. There is no difference in this legislation from what currently exists and what is the standard practice of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The third concern was that it would be necessary for Australian businesses to comply with manufacturing practices which were excessive and unreasonable. On that I simply say this: if one-third of them are not complying with a code which says that these are good manufacturing principles, then there is need for some change. I was horrified to hear the concern raised by Opposition members that if the businesses are made to comply with good manufacturing principles and good manufacturing practice, in fact they would be uncompetitive. We have had this mentality for too long in this country. We need to understand that if we are going to export, if we are going to produce good products, then the standard and the quality have to be first class.

The suggestion that being asked to comply with good manufacturing principles is excessive is nonsense. Who will buy these goods overseas? How will we establish ourselves as having a good reputation in this area? It is an export oriented industry. How are we to establish ourselves unless we ask for quality products within Australia and outside Australia? If we import and export good quality products, then it will be a viable industry and it will provide for Australians a sustainable export industry and an assurance that the quality of therapeutic goods is outstanding, as it should be. The suggestion that being asked to comply with good manufacturing practices is excessive is a nonsense. Indeed, the Opposition should think again about whether it wants to use that argument in this debate.

We then got onto fees and charges. Indeed, the shadow Minister spoke at some length about it. He said that the charges that were going to be levied were excessive. The honourable member for Dundas said that this cross-subsidisation that would occur-we have not seen a final list of charges; an indicative list of charges has been circulated with industry and there has been an amount of discussion about it but there has not been a final list of charges-would in some way cause the breakdown of manufacturing in areas of therapeutic goods. Again, the Opposition is asking for cost recovery. This legislation recovers half of the cost of setting up this regulating mechanism. The cost is $15m; we will recover $7.5m. One could hardly suggest that was cross-subsidisation. One could say that it is reasonable fee setting to recover some of the costs that ensure the quality of products in this country. But the shadow Minister suggested that there should be no fees, no charges. He is suggesting that the taxpayers should pay for this. If it is not the consumers who pay, it is the taxpayers. So the user pays principle that is used from time to time on the other side goes out the window.

If that is the principle the Opposition wants to enshrine, if that is the principle it wants to follow, that is okay. Every time there comes into this place some sort of Bill which relates to regulation and charges, which relates to levies on industries, which relates to any area like that, let us have consistency. The taxpayer should take all of those charges. If that is what the Opposition thinks, there should be no levies on industry, there should be no regulation. All of those things should be paid for by the public purse and the user should not pay. If that is the principle the Opposition is espousing, perhaps we could accept it. But there is inconsistency. It is clear that the fees that are indicatively charged and are proposed to be charged are reasonable. It is not excessive to pay $50 for annual listing. If a company is going to manufacture thousands of widgets and sell them all over the place, $50 a year will not break it. The suggestion that it might is nonsense. The suggestion that we will re-evaluate all those things that we have been evaluating is again just being negative; it is just spoiling. That is not what is proposed in this legislation, and the suggestion that that is what it is about is crazy.

I am looking for a rational reason for the Opposition opposing it but I cannot find one. It may be that there are areas of the regulations that the Opposition would agree with; the regulations are not finalised. The draft of the regulations has been developed with the industry. There has been a lot of consultation. People know about the regulations. There has been a great deal of discussion. We are concerned about the thrust, the principle behind the philosophical approach to this legislation. The philosophical approach is that for too long in this country each State has done its own thing in a disjointed way. Sometimes there is overlap; sometimes there are huge gaps.

At the moment we assess these goods sometimes at the point of supply, sometimes at the point of import. There is no control over the standard to which we produce products, which we may then export. That affects our reputation as an exporter of quality goods. That structure, which is piecemeal and has been built up over decades, requires change. If one is going to change the structure one needs to start with a principal. This legislation enshrines the principle that the Government will adopt a national approach. It will set up a mechanism that will allow present knowledge and experience to be used. It will allow that expertise and knowledge that exists overseas to be used, but it will fill in the gaps so that the whole painting is clear and there are no holes here and there and pieces where paint has not been laid onto the canvas. If you like the analogy, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be able to stand back, look at the picture and know that it is complete.

The suggestion that by setting up this legislation the Government in some way is anti-export is a nonsense. The suggestion that by setting up this legislation the Government in some way will cripple industry and manufacturers is a nonsense. The Government is trying to tie them together. Some members of the Opposition understand this issue very well; others are perhaps a bit dim in their knowledge of this legislation-and I do not include the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) in that. However, I find it amazing that they oppose the legislation. The Opposition has implied that, with the assistance of the Democrats, it will block this legislation in the Senate. I hope that before it reaches that stage the Opposition will allow the legislation to be passed. It is only for the public good. Between now and when the legislation goes to the Senate, I hope the Opposition will give consideration to allowing the legislation to pass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed that a person with the professional skills of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), should talk about Australians drinking snake oil in this day and age. I wonder how many times he has prescribed that particular product for his patients. This debate needs to be lifted from the emotional level of the previous speaker's contribution to some factual information that will relate the debate to a modern pharmaceutical and device industry which is growing and developing and which needs careful attention by legislators. I refer the House to the body that was established by the Government to review business regulations and to ensure that the assessed impact of regulations was reviewed. The Government established that body also to ensure that all new regulations were efficient, cost effective and likely to achieve their desired objectives and that there was proper liaison with State governments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's own committee, which was established specifically for the purpose of looking at those factors, has bucketed the Government's approach in this instance. It is all right for Government members who have some penchant for regulation to come into this Parliament and say, `We are going to cram regulation after regulation down the throats of the Australian people and Australian manufacturers'. One has only to consider the situation in the pharmaceutical industry, particularly the dispensing of prescriptions and the delivery of pharmaceuticals by Australia's chemists, to see that the Government is absolutely opposed to the proper delivery of services to clients. The Government has forgotten what the people of Australia really need. It is really enthralled with the bureaucratic process. If something is big, beautiful, difficult to manage, cumbersome, bureaucratic and costly, the Government seems to go for it. In this instance, it is making a grave mistake.

Whilst the Opposition acknowledges the need for a national approach to therapeutic goods-that means goods of a pharmaceutical nature or device-and whilst there is a need for a national program and common practices to be adopted amongst the States, there is no need to adopt this mumbo-jumbo obstructive approach that the Government's own committee has so strongly criticised. A committee of the Government was set up within the bureaucracy to check whether or not Government proposals were efficient and workable. In March of this year, according to its report, that committee decided that the Government's approach was not appropriate for Australia's modern industry.

The committee cited a number of grounds on which it was critical of the intentions of the proposals of the Government and the Department. Firstly, it cited the refusal to recognise that any country but Australia has an absolute capacity to test any of those devices or pharmaceuticals. It appears that we have to reinvent the wheel and do everything here in Australia from scratch, which would be costly and stupid. Why can we not accept the standards of comparable countries, which often have gone through the process of research and development alongside those organisations that are seeking to break through into new and more advantageous products? It seems that the Australian bureaucracy and the responsible Minister are saying, `If it is not examined fully and in detail here in Australia, we do not trust anybody else'.

A consideration of the record of the current system reveals that it is very difficult to point to any damage that has been caused to any one Australian-certainly no deaths-through a failure of the system. We are moving to a new system. I believe that the Public Accounts Committee found an instance of one death that was caused by infected bandages that were imported into Australia. What is wrong with our import provisions when we are going to stamp on Australian manufacturers but we are not going to check imports to the same degree. That is crazy stuff. That five deaths occurred in a hospital because somebody used the wrong strength product is hardly a reason for changing the whole system. Hospitals should possess the technical competence to avoid mistakes like that. This will be a brand new system. Much of the intention is good but much of the delivery is bad. I do not intend to go into detail at this point; I will leave that until after dinner.

The committee established by the Government was given the following tasks: to assess the impact of the regulations; to screen the regulations and ascertain whether they were effective and efficient; to achieve the desired objectives of the Government; to liaise with State governments; and to ascertain whether or not the current measures meet those criteria. In so many areas they certainly do not meet those criteria, and the committee was correct in saying so. The economies of accepting overseas competence are obvious. The acceptance of existing drugs without further testing, regulation and registration is also apparent. Readily available drugs will all go through this process. Even though people can now buy those drugs off shelves in supermarkets, those products will have to be reassessed because we need a pristine system.

The committee commented on the outstanding results and performance of the pharmaceutical goods manufacturing industry of Australia, which hardly justifies the comment that some 35 per cent of Australian manufacturing facilities operate at unacceptable levels of quality control. That control has existed for a long time and I am sure that if that is the case-and I doubt that it is because the end product does not seem to indicate that-it has taken a long time for Commonwealth authorities to get round to commenting or encouraging State authorities to do anything about it. I doubt the veracity of that 35 per cent.

The Australian pharmaceutical and therapeutic industries have a remarkable safety performance. We are talking about loading unnecessary costs on Australian industry. Those costs will not be applied to imports to the same degree and will seriously damage Australia's future manufacturing, both in the supply of import replacements and to take advantage of export potential. I am most critical of this because it matches government regulation in so many spheres. This week the Government was unwilling to deregulate a failed aviation industry.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time when inflation is annualised at an amazing level of 9.2 per cent, with an annual rate of 8 per cent; when the balance of payments is a massive $1.8 billion and that is considered a good figure for the month; when the pharmacists are reeling under the attacks of a Federal Government that seems to want to deny services to the community and proper remuneration to skilled and highly qualified people; when the airlines are in a mess, when one has to wonder whether John Elliott is running Ansett Airlines of Australia rather than Sir Peter Abeles and whether we could have had a different result from the airlines dispute at a time like this with all those public tragedies around the nation, we have the Government in this House day after day, time and again, quietly regulating more and more, controlling the activities of Australian business and the lives of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we are debating regulations and legislation on an important issue, the supply of therapeutic products to the Australian community. If that is the case, the Government has got its priorities wrong. We have a framework for legislation; there are no regulations to spell out the detail on the Bill which is before the House tonight. This Bill, like so many others that have come to this House, is just a framework which is going to impose more and more costs on the Australian people. This proposal will raise about $30m from the therapeutic manufacturing industries-a $30m bill that will be eventually met by the consumers of Australia-and yet we do not know in detail how the Government is going to apply it. Those people who are responsible for supplying these products do not know how the regulations are going to apply to them; or they know nothing about the bureaucracy, the form filling and all the rest of the paraphernalia that will be imposed upon them. We have only a framework.

What a priority this Government has. It is wrecking the economy, it is wrecking the opportunity for people to move around the nation and at the same time it is quietly, day after day, imposing more and more costs on the Australian people. It is taxing this industry, and eventually the consumers, simply to placate a feeling that seems to exist in this Government that there are problems in the pharmaceuticals industry. There are no problems; the record demonstrates that there have not been any problems. There have been no deaths because things have not been properly inspected or attended to. The Opposition says there should be a national approach to this issue, but we are so concerned about what the Government is doing that we are proposing that this legislation should go to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for proper consideration, firstly, so that regulations can be assessed by the Senate and, secondly, so that those who are interested in the industry, including the consumers, can make representations to the Government.

We want to put this to a Senate committee, and two important factors make this critical. The Government set up its own Business Regulation Review Unit to evaluate the cost of regulation. That review unit has said that the Government is way off track. Its report is a condemnation of what the Government is doing. The Therapeutic Goods Bill is flawed. All of the proposals in the Bill are outlined in the Government unit's own report. On top of that, the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) of this Parliament has studied this matter and there have been serious reservations expressed by this bipartisan Committee. We have a parliamentary committee and a specialised unit looking at regulations, and both of those groups have said there are problems with what the Government is proposing.

The Government's proposal under the Therapeutic Goods Bill will raise another $30m. That $30m will be raised by fees and levies and all sorts of things that do not exist at the moment. One notable feature is that the Government is to apply $13.2m to laboratory testing instead of $1.5m. It is going to increase that expenditure six-fold, for the protection of the Australian people. What it really means is that we are going to have a unit, paid for by the Government, which will be run by bureaucrats who are going to test products on a selective basis. This sort of testing can be done by ethical, well practised, commercial units that can be told with absolute certainty what the Government's requirements are. But no, we are going to expand the testing process so that there will be routine testing of new products after they have gained entry to the market, regular testing of prescription drugs and regular testing of certain devices such as hip replacement devices, dialysis machines and all other sorts of devices that are manufactured within Australia. There are quality alert provisions, according to the Code of Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP), and inspection and testing after consumer complaints.

This is a unit that goes into this field and goes into a whole range of new testing. It is completely unnecessary to expand in this way. Testing is necessary but the expansion is the thing that horrifies me. The codes of GMP for therapeutic goods and for therapeutic devices are the key elements of this legislation. All it is about is controlling, from Canberra, one more industry. The Australian people have not suffered the difficulties of the Third World in the hands of unscrupulous suppliers or manufacturers. The record of this nation, with its modern education and well run institutions, can hold its own with that of any other nation in the world. The Public Accounts Committee went so far as to say that goods already on the market that only require regulation should not be re-evaluated, but the intention is to re-evaluate products that Australians have been buying for years. There is no point to that except to build an ivory tower. There is no public demand for this. The only thing that the public needs is an assurance that the quality of the products that have been on the market for years will be maintained. But there is going to be a re-evaluation.

The Public Accounts Committee of this Parliament stated that under no circumstances should there be cross-subsidisation, but the purpose of the legislation is to raise funds, through fees, and then plough them back into other fields designated by the Government under this legislation. Some of those fields include education against drug abuse and all sorts of interesting things, but the Government's taxing policy is probably the critical factor. The Government has seen an opportunity to get more out of an industry-a total of $30m from goods, devices, and pharmaceutical and other therapeutic goods-and redirect those funds into legal systems, education outlets, adverse reactions monitoring and a whole range of things that are being proposed. We do not need this.

Let the Senate Committee have a good look at it and come forward with a sensible compromise between the positions of the Opposition and the Government. That can easily be done. The Opposition is not opposed to much of what is contained here, but we point to the stupidity of going to the extent that the Government is going to on the advice of its servants, flying in the face of its own unit set up to review business regulation and flying in the face of the Public Accounts Committee just to claim that Australia is going to have something special and different from the rest of the world. But becoming something special and different in this instance will mean the cost to manufacturers will be so great that many of them will be forced to stop manufacturing particular products in Australia and there will be more importation.

That is exactly the wrong strategy for Australia in the current economic circumstances. The additional costs proposed in the legislation will prevent those who are manufacturing in Australia from exporting into the world market-all in the name of something special and unique that is not mirrored in any other country in the world. We are not even prepared to accept the standards of and the examinations made in the United States, Great Britain, Europe, or anywhere else. We have to do it all ourselves. That is also one of the complaints of the Business Regulation Review Unit and the PAC. We will not accept the high standards imposed by the United States or by Great Britain; we have to run tests from day one as if the product is original and had never before been on the market. Even those mild pharmaceutical products which have been on the Australian market for years are retested.

I do not know whether the Government knows what it has got itself into. A few enthusiasts in the Government have been carried away with all this stuff. It is wrong; it is heading in the wrong direction for Australian industry and the well-being of the Australian consumer. They have had to suffer enough because of the Government. In this minor area, any additional cost will filter through the system to all pharmaceutical products. What will the Government do when the pharmacists tell it that because it has imposed these requirements on the manufacturing industry and additional costs have been imposed on pharmacists, it will have to increase pharmaceutical benefits? Of course, the Government will say to the pharmacists that they should dig it out of their own pockets because that is its classic approach to problems such as this: regulate, then make those affected by the regulations pay for the regulations that nobody in Australia wants. It is deplorable. It is typical of the Government that day after day in the House buries this type of legislation, while not being able to deal with the big issues. The Government is going in the wrong direction and it must change its attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before I call the honourable member for Canning, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a debate will take place covering orders of the day Nos 4 and 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank goodness for the clock! Thank goodness the 20 minutes on the clock was reduced to zero minutes! The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) made remarks about an industry that bears no resemblance to the industry we are talking about. Can honourable members imagine more regulation in an area as important as therapeutic goods? The honourable member, in his wide ranging debate, complained that inflation was at 8 per cent; the Opposition could never get it below 10 or 11 per cent. We know that a significant component of that--(Quorum formed) I thank my colleague for supporting me during my contribution on the Therapeutic Goods Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mitchell talked about regulation and went on to say at length that regulation was a particularly bad thing. I would have thought that in this particular industry, as distinct from those other areas of manufacturing endeavour, regulation was a good thing. I would have thought that regulation in the industry to make sure that proper standards were maintained was a good thing. The honourable member spoke of a number of things-the current account deficit, the chemists' remuneration and the airlines-in a very wide ranging debate before he got onto any point of substance at all. I took notes of anything the honourable member said that was even remotely related to the Bill. One thing that he did say was that he believed that it should go to a Senate committee for examination, as though that would solve the problem. We have heard of government by committee but this is really Opposition by committee. Can honourable members imagine the Senate setting up a committee to examine this when it has been through the Public Accounts Committee, when the Ministers-Federal and State-responsible for the carriage of this Bill have talked about this over a number of years? The Opposition still wants to send it to a Senate committee for examination. The mind boggles!

The honourable member for Mitchell talked about the increased cost of testing. Once again, I would have thought that was a good thing-$13.2m to make sure that those drugs were properly evaluated-to the extent that they are not tested at the present time. If funding increases from about $2m to $13m, so long as the testing is stricter and the consumers can be sure that the standard of those drugs is as good as that in the rest of the world, then it is money well spent. It seems to me that when we talk about the costs on local manufacturing and the costs which seems to be the focus of the honourable member for Mitchell's contribution, we should also look at the costs of not doing it. One of the reasons the legislation is brought forward is that Australia is finding it increasingly difficult to participate in international agreements for regulatory collaboration on therapeutic goods because of our lack of a national system, not only in terms of recording and testing these drugs, but also to make sure that in the international area the drugs can be seen by people in other countries to have been tested to a level that does meet the strict standards that are required. I would have thought that manufacturers, at least, would have seen that as a positive; that is, that if they desire to export the drugs-that is, get into the international market-they would make sure that those drugs were tested to a degree that the international market would find acceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not read the legislation, have you?

—My colleague on the other side of the House is shaking his head like a golliwog. I am better briefed than he is and I am a lot better briefed than the honourable member for Mitchell. One other thing that the honourable member for Mitchell mentioned was one more industry being controlled from Canberra. I do not know where that is evident in the Bill. I do not know where that is evident in anything we are talking about here. I would have thought that the Bill we setting up here in the Federal Parliament recognises that the hotchpotch arrangements between the States and the Federal Government that have existed until now need examination and overhaul in a comprehensive way. One of the things that has bedevilled this country is the amount of duplication by the different parliaments which have responsibilities in the same areas. The Federal Government, by taking the lead in something as important as this with the cooperation of the States, means that we will have a much more comprehensive system which will ensure that the therapeutic goods sold in Australia meet the standards that consumers should expect.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mitchell also made the point that there was no public demand. He said that the public was not demanding that we have this legislation. I suppose that if that were the criteria by which we enacted legislation there would not be much legislation enacted at all. I do not think that in the early days there was a great rush from Australia about thalidomide. I do not think there was a great rush to have the parliaments of Australia put in place comprehensive testing arrangements when thalidomide came onto the market. But one would have to agree that the scope and intent of this Bill are to protect against episodes such as that. So the argument the honourable member uses that there is no public demand does not hold water at all.

The honourable member for Mitchell went on to say that there have been no deaths in Australia and he asked, `So why change?'. Again, I find that an extraordinary argument. The therapeutics industry is a very dynamic one. New products come on to the market all the time. It seems to me that with such a dynamic industry we have to move with it. The fact that there may not have been any deaths in Australia is no reason not to advance the control and testing of therapeutic goods. Let us look at why the legislation is required at all. As I have said, the legislation will create one national system to replace the current patchwork of controls. We found that there were great holes in the existing system through which some therapeutic goods could get on to the market without being properly tested, a process Australian consumers should expect. The present situation is inequitable to industry and unsatisfactory to consumers in that varying levels of scrutiny are applied to locally produced and imported goods. Some goods can enter the marketplace without any prior assessment or approval. For that reason alone the legislation before the Parliament today is not only warranted but also necessary. It is about time that this was done. We can always look back and ask, `Why was it not done before?' but it is certainly better late than never.

About 25 per cent of Australian manufacturers of therapeutic goods for human use are not manufacturing to internationally regarded standards of good manufacturing practice. That being the case, I am sure that the legislation before us will ensure that we lift the standards of those goods that are sold in Australia. That is a good thing. It might cost a little bit more-it really is a little bit more when we look at the total cost involved in this legislation-but I think the Australian consumer is well served by it. Australia is finding it increasingly difficult to participate in international agreements for regulatory collaboration on therapeutic goods because of our lack of a national system. With six States and two Territories, plus the Federal Government, all having a discrete area of control, it is very hard for manufacturers to ensure that when they put their goods up for international scrutiny they are accepted.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts has given strong encouragement for the new legislation. Overall, the scope of existing controls will not be markedly increased, rather the legislation will provide a uniform, national system. Yet to hear the honourable member for Mitchell talk we would think that this legislation will replace the whole scheme and that there will be massive changes in the industry. In fact, it brings the industry up to date and ensures that the hotch potch of existing controls work in a much more effective and efficient way.

I now turn to the issue of fees. One might ask why the fees are being introduced. In line with the Government's policy on cost recovery, it has decided that the program will recover 50 per cent of its cost from the therapeutic goods industry. That is a good investment by the industry to ensure that its products are up to international standards. Certainly the Government will put in the other 50 per cent on behalf of the consumers. Therefore, the cost recovery from the industry will reflect the benefit it gets from the legislation. The most substantial fees and charges will be for product evaluation for registration, and the inspection and licensing of manufacturers. This is necessary if we are to ensure that the therapeutic goods for sale in Australia and for sale overseas reach the standards required so that people here and overseas can be sure that the product they buy has been tested and carries an approval with which they can feel confident. It should be pointed out that many other countries charge fees for the same services. So I do not think that we are the only country to do so. We do not do anything different from many other countries. Many other countries, like us, have seen the wisdom of having the industry contribute to the standards that we expect the industry to meet.

I now refer to the attitudes of the States and Territories. They have received drafts of the Therapeutic Goods Bill. All State and Territory health departments have supported the introduction of the national scheme. I know I do not have to point out to the House that all health Ministers are not Labor Party Ministers. There are health Ministers of other political persuasions. The point made by the honourable member for Mitchell is shot down by that one fact alone. It is not just this Government that supports it; it is supported by health Ministers around the country.

The States and Territories are cooperating in the planning of the new legislation. New South Wales, the only State with a comprehensive licensing system for manufacturers of therapeutic goods, is investigating transitional arrangements for the transfer of licences to the national system. Again, we have cooperation from New South Wales and from all of the other States. Victoria, the only State that conducts premarket assessments of some therapeutic goods, has agreed that its regulatory machinery, the Proprietary Medicines Advisory Committee, can become part of the national system. Again we are drawing on the experience of the States to ensure that the national system incorporates all of the good things we have in the system at present and at the same time making sure that it is a much more comprehensive system so that consumers can feel confident that therapeutic goods, those made here and those imported, have gone through that testing process.

Model complementary legislation is being prepared by the Commonwealth which, if enacted by the States and Territories, will feed manufacturers and products which lie outside the scope of the Commonwealth legislation into the national system. Once again we have cooperation between the States and the Commonwealth to ensure that the industry benefits. There has been close consultation with industry associations, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) agreed to the release of the current draft Therapeutic Goods Bill to the associations and consumer groups for their input. Once again the Government has consulted with not only the State governments and Ministers for health but also the industry. In general terms, the industry supports the rationalisation of the legislation and the major elements of it. It beats me why, after all this process of consultation not only with State governments but also with the industry itself, we would want to send the legislation to a Senate committee. The mind boggles.

There are very few issues that may still be contentious. These include controls over exported drugs, some aspects of controls over advertising, release of information by the Department of Community Services and Health, and the final fee structure, which will not be decided until after a joint industry-Government committee meets later in the year. Although there are areas that the Government and the Opposition do not always see eye to eye on, I am sure that, with the consultation process that has been set up by the Government and followed through, we can be confident that by the time the legislation becomes operative those processes will have been gone through and consensus will reign.

But it really does beat me why the Opposition takes the stance that it does. It seems to me that the Opposition opposes everything for the sake of opposing it. To send the matter off to a Senate select committee is counterproductive. We have seen these stalling tactics over and over again. How many times have we referred matters like this to a Senate committee only to have the committee come back and endorse what the Government was doing in the first place?

TALK.START.PARA: —Very rarely.

—That shows how closely the honourable member for Lowe follows what happens in the Senate. Why does he not go and have a look? The most recent example, as the honourable member should know, was the general practitioners, when the Senate committee endorsed everything that the Government said. All the Opposition did was delay the general practitioners in getting the fee increase that they should have got. The Opposition delayed it by three months. The general practitioners said, `Thank you very much', but, of course, the specialists would not worry too much about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the legislation. It shows that this Government is doing the sort of things that this country requires of it. It is looking after the consumers not only in matters like therapeutic goods but also in a wide range of issues that this country needs. The citizens of this country can be assured that this Government, after its re-election next year, will go on with the good work that it has been doing in the last seven years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Therapeutic Goods Bill raises many diverse issues. I am sure that there is a recognition by most honourable members that the concept of licensing, registration, listing of products, application of codes, good manufacturing practice and so on is a progressive step. My concern-and I am even more alarmed since listening to the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear)-is that a bureaucracy will be established in this country with enormous power, which will exercise control and charge the manufacturers extraordinary amounts which, in turn, will be passed on to the consumers. A figure of $30m is mentioned. Of course, under the current arrangements, the cost is about $2m.

SPEECH.PARA: I look at the explanatory notes. Perhaps someone who can speak with greater knowledge and skill than I, and trained in the medical world, can throw some light on one matter in the explanatory notes. Part 2 of the explanatory notes, under `Clause 10-Determination of standards', states:

Subclause 10 (1) allows the Minister to declare, by Gazettal of an order, a standard for therapeutic goods or a class of therapeutic goods. Any such standard (commonly known as a Therapeutic Goods Order) takes precedence over a monograph in the British Pharmacopoeia or the British Pharmacopoeia (Veterinary).

I would be very interested to hear some explanation of that. Does it mean that we will have an authority that regards itself as having greater technical and scientific know-how and that this authority will become a means of dictating the operation of all aspects of this field? Therapeutic goods have existed really for many generations. Most of us can recall our family homes and seeing the things that our forebears had on their shelves. A lot of the remedies were not to be scoffed at. They did not have to have all the nonsense of this Bill to determine whether items were something people might find useful, but with the proper warnings. I believe that in those days people were very well sustained health-wise, particularly in the far flung parts of this nation.

It is true that modern technology, research and medicine have produced many life-saving drugs. Let us think of the difficulty confronting the pharmacy industry today because of the enormous hike in the cost of pharmaceuticals. That is what the Government is making such a fuss about at the present time. Is it the intention now to push the usage of therapeutic goods by the community into a similar category so that the costs become so high that people are forced to either pay up or go without? That is really what it will come down to. Let us have some standards, a listing and so on. This is obviously going to take it far beyond that. It is going to make determinations, and those determinations will be very expensive indeed. Many of the old-fashioned usages will either fall by the wayside or be replaced by something else that will, obviously be very expensive.

I am intrigued that the honourable member for Canning had so much to say in his speech. I recall only in the last year or so the honourable member for Canning ridiculing the medical profession, making public utterances unfairly and without substantiation attacking the medical world of this country. I wonder whether his lending of his total support to this legislation in the way that he has is yet again evidence of some collusion that, if we knew the real facts, would suggest that part and parcel of a big brother approach is that we should tell people what is good for them regardless of whether there is a scientific reason to support that advice.

In one approach, so much is embodied in this legislation that it is all-encompassing. It is typical of this Government and what it has done in respect of the health services of this country since it took office to create a bureaucratic monster wherever it can, and, as a consequence, establish an enormously high cost factor, and then expect the public to pay for it. Is that the way to help those families who really have a dependence on many of the things that would come under the heading of therapeutic goods?
