We see these days in health food stores and similar outlets shelves stacked full with all sorts of things that will come under the jurisdiction of this legislation. There is much concern by individuals and families for the environment and for those things they believe are related to nature and what nature has endowed. Will this create a situation where many of these things will begin to get a little beyond their reach? I believe it will. I would have to see a lot of evidence to convince me otherwise.

Australia today is experiencing an enormous wave of enthusiasm for nature, the environment and related things. What is being put to this House tonight seems to me to contradict that course very substantially. It is not appropriate to begin to talk about various specific matters, but I can think of a number of examples in rural areas-in electorates such as my own. Many things are produced-and have been for many years-that come under the heading of therapeutic commodity. Nothing untoward has occurred. There has been recognition of the products and an export trade has been established. One example of such a product is tea-tree oil. There are divergent views as to its value and usefulness, but I find that it has a wide range of applications. Many people have benefited from the use of it. It is now growing into a very substantial industry, one in which a big expansion in export trade is envisaged. In fact, the expansion has begun to occur. Will the Government's net be thrown over it in such a way that it will be impeded? Will its cost factors be jeopardised because of the need for compliance with whatever regulations are to be established under this legislation? The explanatory notes tell us, as I said a moment ago, that the determinations can take precedence over recognised standards that are usually applied to goods of this kind.

I believe that there is sound reason why this legislation should be looked at again. Evidence should be collected from authorities that have the means to advise the Parliament in an effective and practical manner, particularly on the establishment of standards, the way in which those standards should be determined and the subsequent administration of those standards. It is all very well to say that perhaps some risks have been taken but nothing has been put to this House that gives any evidence of that.

In any country a commodity will be produced that comes very close to what I referred to under the heading of the kinds of things that would be covered here-in other words, a subterfuge. Will there be a law to say that that cannot happen? I doubt it. What if somebody comes up with a particular fetish such as we have seen over the years? People have attempted to market-and in fact have marketed-cures for cancer and things of that kind. There have been enormous hoaxes imposed on the community. I would rather see some legislation introduced that provided a means for assessment of things of that sort so that there was a reduction in the element of risk for well meaning people who read in an advertisement or publication a claim that something could be achieved by the use of whatever product it might happen to be. The substance to which I referred a moment ago was manufactured by boiling lantana branches. This was claimed to provide a remedial cure for cancer. Many people paid enormous sums of money a few years ago for the product in the hope that there was some substance to the claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —They all went to Queensland, Ian.

—They did not. I think they all went to Newcastle. Has the Minister heard of taking coal to Newcastle? In all seriousness, we need to protect our community from that sort of thing-from charlatans and others. We do not need to create a bureaucracy merely to impose a cost, to create a division between recognition of what are already well established provisions for checking and on assertion of whether a commodity has a basis of recognition. To establish some new standard without a means of determining what that standard will be, merely on the whim of a section of a department, without any recourse to some higher authority, is the real danger in this legislation. It is for that reason that I believe further scrutiny is necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was with some surprise and, indeed, a great deal of sadness that I listened earlier to the speech by the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). He has a reputation for being a caring member of this House. He is Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and runs that Committee remarkably well. Today, he either misunderstood the position, particularly of the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), or he misrepresented it. The problem that we on this side of the House have is not with the principles of the legislation, nor, indeed, with the need for the legislation; our problem is with the details of the legislation and, in particular, with the absence of any detailed regulations. The Government is yet again asking us to buy a pig in a poke. The industry and the Opposition both support the need for appropriate principles to be established and enforced. But this legislation is not appropriate; it is grossly flawed.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) say some remarkable things. He said, `Regulations are good for you'. It sounds like a new recipe. He also claimed quite incorrectly that this legislation had been examined by the Public Accounts Committee. That is completely false. The principles and the area have certainly been examined by the Public Accounts Committee but this legislation has not been examined by it. He also said, `The increased cost of testing is a good thing'. It does not matter about the increased costs for small businesses; it does not matter about the increased costs for consumers-in this case, of course, the sick in our society; it does not matter about increased bankruptcies or increased exports. He said that increased costs are a good thing. I point out to him that the alternative to not doing it is not to do it at all, but to do it efficiently.

He also made some rather strange remarks in a roundabout sort of way about the fact that there was no central control in Canberra, and then went on to support centralisation of the bureaucracy in Canberra. He also missed the whole point of the matter, which is that the intent of the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 is fine. We are very happy with the intent of the Bill; it is the details of the legislation and regulations with which we have major problems. That is why we wish to refer it to a Senate select committee. I point out in passing that our opposition to this Bill will not necessarily hold up the Bill. It is not scheduled to come into effect until between March and July 1990. There is plenty of time for a Senate select committee to examine the Bill and report back. The Government might be beginning to realise the flaws in this legislation and the fact that the committee is very likely to reject the legislation outright.

It is rather sad to see this sort of legislation. It is the end-of-the-Roman-empire type legislation. It represents the last days of a falling government. I do not know whether the responsibility for this terrible, appalling legislation lies with the public servants, the lawyers or, as in the end where the buck must stop, with the Government. But the Bill is so grossly flawed that it is amazing to see it come before this House. We are being asked, as I say, to buy, sight unseen, a whole host of regulations. In some cases with legislation that does not matter, but this legislation basically comprises regulations with a Bill to support them, not a Bill containing a few regulations to fill in the gaps; the regulations comprise the heart of this Bill. Basically, we do not have them available to us to examine and debate.

We agree with many of the aims of the legislation. We completely support the aim of improving the standards, of the industry and the level of protection to the Consumer. We agree that licences in some form are worth while, that fair controls are appropriate and that uniform regulations and legislation across the States would be beneficial. But there are major problems. On that uniformity question, for example, there are difficulties with advertising. Currently, manufacturers in this area must comply with the Media Council of Australia code. Those who wish to sell their items in New South Wales have to comply with the New South Wales therapeutic goods and cosmetics Acts. Now we have these new regulations, all of which are significantly different. What is the poor manufacturer supposed to do? There are clearly financial impositions, in terms of time and red tape, upon small businesses. The Government keeps on telling us that small businesses may well be the lifeblood of this country's future economy. If that is the case, it is going to be a very anaemic looking economy-even more so, if possible, than it looks at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that is possible.

—I agree with the honourable member for Gippsland. Let us look at the operation of the Bill. I understand that, basically to appease the Victorian Government, the Proprietary Medicines Advisory Committee from Victoria is likely to have a major input into, if not to be the overseeing body for, this Bill. There are major problems with this Committee. In particular, it is vastly inferior to the equivalent New South Wales committee. The industry is very concerned, as is the Opposition, that there is no industry input into this Committee and that the amount of expertise in the Committee is very limited. If the Government is really looking for a committee which is worth while and which works, why not use the New South Wales committee, which is open to representation from industry and has expert advice on it? Clearly Victoria is being bought off politically. Unfortunately, this is at the expense of quality. Clearly in the end there must be only one body in Australia. It is inappropriate to expect the various manufacturers to conform with half a dozen different pieces of legislation. It is bad enough having to try to face up to this option before us now.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the Code of Good Manufacturing Practice just briefly. This will be the basis of the licence to manufacture the goods. We support the high standards that this requires, but effectively this is just more red tape and is considered by ourselves and by virtually the whole of the industry involved to be excessive. It will be an extra stratum on top of the United Kingdom (UK) European Community and the United States of America requirements as well as the World Health Organisation requirements. Surely it must be possible to integrate the two, three or four, or however many countries we are looking at exporting to, to make sure that the imposition upon manufacturers, importers and exporters is not as great as at present. Surely it should not be beyond the legislators to organise that appropriately.

One of the major problem areas that we have concerns the question of fees. The Government has stated, I believe, that 50 per cent of the costs will be recoverable. These amount to some $15m in costs imposed on what is really still-although it is rapidly expanding-a small industry. If we compare these fees, for example, with the UK costs, the latter are #1,000 in the first place and then #500 per annum, whereby in Australia for a full licence the equivalent cost will be $13,000 every single year. Not much will happen in every single year. In every single year after the first year somebody will press a little button on a computer and say `Yes, it is the same as last year-$13,000. Thank you very much'. It is all in keeping with the imposition of taxes and extra financial burdens on industry and individuals that always comes from this Government.

The effect of this will be an extra cost upon, in the first place, the companies involved and, in the second place, upon the consumers. The Government has made it very clear-and the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), I believe, has stated-that it expects that the extra costs will be passed on to the consumer. First of all, we will have decreased international competitiveness. As the honourable member for Tangney pointed out, this is one of our boom industries in terms of exports. The cost to the Government is often just a question of pushing a computer button. The value to the industry is almost zilch in most cases. Very little service will be offered by the Government for these exorbitant fees and there will be no relationship between the fees charged and the service offered. This relationship was one of the recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee, which the Government is so keen on citing. We should bear in mind, of course, that the industry already pays corporate taxes. The fees will result in an increased number of bankruptcies in an industry area that we need to encourage, not discourage.

This is a terrible piece of legislation. If these fees are essential why not, for example, have exemptions as appropriate or give a greater differential of fees with some relationship to the type of service offered, again as recommended by the Public Accounts Committee? For example, why are products which have been on the market for years, and which are absolutely safe and have never had any problems at all, to be re-evaluated at enormous cost to manufacturers, importers and exporters when clearly it will be no advantage to the manufacturer, exporter or consumer. The only advantage is to the Government in the money it will rake in. Clearly these extra fee impositions are revenue raisers-from the highest taxing Australian Government known to mankind. The fees include such nonsense as an evaluation fee for the exemption; an application fee for registration; an evaluation fee for the registration; and an inspection fee for the registration. There is an application fee for the licence and an inspection fee for the licence. This is in spite of the fact that the Public Accounts Committee said that all such registration fees should be minimal. These are not once off; they are annual fees-year in, year out. They represent more taxes upon, in the end, the consumer and upon the industry involved.

Supposedly the Government, as I said earlier, is recouping only 50 year cent of cost. That may be acceptable if it were 50 per cent of the costs that were appropriate and necessary. These sorts of fees are inappropriate and unnecessary and are an imposition. The Government should not be proud of recovering only 50 per cent of them when those fees are, on the whole, unnecessary.

We have very little confidence in the ability of the Department involved to actually do the testing properly. I have in front of me countless examples of inefficiencies from the Department. One springs to mind as a good example-or a bad example, whichever way one looks at it-of the incompetence of the Department under the Minister's control. It relates to a device called a Medis infuser pump. There are mark 1 and mark 2 versions which are very similar. They are imported by a small company called Medical Specialities Australia. I know the director of this company. She has worked very hard to get a small company off the ground and now, after years of work, is just beginning to see the company expanding its activities to the benefit of not only herself but also Australia. This pump basically allows ambulant patients to remain ambulant-and therefore again save the Government money, because the patients do not have to be hospitalised-while they receive drugs of various types rather than being tied to a bed by an intravenous drip.

The Minister said that there were limitations in the design of the pump-this is the mark 1 version-but that since it was inexpensive the Department had decided to pass it. This was in writing from the Minister. It seems to me to be crazy. Either the thing is good or it is bad. The fact that it does not cost a great deal surely should not influence the decision as to whether it is safe to be allowed to be used on the Australian public.

Clearly this device is absolutely safe. It is widely used overseas for literally thousands of patients. It has been tested in the United Kingdom and the United States of America. It has been tested and proven by the stringent criteria available in those countries and has been tested in Australian public hospitals. In this situation, why can we not accept the stringent criteria of the United States and the European Community? One leading hospital biophysician in this area, having tested the pump and having said that he thought it was an excellent device and completely safe, was told by the medical devices and dental products evaluator not to put his approval of the product in writing because of the politics of the evaluation. That is the trouble. This is a very good pump which is very worth while. There has been an extreme amount of evaluation going on-completely beyond what was necessary. The pump has been proven overseas and an almost identical pump has been proven in Australia. Yet we are going through the red tape, the bureaucracy and the expense to the company and, in the end, the consumer of the unnecessary evaluation of this very worthwhile device. There are too many politics in this area. There is too much money grabbing, too much regulation and too much central control. As I said, we support reasonable controls, but these controls are interfering and unreasonable. We do not want red tape or this gross interference and we do not want the money grabbing.

Another area causes me some concern. In my profession prior to entering Parliament I had quite a lot to do, both directly and indirectly, with the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). Because of that, I have enormous respect for that organisation. I understand from the explanatory memorandum that this organisation will be responsible for the drugs and poisons part of this legislation. The problem is that, for all its wonderful reputation, the NHMRC is not known for its understanding of industrial problems or for its sympathy towards industry. It is entirely inappropriate that the drugs and poisons part of this legislation should be governed by a body such as the NHMRC, which is not representative, which has no industry input, and which on the whole is not accountable, when there are virtually no good appeal mechanisms against its decisions.

I might also mention in passing that this Bill gives formal recognition to the NHMRC in a somewhat backdoor sort of way. If the Government wants to recognise it, that is fine; we can discuss that separately. But if that is to done in a formal way, why not introduce the legislation separately rather than by this back handed sort of way?

In regard to the NHMRC committee, it would be much more appropriate, surely, to have a separate committee and to have the NHMRC as part of that committee, to have industry representatives on that committee and to have an adequate appeals mechanism. The current appeals mechanism is to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. August body though it may be, it has no expertise in these particular areas and it seems entirely inappropriate to me that, in an area which needs great expertise, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal should be the sole arbiter. Surely there should be a separate appeals mechanism set up which will allow for experts in the area to adjudicate upon points of difference, as there almost certainly will be with the NHMRC's decisions.

There are all sorts of problems with this Bill which I have covered before. One of the problems is that it has not been thought through carefully enough. I have to say, of course, that this is typical of this Ministry, the Ministry which is known for half-truths, which bases, for example, the pharmacy problems upon very flawed data and propaganda and which resorts to insulting the members of that valuable profession. Will it resort now to insulting another group, the hospital and other manufacturers of therapeutic goods in this country, who will not toe the left wing socialist line? The things that are flawed at the moment are all related to this Minister's management. This particular Bill clearly will not improve the standards of the industry. It will increase the costs to both patients and taxpayers. It will not increase the protection of the consumer. It will send many of our small businesses bankrupt. It will decrease our overseas competitiveness. It will clearly reduce our exports. This flawed Bill should be withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to make a few comments to correct some of the statements that have been made. Firstly, the draft regulations have been developed. In fact, a set was sent--
—Where are they?
—A set was sent to the Opposition shadow Minister about a week ago.
—There are 148 members in here. What about the rest of them?

—They were sent to him. He does not seem to know that they are there, either. Secondly, Australia is not reinventing the wheel with this legislation. The Department is developing bilateral and multilateral agreements, especially in the exchange of product evaluation and good manufacturing practice inspection reports. That is a very important process, as people would recognise in an international environment, not only for ease of improving the processing of products through the system but also to ensure that we have an international system that we can work on in a trade environment as well. This is an administrative matter and not something that is dealt with in the legislation. Thirdly, the products already legally on the market will not be automatically re-evaluated. However, the legislation does allow review if current evidence indicates that there is a problem and it is necessary. It was also claimed that the codes of good manufacturing practice are imposed without consultation. That is simply not so. The codes are developed jointly with industry in the process which is occurring now with the revision of those codes.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now deal with the comments about lack of consultation. On several occasions the Opposition has claimed that there has been a lack of consultation over this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —So has industry.

—The comment quoted from the Public Accounts Committee report was a reference to preliminary development of the proposals in 1986, not to the development of the current Bill. In fact, a detailed proposal on the legislation was released publicly back in October 1988, which is a good 12 months ago now. In May this year a later update was issued, a draft of the Bill was released to industry, consumer groups and the States and the instructions for the regulations were also released for comment. Wide consultations were held. I believe that the Bill reflects those discussions. I think it is interesting that some members have commented about the industry's lack of consultation. I think it is fair to say that if it is all summed up, not too many pieces of legislation in relation to governing an industry have gone through such a rigorous but nonetheless very positive process as this Bill has.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not aware of any requests to the Department, where a consultation has been turned down, whether it was for a personal meeting, telephone discussion or participation in seminars. If honourable members opposite really had a wide understanding of the industry and a wide contact with the industry, as the Department certainly has, I think they would find that this Bill has received a very high degree of acceptance. It is noteworthy that, although the Opposition claimed that it has concerns about lack of consultation, it did not actually take up the opportunity to get a briefing on this Bill from the Department.

Let me turn now to the issue of cooperation with the States and the Territories, because this is something that has been talked about in terms of overlap, duplication and such things. The real fact of the matter is that under legislation such as this, which involves all the States, over the life of the Federation of this country, although overlaps and duplications have occurred, there has also been a hideous number of gaps, and it is through those gaps that many problems have occurred. If there is a slight degree of overlap and duplication, particularly in the case of the Victorian legislation, that is nothing compared with the multiplicity of duplication and overlap that has occurred in the past. But within a short time even that will have been removed and we will have a national system of assessment of therapeutic goods regulations, not an additional system. In fact, it is for that reason that the Commonwealth has at all stages provided detailed information to State and Territory governments. I am very pleased to confirm that all States and Territories have indicated that they will participate in this national scheme. The States and Territories recommended that the Commonwealth draft complementary legislation. Such a draft has been prepared and, in the near future, it is expected to be referred to the parliamentary counsel committee.

Victoria has agreed that the Victorian Proprietary Medicines Committee will function as part of the national system. I think that shows the tremendous level of cooperation that has been able to develop in this highly complex, highly technical, highly innovative and rapidly progressing area. I congratulate all the officers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have they seen the regulations?

—Yes, they have seen the drafts of those. I congratulate the officers in all States and Territories, particularly those in my Department, on the work that they have carried out. I also congratulate the Ministers on making sure that it has been carried out as quickly as it has. An Opposition member-I am not sure who-said Victoria may not change its legislation until spring 1990. That does not mean that Victoria cannot participate in the national system before then. I think that needs to be understood.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that Liberal-National Party members in this House will always talk about over-regulation. But as my friend and colleague the honourable member for Charlton and Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) would be well aware, they talk a lot about it but they have never done terribly much about it. This Government has been quite willing and obviously quite able to embark upon deregulation in many areas and to improve in many areas of micro-economic reform the industrial system in Australia.

The much cited Business Regulation Review Unit report must be fundamentally questioned. When we are talking about such things as therapeutic goods and devices, we are talking about medicines that people take and devices and appliances that people have to use on a day to day basis in dealing with their lives, health and safety, and such a report must be fundamentally questioned when it starts from the premise that a problem is substantiated only if identifiable deaths occur. My goodness, do we have to get to that stage before some action is taken? That would be grossly irresponsible. We have seen enough problems in the past in this area. It is bad enough that from time to time some things can slip through. Certainly, there needs to be as much effort as possible to reduce the damage to an individual's health. Any risk of death must be clearly identified and action taken to overcome that.

I refer honourable members to the excellent, very articulate and very well educated points made by my colleague the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) and the detailed investigations of the Public Accounts Committee, which he chaired. There is no doubt that the Public Accounts Committee was of the view that there are serious problems in the industry which must be addressed. I praise all members of that Committee from both sides of this House for the work they put into the report. I am very pleased to be in a position to have so much of the report incorporated in this legislation.

As far as regulations are concerned, I think the industry overall-there may be many small examples of it-is very pleased with this legislation and recognises its value to Australia in developing an internationally competitive environment and an internationally respected environment for therapeutic goods and devices.

As far as fees and charges are concerned, it is extremely disappointing that the whole thrust of the Opposition's comments is to place costs on industry before any consideration of public health. That is a shame. It is in conflict with what the public would believe, and they are the people being served by the manufacturers, by the Government and by this legislation. It is those people whose health is to be protected. The Cabinet's decision on fees and charges is extremely fair. Fifty per cent of the costs, rather than 100 per cent, are to be recovered from the industry. It is worthwhile noting-it has certainly been noted by industry-that setting up a government-industry consultative committee to advise the Minister on the scale of fees and their utilisation within the therapeutic goods program is a very positive step in terms of the relationship between industry, the Department of Community Services and Health and government. That will be a very valuable addition to the area of therapeutic goods and their regulation.

I thank all honourable members who participated in the debate. I congratulate and thank the Public Accounts Committee of this Parliament on the work it put into this matter over a period. People who are on those committees do a lot of work. They go all around the place and spend long hours working to get consensus and agreement on the reports. Much of that has been reflected in this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Throughout debate on the Therapeutic Goods Bill 1989 and amendments moved by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), the Opposition has played a very constructive role. It has sought to accommodate the Minister, although we have our points of difference. However, we very much regret that the same sort of constructive role has not been played by the Minister in the pharmacy dispute, which he has deliberately inflamed by painting pharmacists throughout this country as greedy, self-serving monetarists. For that reason, whilst the Opposition cooperates in this matter, we ask that the Minister take a far more fair-minded approach to what is becoming a very bitter, divisive dispute within our community. It is affecting pharmacists, their families and their clientele. It is outrageous that this Minister is treating the pharmacists in this fashion.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, I rise on a point of order. The honourable member for Gippsland knows full well that this is totally irrelevant to the Bill. It is certainly totally irrelevant to the committee stage of the Bill. It is typical of the sorts of stunts he carries out in this House. I believe he is totally out of order.
—I presume that the point of order is about relevance. I call the honourable member for Gippsland and ask him to return to the Bill.
—On that point of order regarding relevance, again the Minister shows the sort of thug-like approach that he has taken to this pharmacy dispute and I ask--
—I ask the honourable member for Gippsland to return to the Bill or resume his seat.

—In drawing to a conclusion, the Opposition wishes to cooperate with the Minister in the passage of these amendments. All we ask in return is that he show the same sort of sense of restraint and cooperation in regard to the pharmacists dispute.
—Mr Deputy Chairman, I rise to a point of order. The point of order that I raised before has simply been ignored by the honourable member for Gippsland.

—I do not ask the Minister to raise a point of order but I am aware of the fact that the honourable member for Gippsland, while on his feet, used terms when referring to the Minister that I regard as unreasonable. I ask him to withdraw.

—Certainly, Mr Deputy Chairman, although I do make the point--
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw unreservedly.
—I withdraw unreservedly, but I was not describing the Minister as a thug. I only said that his behaviour in regard to pharmacists was thug-like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief in this committee stage. I have laboured under the practical human difficulties, since making my speech in the second reading debate, of not being able to be in two places at one time. Hence, I have not been here for the comments of the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples). Simply put, the amendments have been moved by the Government and we will not oppose them. We will not be dividing or voting on them. That is consistent with what I said during the second reading debate. I imagine that the Minister was labouring under the same problems because he was not here to hear my remarks. If he was not able to hear them on the blower, I hope that he and the Government will consider them carefully because we did enter into this debate with very good bona fides and have clearly stated-if not exhaustively, certainly extensively-the problems we have with this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We have given the Government plenty of notice about our intended plan of action in the Senate-that is, to oppose the passage of the Therapeutic Goods Bill at this time and to seek its referral to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I say to the Minister that, as with the vocational register and its handling by a Senate select committee on that occasion, if the Committee is given reporting dates, it is quite likely that we could still see the Committee report back to the Senate in plenty of time for the Government, if it is still the government at that stage, to be able to meet the starting date of this legislation, which is March 1990. I hope that the Government will take a very constructive attitude to the way in which this Bill is handled in the Senate. I hope also that, on this occasion and on all future occasions, so far as the health portfolio and so far as my working relationship with the Government are concerned, the Government will learn that the Opposition will not support legislation that is very much dependent upon regulations.

As I said in my contribution earlier today, there has been an about-face in the health portfolio in recent times. Normally legislation has attendant upon it some regulations that provide some administrative arrangements or perhaps plug a few gaps here and there. However, in at least two major pieces of legislation relating to the health portfolio the reverse has been the case. The Parliament has been presented with enabling legislation which is pretty innocuous, but the real guts of the Bill-if I can use that vernacular phrase-is to be found in the regulations. It is quite unreasonable for the Government to expect us to pass legislation on a wing and a prayer, as it were, without being able to see the regulations. I simply make that point and hope that a constructive debate will take place in the Senate where the numbers are a little more finely balanced. I hope also that we will be successful in referring the legislation to a responsible Senate committee which, at the end of the day, carries a Government majority but, importantly, provides for consultation and communication with the industry.

As I came back into the chamber I managed to catch the tail end of the remarks of the Minister for Housing and Aged Care when he was speaking about the extensive consultation with industry. I do not doubt that the Minister has received extensive submissions from industry and that he, his Department and his ministerial office have sought advice from industry. However, I wish to make two points about consultation. Firstly, even in the dying months of this Government's administration it must make an effort to reach out into the wider areas of industry groups and not simply content itself with dealing with matters that it might feel comfortable with. In other circles these are known as the peak groups or peak forums. If the Minister's attention is drawn to my speech during the second reading debate he will learn that hundreds of very small firms in this country which, with the right encouragement and environment, may grow to be big firms. Those small firms are largely unrepresented. They do not belong to organisations such as Australian Medical Devices and Diagnostics Association Inc. or similar organisations. The Government should make an effort to ascertain the effect of its intended legislation on the grass roots version of industry. Secondly, I make a very fundamental point that consultation does not occur when, following the receipt of advice, that advice is refused. Consultation is genuine only if there is a bit of give and take and a bit of understanding shown.

I reaffirm that the principle of the legislation is first class and is not contested by the Opposition. As part of the maturation of this country we will move towards a more uniform and more national code of practice in this whole area. I believe that that will be achieved only by the Government playing a more cooperative role with the States. I spelt all of that out during my speech in the second reading debate. I do not believe that the Government is going about this in the most appropriate way to achieve the success that it is looking for. Hopefully the Opposition can assist the Government by moving in the way that it will be moving in the Senate.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.
