DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1989[COGNATE BILL:CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING) BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 October, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill concurrently with the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the House are two anti-dumping Bills which were introduced on 5 October. They are the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1989 and the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989. They are companion Bills which seek to make amendments and effect a restructuring of the Government's anti-dumping legislation which is contained in three Acts, namely, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act of 1975, the Anti-Dumping Authority Act of 1988 and the Customs Act of 1901.

SPEECH.PARA: Anti-dumping measures in Australia were originally incorporated in the Australian Industries Preservation Act of 1906. Later, anti-dumping measures were included in the Customs Tariff (Industries Preservation) Act 1921, the Customs Tariff (Dumping and Subsidies) Act 1961 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975. No doubt the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who takes an intense and keen interest in legislation surrounding the issue of dumping because of his desire to protect the interests of his constituents, particularly those involved in the citrus juice industry, will be somewhat familiar-although I suspect not intimately familiar-with all of the provisions of the preceding Acts.

These Bills seek firstly to remove any difficulties that might arise as a result of the High Court's deliberations during the Air Caledonie case. This is done by transferring sections of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 to the Customs Act of 1901 by repealing them under the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1989 and effecting the transfer through the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill. I suspect that radios throughout Australia are being turned off at this stage. However, I do make the point that the listing of the legislation and a detailing of the mechanics surrounding the changes to the principal heads of legislation is very important. I feel very sorry for those listeners to the parliamentary broadcast who do not have as detailed or as intimate a knowledge of or interest in this complex legislation as do members such as the honourable member for Farrer.

The High Court decision in the Air Caledonie International v. The Commonwealth case, which arose when the Government sought to impose a `fee for immigration clearance' in respect of international airline passengers entering Australia, dealt at length with section 55 of the Constitution. Section 55 provides that laws imposing taxation deal only with the imposition of taxation. It was considered in the past that the prohibition on mixing taxing and non-taxing Acts was not infringed when an Act dealing only with the imposition of customs duties amended a principal Act which contained provisions concerning non-customs duty matters. The High Court, as a result of the decision in this 1988 case, now construes section 55 as extending to laws in the form in which they stand from time to time, after amendment, with the requirement that such laws deal only with the imposition of taxation or duties of customs.

As it was considered by the Government that some problems could arise due to this decision, the restructuring of this legislation is being proposed to ensure that laws imposing duties of customs are in separate Acts from laws dealing with non-duty matters. Consequently we have the first Bill, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1989 which repeals a plethora of current sections. The second of the Bills before the house this evening is the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989. This Bill is the vehicle used for transferring to the Customs Act 1901 the sections repealed from the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1989. I very much fear that at this very point we lose the few remaining listeners we have to this parliamentary broadcast.

This Bill also proposes to make a substantive legislative change. The Government is seeking through this legislation to allow a profit margin to be included in the matters considered when a normal value is being construed. I do make the point, though, that this will not apply where sales in the country of export have been at a loss for an extended period. This is a very important matter to members of the National Party of Australia and to our coalition Liberal Party members representing rural areas, because dumping is a fundamental concern to a whole range of agricultural industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —And manufacturing.
—And manufacturing, too. I happily stand corrected by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business.
—On this occasion only.

—As the honourable member for Farrer says, on this occasion only. Dumping occurs when the export price is less than the normal value of goods in the domestic market of the country of export-a definition you yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker, would know only too well. Sometimes, because the goods are not sold on the domestic market of the exporting country or because of a centrally planned economy, the normal value on the home market is not available and therefore a normal value has to be constructed. Normal values are constructed under section 5 (2) (c) or 5 (4) of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. According to the second reading speech of the Minister-a best seller at the time-it was the Government's intention last year in amending three provisions of the current section 5 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 that a profit could be included in circumstances specified in regulations to the Act. I should note that this was part of the same legislative package which last year created the Anti-Dumping Authority. After that Authority was established in September, the Government referred to it the matter of the regulations which were to prescribe the circumstances where a profit component should be included, must be included, in the normal value constructions or, in the words of the Minister, in his letter to the Anti-Dumping Authority dated 24 November 1988:

SPEECH.PARA: When the recent changes to Australia's anti-dumping legislation were made, Section 5 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 was amended so as to provide that when constructing a normal value a profit component is to be included only in circumstances identified by Regulation.
It is now necessary to establish those circumstances . . .

This action was also taken against a background of the Gruen review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 and preceded the amending legislation passed in the Parliament last year. The Government decided to reject Professor Gruen's recommendation that section 5 (9) of the Act be repealed. This legislation is a result of the findings of the Authority in regard to this and other matters. The Authority noted in its deliberations on the issue of including a profit margin:

The Authority is convinced that it was never the Government's intention that a profit not be included when constructing a normal value in non-section 5 (9) cases. It believes that it has the general support of all areas of the business community for the inclusion of a profit in such cases. . .

This quote from the Authority's report No. 4 brings me to mention the section 5 (9) exception which, against the Gruen recommendation, the Government decided to retain in totality but in a tightened form. Section 5 (9) deems the occasion when sales are not in the ordinary course of trade. A similar provision is also used in the United States, Canada and the European Economic Community, and is in accord with article 6 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and article 2 (4) of the GATT anti-dumping code. The Authority looked at the construction of a normal value in the cases where section 5 (9) has been invoked. In examining the extent to which normal values were constructed, Professor Gruen found that of the various ways in which a normal value could be determined, only 15 out of a total of 176 instances, being 8.5 per cent, resulted from section 5 (9) being invoked. According to the Authority, the Australian Customs Service has advised that this ratio has changed little. The Authority stated on page 29 of its report:
. . . There is a strong argument for never including a profit when section 5 (9) has been invoked and a normal value is being constructed under section 5 (2) (c).
It continued:

One of the criteria under section 5 (9) is that the goods must have been sold at a price below the cost to make and sell them. If the goods were sold at a price exactly equal to the cost to make and sell them-(i.e. at a profit level of zero)-then section 5 (9) could not be invoked. Providing the other requirements of section 5 (1) were met, the selling price would be recognised as the normal value for the purpose of a dumping inquiry.

The Authority concluded that after conducting a number of dumping inquiries it might be possible to identify some circumstances in which a profit margin could be included in section 5 (9) cases, but recommended that at this stage a profit margin should not be included.

It also raised matters concerning effecting the transfer of a number of minor amendments, concerning the following matters: the publication of details relating to undertakings; the ability to partially revoke notices and partially release a person from an undertaking; to allow for securities for a breech of an undertaking; and to make clear the power of the Comptroller-General of customs to reject applications under section 269tc.

The Opposition is accepting the recommendation of the Authority and this legislation along the same lines as the Authority made its recommendation in regard to section 5 (9)-that is, at this stage. We accept the recommendation of the Authority at this stage. Before very long the coalition parties will return to government and we will then review the existing dumping arrangements. We will also review the effectiveness of the Anti-Dumping Authority, we will simplify the legislative provisions, and we will ensure adequate resources are available to Customs to enable speedy resolution of dumping complaints.

The reforms are absolutely necessary and long overdue and they stand as testimony to this Government's failure to implement reform in a micro-economic sense; that is, this Government will not tackle reform of industry on a specific basis. Instead, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) employs one arm and one arm only of government economic policy, being, of course, monetary policy. The Treasurer fails to address either fiscal policy or wages policy in a way that will bring about productivity and efficiency in this period of Australia's economic stagnation. Moreover, Government members run as fast as their cowardly little legs will take them from micro-economic reform whether on the waterfront, with coastal shipping, or the issues surrounding privatisation. The Government will not face its responsibilities. How then can industry-let alone primary industry-maintain a competitive edge on corrupted world markets when its own competitive edge at home is either hindered or in no way assisted by government?

The legislation before the House is of tremendous importance in bringing about micro-economic reform. Sadly, it is a little too late. Moreover, it is just too little. The fact is that unless the Government has the courage, the determination and the vision to bring about extensive micro-economic reform, this country will continue, sadly, to have record balance of payments figures, galloping inflation, increasing unemployment and record interest rates. We can consider the legislation tonight in the midst of a falling economic policy which does not merely threaten to crush the Government, but is actually crushing the Government with its weight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill and the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill. I guess there is no greater concern for primary industries today than the fear that they will be ruined by a flood of cheap imported products. This fear is born of a genuine concern that in Australia we are breaking down protectionist trade barriers. At the same time, our farmers know of and see only too well a wall of protectionism in the European Community, the United Kingdom and some of our Asian trading partners. Their argument goes: why should we break down our defences when other countries are not doing so? We are leaving ourselves open to ruin from the dumping of surplus subsidised products. Their other concern is the time lag between reporting a case of dumping and the time taken to see whether dumping is occurring.

SPEECH.PARA: In the second reading speech, the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) says that the second substantive proposal in the Bill is aimed at implementing the Government's recent decision announced on 10 September on the inclusion of a profit margin when the normal value of goods is being constructed. As we know, dumping occurs when the price at which goods are exported to Australia is less than normal value of the goods in the country of export. This normal value is usually just the price of the goods in the domestic market of the country. However, a problem arises in some instances when goods are produced only for export. The normal value must then be obtained in some other way. These Bills set out to address that problem.

In my electorate the fear of dumping has not been restricted to primary producers. Some genuine concerns were raised two years ago about the possible dumping of cement. The industry and the Government worked through that problem. I now appeal to the Government to continue to be vigilant in the pursuit of dumping when it comes to primary production. It was this fear that the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology during its inquiry into the sugar industry found was uppermost in the minds of sugar growers. The Senate inquiry was told that there is a delay of up to 12 weeks before information can be provided in respect of imports. The Committee's reports states:

This delay limits severely the ability of refiners to monitor trends and provide relevant up-to-date information to Customs Authorities in support of a dumping complaint. By comparison, in New Zealand, statistics are available from the Customs Department on a weekly basis 10-12 days after the end of the week to which the statistics relate.

The Committee noted that very few companies are likely to be major importers. Because such industries are large and well-known, potential importers of dumped sugar are unlikely to get away with doing so without strong protest from those likely to be affected adversely. An aspect of the inquiry report concerns me and I ask the Minister to take note of it. The report states:
It is worth noting that the Australian Customs Service told the Committee that there may well be difficulties in establishing a dumping case in respect of the sugar industry.
This appears to contradict the earlier assurances, but the Committee nevertheless recommended:
If deficiencies are alleged the Government should investigate them, and if necessary, amend the anti-dumping legislation.
I press the point that advice given by the Australian Customs Service to the Committee is answered in these Bills.

There are two other concerns at the moment with respect to dumping. I refer to the pineapple industry, where there are reports of cheap imported pineapples flooding the markets and destroying the viability of farmers. In my electorate I have received no personal representations, but the association concerned is making a very public campaign, supported by the National Party of Australia. Both Senator Ron Boswell and the National Party State Primary Industries Minister, Mark Stoneman, have shown an ignorance of bilateral and multilateral trade. They have continually demanded that a high protective barrier be put up to stop the import of pineapples and at the same time said that Australia needs access to more world markets. It is important to recognise that if we take that track and put up protective barriers we undo the very gains that we are making and the very proposition that the Nationals are putting up would be realised.

I urge the Minister to monitor the situation continually to ensure that our producers are not the victims of a flooding of dumped products because I have always believed that on a fair playing field we can not only match, but also beat the world and we are achieving that. We are achieving it in a meaningful way this year with a win at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) negotiations. All the reports I have seen so far, though, lead me to believe that the greatest howls of protect in regard to pineapples are coming from the Golden Circle cannery. In 1981, Golden Circle rejected a request by G. J. Coles to package pineapple under Coles' Farmland label and insisted that it would market products only under its own brand label.

Coles and other supermarket chains subsequently placed orders with overseas suppliers who were prepared to meet its requirements. Canned pineapple imports are not significant in the total domestic market and in 1987-88 represented approximately 13 per cent of the total canned pineapple market. In spite of the imports, Golden Circle, the sole Australian producer, processed a record tonnage of pineapples in the cannery year ending 30 November 1988. Australian consumption of canned pineapples has been rising steadily in recent years and Golden Circle has maintained its market share against import penetration. The decision of Golden Circle not to participate in sales with supermarket chains may have been a major factor in the import of canned pineapples. I would appreciate it, though, if the Minister would undertake a continuing scrutiny of the situation, as I am sure he will, to ensure that our pineapple producers are not the unwilling victims of both dumping and the paranoia of the Queensland National Party.

Finally, I mention also the need for continual monitoring of the situation with Canadian pork meat. Producers are concerned about two aspects: the fear of subsidised imported product and fear of the disease, transmissible gastroenteritis. Of these, the former is within the ambit of the Bill. The industry fears that the pig meat industry will be badly damaged by subsidised Canadian competition. As I understand it, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) had modelled possible outcomes and has concluded that imports from Canada will probably not exceed 17,000 tonnes per annum and may average 12,000 tonnes per annum. This also depends upon the exchange rates and in some years there may be no importation whatsoever. This compares with the domestic production of roughly 300,000 tonnes. Of course, the quantity varies, as I said, with the exchange rate. I ask the Minister to assess whether the ABARE model is holding up over time.

Most producers are confident that they are efficient enough to beat fair competition. I support that proposition totally. They also understand that if we win at the GATT talks, as we did with US sugar quotas and with the Korean beef deal, we have to have free markets. Our producers gain by free trade. As the overwhelming percentage of Australian farm product is exported, Australian farmers have more to lose from high tariff protection than any other nation. That is why I fail to understand the attitude of some of my opponents in Queensland who have a different story for every audience. At the end of the day they have to represent the whole agricultural industry. We cannot quarantine one industry and put at risk the total Australian agricultural production. We have proved continually, with GATT this year and with the breakthroughs we are making in the United States-and those breakthroughs will impact on the EEC-that we are going to win.

The other aspect in regard to the pig industry is that until now growers have looked only to the Australian market. I put this proposition to the House: because, until now, Australian growers have supplied only the Australian market, there has never been a requirement-financial or otherwise-to look to exports. Now that we are importing Canadian pig meat, producers are saying that there may be an export market there. Certainly we will have a look for it. It is said that necessity is the mother of invention. This may well prove to be the case in this industry. A small industry that is producing 300,000 tonnes of meat may well be able to double production and gain access to the Asian markets. As we know, in Asia pig meat is very popular. All primary industries need to assess export opportunities. Exports improve our economy and the viability of farmers.

The great powers of the world have the economic and military muscle, yet they lack the intestinal fortitude that goes with free trade. As we all know, Australians have been laid to rest all over the free world where we fought for freedom and I believe that if we have to raise continually the fact that we can stand on our own feet in free trade and embarrass the EEC and Japan we should continue to do just that. They pride themselves on being tough, yet when it comes to agriculture they are trade cowards. We should continually raise that point. In my view they are not just in the short term looking after their own political interests, they are downgrading their own agricultural industries. By protection, by covering them up, they are creating inefficiencies, just as a child who is locked up in a house and is not allowed to get out into the real environment becomes socially deficient.

By our free trade, by the initiatives of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, and by the initiatives of the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), we have created the toughest, the most effective and the most commercial agricultural base this country has ever seen. I compliment the Minister once again for the wise and tough decisions he has made to oppose dumping. Logically and rationally we must work through the problems other countries impose on us by dumping their goods onto our markets without putting at risk the free trade position we must maintain if we are to continually have not only a viable but also an expanding agricultural industry. I think that that is the most positive argument we have to offer. we not only wish to maintain our present agricultural base but also, as we have so much to gain, we must gain access to more world markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot to offer, too.

—As the honourable member opposite says, we have a lot to offer. The potential is there. We can achieve it. The `it's all right, we don't need to change' attitude has affected us. When we have been on the front foot we have done well. The sugar industry is a classic example. We would have the potential today to export another half a billion dollars worth of sugar if we took the brave step of deregulating the industry and producing more cane. That applies to many other products. Perhaps in 50 years time it will be recognised that the decisions that have been taken on free trade by Australia and the position we have taken at GATT through the Uruguay rounds have been the most far-reaching in agriculture since the industrial revolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with much of the argument advanced by the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and with all of his sentiments. Unfortunately, for reasons I will try to make clear, he has arrived at a wrong conclusion in his support for the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill and the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill. This legislation proposes amendments to legislation which was enacted by the Parliament only last year. The principal Act established the Anti-Dumping Authority to coordinate the Government approach to dumping complaints. Some of the amendments in this legislation incorporate provisions which might be construed as taxation measures more relevant to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act rather than to the anti-dumping legislation, presumably to avoid possible legal challenge under section 55 of the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: These changes are largely procedural, and are not a matter of controversy, although they do add to a growing list of government legislation which has been the subject of very poor drafting. Such drafting problems are then the subject of ad hoc amendments in the Parliament which are often retrospective in their effects and fail to address the fundamental errors in the construction of the legislation in the first place.

I point out that if the Commonwealth was not stretching the limits of its constitutional powers, many of these examples of contorted drafting and hurried error would not be made. However, there is no question about the powers of the Commonwealth over industry protection and dumping. Objections to the Government's approach in these areas are largely economic. The dumping issue and the issue of protectionism are intimately and irrevocably linked.

Anti-dumping legislation is a form of protection of local industry. The only debate is over whether this protection is justified. I will argue that anti-dumping legislation is neither a sensible nor a justified form of protection. It follows that the second element of this legislation, which in part extends the protective effects of the calculation of the `normal price' for dumped goods, is not justified.

The attitude of this Labor Government to anti-dumping has been confused and contradictory. On the one hand it commissioned Professor Gruen to review the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975. He opposed the use of anti-dumping legislation as a measure of industry assistance, and recommended that the scope of such legislation should be restricted. In rhetoric used in the Parliament and to those who are usually opposed to protection, the Government has insisted that its approach to anti-dumping was to avoid its use as a form of protection, restricting the scope of legislation to unfair trading practices, to use its words.

However, we find that the Government has allowed industry leaders to think that tough anti-dumping legislation can be a trade-off for reductions in the levels of industry protection. It is not surprising that the highest numbers of dumping complaints over the years have been made by the most heavily protected industries in Australia. Some companies see dumping duties as just another tool to defeat international competition. Such duties loom as a desirable form of protection for companies because they are decided by administrative means in particular cases and do not impose across-the-board tariffs which, when applied to components or other imports, might add to a company's cost structure. However, the costs to consumers and quite often the taxpayer are possibly greater for anti-dumping measures than for any other form of protection. Not only is the price of the goods concerned effectively increased to much higher levels, but also the Government loses revenue as foreign companies increase prices to the Australian consumer to avoid the penalties arising from a successful dumping complaint. The procedure adds uncertainty to both people seeking to trade with Australia and Australian firms who are supplied by overseas companies.

When the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) introduced last year the legislation establishing an anti-dumping authority, he seemed to acknowledge in his second reading speech the risk that dumping complaints could be misused. He then issued a press release inviting industry, unions and farmers to use the `tough' new laws which would effectively ensure `fair competition'. The Government wants it both ways. Given the divergence in what the Government says on this issue, we should judge it by what it does.

It would seem that the number of dumping complaints has declined from 100 in 1982-83 to 28 in 1987-88. The number of times that duties have been imposed from these complaints has declined from 42 in 1982-83 to 16 in 1987-88. Reviews of existing dumping duties have increasingly revoked those duties. These are all good signs. However, the number of dumping duties which are longstanding is still a matter of concern, and the length of application of these duties indicates the myths that surround commercial practices that are often branded as dumping. The Industries Assistance Commission, which has seen its scrutiny of anti-dumping measures reduced by the Labor Government, was moved to observe in its last annual report:
There is potential, however, for on-going conflict between an anti-dumping system directed against `unfair' trading practices, and government initiatives to reduce protection.

That is precisely my point. This legislation is the first change to the Government's new anti-dumping regime. Ominously, it will increase the level of effective protection to industry and represents a cave-in to pressure from industry over quite a long period. The particular change we are considering will in effect increase the normal value that is calculated for imported goods about which a dumping complaint has been made by more frequently incorporating a profit level in a notional price. Goods which are sold in Australia below the normal value at which the same goods are sold in the country of origin are considered to have been dumped. In most cases the normal value is deemed to be the market price at which the goods are sold. However, the Australian Customs Service uses a formula to estimate such a price when the country of origin has a non-market economy, when the goods are not sold in their country of origin and when the goods are sold at a loss in their home country.

Professor Gruen argued that the use of a constructed value for goods in dumping complaints presented a range of problems and potential for abuse. To reduce these problems, he argued that an artificial level of profit should generally not be included when constructing a normal value. These proposed changes reject Professor Gruen's arguments in favour of a review done by the Anti-dumping Authority itself. In general, a profit will be included in the normal value if it is constructed, but at a level which is left to the discretion of the Authority. It is an open-ended change which will increase uncertainty and will often appear arbitrary. It is cloaked in largely tattered garments of moderation and plots a middle course between favouring free trade through an arbitrary ruling against the inclusion of profit and protection through use of the anti-dumping procedure. Whilst it is true that the review by the Anti-dumping Authority rejected some protectionist arguments, the effects of the change will, nonetheless, tend to increase the number of successful dumping complaints and, therefore, the overall level of protection provided by anti-dumping law.

International precedents make this change even more ominous. It is certainly true that this change will bring Australian law into line with other countries such as the United States. That is not necessarily a good thing. The use of contrived levels of presumed profit in the calculation of the normal value of supposedly dumped goods has been the foundation of much of the new protectionism which American anti-dumping legislation and practice represents. This new protectionism effectively puts a floor on the price of competition in national markets and insists on foreign companies increasing their revenue and profit margins at the expense of reducing the overall volume of imported goods.

For all the talk of fair trade, the most unfair trading practice in the contemporary international trading environment is the imposition of non-tariff trade barriers. The assumption that a certain level of profit should be included in the artificial calculation of price which determines whether unfair trading has occurred has no justification in normal commercial practice. If the same standards were applied to the trade practices of domestic commercial firms, then most retail sales after periods of high demand, such as Christmas, would be outlawed.

Anti-dumping legislation represents one of the few forms of protection which is allowable under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade rules. For this reason, there is a tendency to use it extensively and more often. The argument that other countries do it, therefore we should follow, is a well-worn defence of all forms of protection. It is wrong. It is in the interests of Australian consumers to purchase goods for the cheapest price at which they are available. The gains to the economy from the more efficient use of resources which these price decisions represent outweigh any potential loss to a particular business or industry. Retaliatory protection has never reduced trade barriers. Instead, it has acted to ratchet up the general level of protection and undermine the flow of trade. The current boom in non-tariff protection, such as anti-dumping legislation, reflects international competition between governments to outdo each other in looking after local industry at the expense of local consumers and, in the long run, to the cost of local industry.

To put this discussion in context, I want to look briefly at what dumping and unfair trade are-or, more precisely, at what the Minister tells us they are. The Minister in his second reading speech said:
Dumping occurs when the price at which goods are exported to Australia . . . is less than the normal value of the goods in the country of export.

One might ask: What is wrong with that? Surely, if Australians can get goods at cheaper prices than someone else, then we should take advantage of our good fortune; but not according to the proponents of anti-dumping regulation. To these people, cheap goods are not what they seem. They are part of a movement which will drive many Australian manufacturers to the wall. Cheap goods more often than not are dumped on Australian markets to get rid of them, possibly with some commercial advantage in terms of market share. It is suggested that once an Australian industry is ruined the companies exporting to Australia can then take advantage of their position by charging inflated prices.

This predatory pricing, as it is known, is penalised by anti-dumping law in Australia if prices charged in Australia can be shown to be less than in the country of origin of the goods and if material injury can be demonstrated by the complainant. The implicit assumption of fair trade laws such as those against dumping in Australia is that if any foreign company successfully competes and takes business away from an Australian firm, then it is guilty of causing damage to local business. In fact, in tight market conditions where damage can be proved, the advantages from cheap imports are likely to be at their highest for Australian importers. This is the silly foundation of anti-dumping law.

There are other problems with the Minister's definition. The greatest of these is defining the so-called normal value of goods. It is not just a problem of determining that value. It also ignores such common commercial practices as differential pricing. It ignores the different market conditions which might apply to Australian demand for those goods. Fundamentally, it misunderstands the nature of the price mechanism in a market economy. Anti-dumping legislation distorts the price signals on the local market, thus inhibiting the ability of local firms to respond to demand.

Predatory pricing designed to drive competitors out of business, which was a feature of arguments about monopoly legislation in the United States, is not a common practice, largely because in a relatively open market it cannot work. As long as Australia is open to imports from a range of sources, monetary loss faces any company which sells goods to Australia at beneath the actual cost of producing them. We should allow Australian consumers to take advantage of such folly. Much so-called dumping is little more than the clearing of a glut in the supply of a product on international markets, little different from a retailer's sale of surplus stock at a discounted price. This process is in the long term interests of Australian manufacturers, who compete on international markets.

However, most of the dumping complaints do not arise from competitive industries. They arise when a locally based firm has lost a contract and seeks some way of gaining a slightly lower price than its competition without reducing its price and therefore its profit margins, or the conditions of its employees. Most of the initiators of dumping complaints have been from the chemical and petroleum products industry, the base metals industry, and machinery and equipment manufacturing interests. In the past, textiles and food and beverages industries also made a contribution to such complaints.

Not only are these industries already relatively heavily protected, but the reasons for inefficiency and uncompetitiveness can not be blamed on international competition. One recent complaint involved the importation of coloured pencils, at supposedly dumped prices, from three other countries. I doubt that any honourable member opposite could seriously argue that a foreign firm is using its market power to develop a coloured pencil monopoly, or that the Australian coloured pencil industry is so important that it must be protected from competition, despite the much higher charges to those parents of children who are the consumers and who will pay for that protection.

There are many distortions of international trade, and governments produce many of those distortions through subsidy and centralised marketing arrangements which lead to distortion of prices. However, it has not been demonstrated that Australians should not take advantage of the cheaper goods which this can provide, whilst the Government uses international forums to advance its version of free trade. The extension of those distortions through non-tariff barriers, is unworthy of this Government and its fine words on free trade, but it is typical of the double standards which we have come to expect from the Hawke Labor Government.

This legislation will, if only to a small degree, slow up both the process of industrial reform in Australia and the reductions of taxpayer funded protection. It will give a further out to companies, and particularly trade unions, afraid of competition from their fellow workers, both in Australia and overseas. The economic arguments against the extensive use of anti-dumping legislation are overwhelming. The Opposition did not support the establishment of the Anti-Dumping Authority, and the first piece of legislation arising from its work-the piece that is before us-firmly suggests that this was the correct decision to take. The assertion that `fair trade' must be seen as an alternative to `free trade' is nonsense. The only fair trade involves true competition for price and quality as assessed by consumers. Dumping duties do not allow or encourage such competition. As Professor Gruen said in the Australian Financial Review of 4 May 1988:

Anti-dumping policies are used predominantly by certain rich, unadaptable economies... which find it politically easier to use anti-dumping techniques for protecting their industries than to allow their industries to compete freely.
That is a pretty good description of our economy under the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to the contribution by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), and the sorts of observations that he made, I have to wonder what planet he comes from. We have just heard an extraordinary set of propositions. The previous speaker seemed to be saying that Australia should not have any anti-dumping mechanisms or protection. He rejected as spurious the distinction between fair and free trade. I believe he has failed to see what the function of anti-dumping legislation is. It is not intended to be-and I do not believe that under this legislation it will in practice be-a form of industry protection. It is a form of protection against unfair trading practices.

SPEECH.PARA: We live in a mercantilist world. The previous speaker's Pollyanna remarks related to how one could let the market decide matters. He pretended that if people dump product on the Australian market, that represents some sort of unsolicited free gift for the people of Australia. He made some incredible remarks. Is he seriously saying that we, unlike practically every other developed economy, have no effective procedures to protect against this sort of practice? Do we wait for predatory companies from overseas to come in and effectively destroy large sections of our industrial and manufacturing base beyond the point of repair and beyond the point where it can be restored? We would then be subject to enormous market power on the part of those same overseas producers against which we have no effective competitive defences. This would create massive unemployment and would turn Australia into an industrial wasteland. Is that what the honourable member wants us to do? Obviously, he does. I am not really sure what interests he represents or purports to represent when he makes these sorts of remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I think that is an unworthy reflection on me. I have never taken such a point of order before.

—It arguably may have been a rhetorical proposition, but I am sure the honourable member for Sydney will be sensitive to the feelings of the honourable member for Curtin and the fact that he has been affronted. I invite him to withdraw any intention perceived that he may have been so intent.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: I would have thought that I was addressing the arguments that the honourable member put forward. I do not think that anything I said amounted to a personal reflection on the previous speaker.

—The honourable member presses the matter and invites the Chair to be a little more deliberate in its assessment of the situation. The Chair is of the opinion that arguably there was a suggestion of a questionable motivation implicit in the remarks. I require the honourable member to withdraw.

—In deference to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I withdraw. Having made those few observations on the extraordinary contribution by the previous speaker, I will now talk more generally about this legislation. It needs to be seen in the context of a significant revision of anti-dumping legislation in recent times. Part of the legislation deals with a fairly technical matter-the need to avoid some unconstitutionality. That has required a degree of restructuring of the legislation to avoid any potential problem with section 55 of the Constitution. I will not comment further on that matter because I do not think there is any great controversy about that. It does not really go to the major substantial elements in the legislation that is before us.

SPEECH.PARA: The main matter before us is the question of normal value and the circumstances in which a profit component can be included in the construction of a normal value. This was one of a number of matters that have been of concern to Australian industry, both on the employer and the trade union side, in recent times. There are a number of other matters, including the question of the definition of `material injury'. These several matters have been considered by the Anti-Dumping Authority and it has recently placed before the Minister a report with a set of recommendations dealing with a number of matters of general principle as distinct from specific inquiries.

In terms of the way the Anti-Dumping Authority has conducted these inquiries, the attempts at consultation with industry have been admirable and, hopefully, that will set some sort of pattern for future developments in the way these sorts of inquiries are conducted. Anti-dumping legislation is, of course, a politically sensitive matter. In recent times we have seen demonstrations by people involved in the cement and tyre industries and some sectors of that sort. There has been concern. It has become a live political issue in some electorates.

As chair of the Caucus industry committee I would have to say that the issue has attracted great interest from other members of Caucus who are not necessarily members of the committee as a result of the fact that there is an obvious degree of electoral sensitivity if there are industries where people in specific electorates are quite directly and specifically affected. Of course, the local members start to feel the heat from that. It is undoubtedly a politically controversial issue.

It is also intrinsically very important economically. For an industry like the chemicals industry, for example, which might be contemplating a major investment decision and adding to its capacity in a pretty significant way, it is one thing to have a carefully structured reduction in the protection regime which is predictable and capable of being taken into account by a firm which is considering an investment; what is considerably more difficult to take into consideration is the prospect of several shiploads of dumped product suddenly turning up in an Australian port and wiping out the market in an industry very quickly and for a considerable period. That element of risk associated with that sort of development really is one of the major disincentives and one of the major factors holding back investment in additional capacity.

Having talked to quite a few people in industry who have the responsibility for making these sorts of decisions, I can state that there is no question but that the concern and uncertainty relating to the possibility of the sudden arrival of a large quantity of dumped product is very significant. Arguably more significant than the actual level of formal protection itself is concern about the risk of suddenly being confronted with dumping. The previous speaker talked about uncertainty and the need to eliminate it. If he is talking about some sort of orderly development of key sectors of Australian industry, the elimination of the form of uncertainty that arises from dumping is terribly important. He seemed quite oblivious to that consideration.

As to anti-dumping legislation, there has been a lot of talk about a need for a level playing field. That is the current buzz phrase. People say that we need to free things up, remove artificial distortions and have a situation where Australian industry is able to complete on an equal footing with the industries of other countries. I have always had a degree of scepticism about some of that rhetoric. The previous speaker spoke about non-tariff barriers. Some countries have been able to develop their industry successfully in the post-War period, but the idea that removing all protection from the domestic market and throwing the whole thing open to the free play of market forces represents a route towards a viable industry development model is belied by the actual experience of countries like Japan and South Korea, of Western Europe and so forth. But, even if one accepts that a level playing field is desirable and accepts the basic propositions which underlie that type of rhetoric, I think it is reasonable that is should be a genuine level playing field. In the field of anti-dumping legislation there has been some concern from industry as to whether that is the case.

To refer to the present legislation and the method of construction of a normal value, this issue of whether one includes a profit component concerns industry quite a bit. The industry quite reasonably argues that no business operates on the presumption that it will earn a zero profit; that it will have a zero rate of return on its shareholders' funds. In the real world that is quite unrealistic. I point to a case in the United States of America, where a fixed profit margin of, I think, 8 per cent is included. They say, `If that is the sort of situation that prevails with our major trading partners, why should we not have similar provisions in our legislation?' In other words, industry representatives are saying , `Okay, let us have a level playing field but our protection against predatory practices and unfair trading practices, against dumping and so forth, should be no less strong than that available to our major trading partners'. That is the argument the industry puts forward and it is why this question of inclusion of a non-zero profit component in a constructed normal value has come to the fore. That, together with other issues such as the definition of material injury, are terribly important in determining how effective in practice anti-dumping legislation will be.

The material injury question is not really the subject of the current legislation, but it was one of several issues that were considered by the Caucus industry committee. As a result of quite a discussion that took place at the Caucus industry committee, a number of references were made to the Anti-Dumping Authority. Part of the Anti-Dumping Authority's response to those references is the subject of the legislation before us today. There was a sentiment among Caucus members concerned with industry policy that, while acknowledging that we are subject to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and that we cannot simply flout the provisions of that, it is reasonable that we try to utilise to the fullest extent available the provisions of the GATT anti-dumping code so that we have protection against dumping which is consistent with but not significantly weaker than what the GATT code envisages and provides for.

Again, on that matter of material injury, which is not the subject before us today, there was a concern that we were adopting an overly restrictive definition of material injury and that there would have to be a substantial drop in profitability and/or market share. But the GATT anti-dumping code envisages a whole range of possible measures or indicators of material injury so it was felt that we ought to broaden that out. Again, that is not the subject of today's legislation.

Certainly the inclusion of a non-zero profit component seems to me difficult to argue with. The Opposition claims to have a number of people who represent, come from or are knowledgeable about the operations of the business sector. It would be interesting if its members could point to some of their colleagues in the business world who would consider that having a zero profit margin and zero rate of return on shareholders' funds was somehow a viable way to conduct a business. It would be pretty extraordinary if they did.

This legislation envisages the possibility of a non-zero profit margin. It prescribes a non-zero profit margin in one particular case. Subsection 5 (9) of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 says that, if there is a case where it is necessary to construct a normal value because of the fact that a product is being sold in the country of export at a loss over an extended period, it can be argued by the Minister or the Anti-Dumping Authority that it would be inappropriate to include a non-zero profit margin in that case. But in general the idea of including a profit margin-which may be zero, depending on the circumstances but that could be a matter of decision on a case to case basis-seems to me self-evident. For the Opposition to be attacking this legislation and the Government's approach to it in the way it has is absolutely extraordinary. How can anybody argue that Australia should not have any effective anti-dumping measures? That was the essence of what the previous speaker argued. It shows in the clearest and starkest terms the nature of the Opposition's commitment to the development of Australian industry. In other words, the Opposition is saying, `Okay, we will open up our industries to the most predatory practices, with no protection whatsoever. We will supposedly be committed to a level playing field but we will have considerably weaker or in fact non-existent. . .'--
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent times some important changes have occurred in economic activity in this country. For the first time we have a strongly growing economy but an Opposition that is willing to bring on a recession. That should be made very clear. The Liberal Party's action plan really is all about bringing on a recession. I should like to explain what that means. When I first became a member of this House it was very noticeable that the Labor Party was clearing up the mess of mass unemployment that has occurred throughout the Australian community. It had to repair the damage that had been caused by the Liberal Party. It has been a long haul, but the Labor Party has got on top of the problem essentially because it has policies about retraining and housing and an industrial relations system that works.

SPEECH.PARA: When one considers the recently released economic policy of the Liberal Party, one discovers two or three issues. Firstly, the Liberal Party would relinquish control over interest rates through the Reserve Bank. The Liberal Party would return the proceeds of fiscal drag and bracket creep back to the consumers, which would lead to a very demand-led economy. In those circumstances the only way to reduce that demand would be by promoting mass unemployment. That point should be pressed home. The other night the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) spoke about taxation policy and capital gains tax. The Liberal Party wants to remove retraining, particularly that of Aborigines, and to remove the Jobstart program. When we put all those things together, it is clear-it is on the record-when we couple it with the fact that the Liberal Party is promoting a recession--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—The Liberal Party is in fact talking about increasing the level of unemployment. Many people in my electorate say to me, `It is not the fact that I am unemployed but, when I do become unemployed, as happens in a dynamic economy, I am going to get no support or help if the Liberal Party is in government'. That is the substantial position. That is the big worry, and the point must be emphasised. We cannot afford to return to the level of social division and social concern that existed when the Labor Party came to government.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories will cease interjecting.

—During the past 10 or 12 days, from talking to many people in the community, I have learned that they recognise that, as do many people in the business community which is the other interesting aspect. They are not prepared to tolerate a Russian roulette industrial relations policy-not knowing when they are going to be knocked over by the system of contracting out which the Liberal Party is going to bring in in industrial relations. People will make an assessment when they consider the pattern of unemployment creation, the proposed taxation changes and also the industrial relations system. I heard what the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) said before. However, what I am saying is the case, because those are the circumstances that exist.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed out today, the capital gains tax is a very central issue. It is about giving back a very large windfall gain to those who do not need it. The Opposition talks about business; but in its period in office it did nothing about the double taxation of dividends. The Labor Party introduced dividend imputation. The Opposition did nothing about reducing the top marginal rate. The Labor Party had to do that. One must consider the structural questions and the Opposition's record. It is clear that the Opposition's policy would create division and a lack of social cohesion.

In terms of training and taxation policy, the Government is prepared to restore equity and fairness to the system. The people in the community who have jobs and houses understand that. The Government is very clear on that. That has always been its position. However, the Opposition is not happy with that because it is the truth.

On a more optimistic note, I am pleased to advise that the Government Whip, the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham,) is 50 years of age today. I am sure that he would appreciate having the company of members of this House for a refreshment following the adjournment of this House. Because he has been a member of this House for a long time, I know that he has the respect of many.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 4 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to criticisms by senior RAAF officers of the proposed construction of the Badgerys Creek Airport and the impact air traffic at that airport will have on air traffic at the RAAF Richmond base and at Schofields; if so, what is his response.

(2) Will he provide (a) details of the proposed flight paths for the Badgerys Creek Airport and (b) the overall plan for the management of air space in the Sydney Basin following the construction of the Badgerys Creek Airport.
(3) What will be the impact of the Badgerys Creek Airport on air traffic using airfields at Hoxton Park and Camden.
(4) Has his Department reviewed the original flight paths proposed for the Badgerys Creek Airport.
(5) Has there been any change to the original flight paths; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The potential impact of air traffic using a major airport at Badgerys Creek on air traffic at the RAAF Richmond base and at Schofields was addressed in the Environmental Impact Statement for the Second Sydney Airport following consultation with the Department of Defence.

(2) Details of the flight paths to the proposed general aviation aerodrome at Badgerys Creek and the overall management of the Sydney Basin airspace following construction of that aerodrome have not been finalised.
(3) Operationally the initial development of Badgerys Creek as a general aviation aerodrome is not expected to significantly impact on air traffic using Hoxton Park and Camden aerodromes.

(4) and (5) Indicative flight paths, which formed the basis of the noise exposure forecasts, are shown in the Environment Impact Statement for Badgerys Creek as a major international airport. These flight paths relate to the operation of the airport at its maximum capacity. They have not been reviewed.
